description: Find the leg or hypotenuse of a right triangle using the Pythagorean theorem.
title: Pythagorean theorem

description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.
title: Pythagorean theorem

description:
Algebra is a beautiful and important area of study with unlimited applications.  One can spend a lifetime studying and exploring it (and some people do).  If you're not one of them, and are looking to learn, review or practice the most core ideas in Algebra, you've found your home.

This subject is ideal for anyone looking to prepare for a high school or college placement exam.  It covers all of the foundational ideas in algebra and related topics in pre-algebra and geometry.

If you're looking for more exhaustive coverage, then the Algebra I & II subjects may be better for you.
title: Algebra basics

description: Where did the word "Algebra" and its underlying ideas come from?
title: Origins of algebra

description: The general idea behind the word 'abstract'
title: Abstract-ness

description: Why the abstraction of mathematics is so fundamental.
title: The beauty of algebra

description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.
title: Intro to the coordinate plane

description: Jesse Roe and Sal Khan talk about why we use letters in algebra.
title: Why all the letters in algebra?

description:
Did you realize that the word "algebra" comes from Arabic (just like "algorithm" and "al jazeera" and "Aladdin")?  And what is so great about algebra anyway?  

This tutorial doesn't explore algebra so much as it introduces the history and ideas that underpin it.
title: Overview and history of algebra

description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.
title: What is a variable?

description: Great question. In algebra, we do indeed avoid using the multiplication sign. We'll explain it for you here.
title: Why aren't we using the multiplication sign?

description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").
title: Evaluating an expression with one variable

description: Practice plugging in a value for the variable in an equation. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.
title: Evaluating expressions with one variable

description: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.
title: Introduction to variables

description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables

description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables.
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables

description: Learn how to evaluate expressions that have two different variables in them by using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables: fractions & decimals

description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables. These problems include some fractions and decimals.
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables: fractions & decimals

description: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.
title: Substitution and evaluating expressions

description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!
title: Evaluating expressions with variables: temperature

description: Practice plugging in values to evaluate real-world algebraic expressions. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.
title: Evaluating expressions with variables word problems

description: In this example of evaluating expressions, we're dusting off some geometry. On top of that, it's a word problem. We're seeing how different concepts in math are layered on top of each to create more interesting and complex problems to solve.
title: Evaluating expressions with variables: cubes

description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents, specifically, are our focus here.
title: Evaluating expressions with variables: exponents

description: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.
title: Evaluating expressions word problems

description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.
title: Writing basic expressions with variables

description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.
title: Writing basic expressions with variables

description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions that involve grouping quantities in parentheses.
title: Writing expressions with variables & parentheses

description: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.
title: Writing algebraic expressions introduction

description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.
title: Equivalent expressions

description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.
title: Equivalent expressions

description: Learn to tell whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by combining like terms and using the distributive property.
title: Introduction to equivalent algebraic expressions

description: Here we have a problem that asks us to identify which variables are dependent and independent. Hint: independent variables are not influenced and remain unchanged by the other variable.
title: Dependent & independent variables

description: It's helpful to express an equation on a graph where we plot at least 2 points. Watch and we'll show you.
title: Dependent & independent variables: graphing

description: We're flipping the last video on its head and doing the opposite. This time we give you the graph and ask you to express it as an equation.
title: Dependent & independent variables: equation

description: Practice figuring out of a variable is dependent or independent.
title: Dependent & independent variables

description: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.
title: Dependent & independent variables

description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.
title: Intro to combining like terms

description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.
title: Simplifying expressions

description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.
title: Combining like terms challenge problem

description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. Coefficients on some terms are negative.
title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients

description: Practice combining like terms using the distributive property. These problems involve adding and subtracting negative numbers.
title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients & distribution

description: Learn how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.
title: Simplifying expressions with rational numbers

description: Practice combining like terms for expressions that have rational coefficients. This requires adding and subtracting fractions.
title: Combining like terms with rational coefficients

description: Learn how to combine like terms (with negative numbers and variables), including more complex problems involving the distributive property.
title: Combining like terms

description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.
title: Interpreting linear expressions: diamonds

description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.
title: Interpreting linear expressions: flowers

description: Practice interpreting linear expressions
title: Interpreting linear expressions

description: Any expression (mathematical or otherwise) has meaning. Help us match the linear expression to the meaning options given. In some cases, more than one meaning may apply.
title: Interpreting linear expressions

description: Sal explains why there cannot be a single number that is the result of dividing by zero.
title: Why dividing by zero is undefined

description: Sal explains why there cannot be a single number that is the result of dividing zero by zero.
title: The problem with dividing zero by zero

description: Sal revisits the problems of dividing any number by zero and dividing zero by zero. He shows, using general mathematical considerations, why those are undefined and indeterminate problems.
title: Undefined & indeterminate expressions

description: Sal uses algebraic reasoning to tackle the problems of dividing by zero.
title: Division by zero

description: This topic is an overview of the fundamental ideas and tools of algebra.
title: Introduction to algebra

description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations really are.
title: Variables, expressions, & equations

description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.
title: Testing solutions to equations

description: Practice plugging in values to equations and checking to see if the equations hold true.
title: Testing solutions to equations

description: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.
title: Algebraic equations basics

description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.
title: Same thing to both sides of equations

description: Equations are about relationships (no, not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.
title: Representing a relationship with an equation

description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?
title: One-step equations intuition

description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.
title: Dividing both sides of an equation

description: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it
title: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation

description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54
title: One-step subtraction equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals

description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals

description: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!
title: One-step division equations

description: Remember that what you do to one side, you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction, x/a? Let's do it together.
title: One-step multiplication equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations

description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals

description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals

description: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations

description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.
title: Intro to two-step equations

description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples, but you can do it!
title: Two-step equations intuition

description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2.
title: Two-step equations example

description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve.
title: Two-step equations

description: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.
title: Two-steps equations intro

description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.
title: Two-step equation word problem: computers

description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!
title: Two-step equation word problem: garden

description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video, we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41,790.
title: Two-step equation word problem: oranges

description: Practice writing equations to model real-world situations, then solve the equations to answer interesting questions about the situations.
title: Two-step equations word problems

description: Learn how to set up and solve equations to find answers to real-world questions.
title: Two-step equation word problems

description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.
title: Why we do the same thing to both sides: Variable on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.
title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.
title: Equations with variables on both sides: 20-7x=6x-6

description: Practice solving one-variable equations like 20 - 7x = 6x - 6, where the variable appears on both sides of the equals sign.
title: Equations with variables on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.
title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions

description: Solve linear equations where the variable appears on both sides of the equation and the coefficients are decimals or fractions.
title: Equations with variables on both sides: decimals & fractions

description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.
title: Equation with the variable in the denominator

description: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.
title: Linear equations with variables on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
title: Equations with parentheses

description: Practice solving equations with parentheses using the distributive property.
title: Equations with parentheses

description: Solve linear equations that contain expressions with parentheses and the coefficients are rational numbers.
title: Equations with parentheses: decimals & fractions

description: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).
title: Linear equations with parentheses

description: Sal shows how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.
title: Number of solutions to equations examples

description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.
title: Number of solutions to equations: 8(3x+10)=28x-14-4x

description: Practice telling whether an equation has one, zero, or infinite solutions.
title: Number of solutions to equations

description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.
title: Creating an equation with no solutions

description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.
title: Creating an equation with infinitely many solutions

description: Given a linear equation with missing values, determine appropriate values in order to have one, zero, or infinite solutions.
title: Number of solutions to equations challenge

description: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.
title: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?
title: Sums of consecutive integers

description: Practice finding the nth number in a sequence of consecutive numbers based on the sum.
title: Sums of consecutive integers

description: Sal solves the following problem: The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 231. What is the largest integer?
title: Sum of integers challenge

description: Sal solves the following word problem: You have 50 ounces of a 25% saline solution. How many ounces of a 10% saline solution must you add to make a solution that is 15% saline?
title: Linear equation word problem: saline

description: Sal solves the following problem: Drink A with 40% sugar is mixed with Drink B to obtain Drink C which has 25% sugar. What is the percentage of sugar of Drink B?
title: Linear equation word problem: sugary drinks

description: Solve word problems by creating linear equations and solving them.
title: Linear equations word problems

description: Sal solves the equations ax+3x=bx+5 and a(5-x)=bx-8 for x. Note that these equations include other unknowns (a and b) but we solve them for x.
title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients

description: Solve a linear equation where the coefficients are represented by letters.
title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients

description: An equation like ax+3x=bx+5 can still be solved for x even though some of the coefficients are variables.
title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients

description: equations of the form AX=B
title: Linear equations 1

description: solving equations of the form AX+B=C
title: Linear equations 2

description: Linear equations with multiple variable and constant terms
title: Linear equations 3

description: Solving linear equations with variable expressions in the denominators of fractions
title: Linear equations 4

description: Introduction to averages and algebra problems involving averages.
title: Averages

description: Taking a percentage of a number.
title: Taking percentages

description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.
title: Growing by a percentage

description: Slightly harder percent problems
title: More percent problems

description: Sal solves the equation P=2I+2w for the variable I.
title: Solving an equation for a variable

description: Some of Sal's oldest (and roughest) videos on algebra.  Great tutorial if you want to see what Khan Academy was like around 2006.  You might also like it if you feel like Sal has lost his magic now that he doesn't use the cheapest possible equipment to make the videos.
title: Old school equations with Sal

description: Learn how to solve linear equations that contain a single variable. For example, solve 2(x+3)=(4x-1)/2+7.
title: One-variable linear equations

description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.
title: Testing solutions to inequalities

description: Practice plugging in values to inequalities and checking to see if the inequalities hold true.
title: Testing solutions to inequalities

description: Learn how to graph an inequality on a number line to indicate which values make it true.
title: Plotting inequalities

description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.
title: Plotting an inequality example

description: Create  number line graphs of inequalities.
title: Plotting inequalities

description: Learn how to write inequalities to model real-world situation.
title: Inequalities word problems

description: Practice writing inequalities with variables to describe real-world situations.
title: Inequalities word problems

description: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.
title: Introduction to inequalities with variables

description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!
title: One-step inequalities examples

description: In addition to solving the inequality, we'll graph the solution. Remember to swap if you mutiply both sides of the inequality by a negative number.
title: One-step inequalities: -5c ≤ 15

description: Practice solving inequalities in one step.
title: One-step inequalities

description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.
title: One-step inequality word problem

description: Learn how to solve (mathematical) inequalities. A key concept in this tutorial is flipping the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number.
title: One-step inequalities

description: We're turning up the heat a little and asking you to help us solve a multi-step inequality problem.
title: Two-step inequalities

description: Solve 2-step inequalities like 3x + 2 > 5.
title: Two-step inequalities

description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.
title: Two-step inequality word problem: apples

description: Learn how to solve an inequality word problem about cell phone texting plans.
title: Two-step inequality word problem: texting

description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.
title: Two-step inequality word problem: R&B

description: Practice constructing, interpreting, and solving linear inequalities that model real-world situations.
title: Two-step inequality word problems

description: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.
title: Two-step inequalities

description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9, draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.
title: Inequalities with variables on both sides

description: Sal solves the inequality 5x+7>3(x+1), draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.
title: Inequalities with variables on both sides (with parentheses)

description: Sal solves several multi-step linear inequalities.
title: Multi-step inequalities

description: Solve linear inequalities that take multiple steps to solve.
title: Multi-step linear inequalities

description: Learn how to solve an inequality word problem about cell phone texting plans.
title: Two-step inequality word problem: texting

description: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.
title: Multi-step inequalities

description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.
title: Compound inequalities: 5z+7<27 or -3z≤18

description: Sal solves the compound inequality 3y+7<2y AND 4y+8>-48.
title: Compound inequalities: 3y+7<2y and 4y+8>-48

description: Solve compound linear inequalities.
title: Compound inequalities

description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5x-3<12 AND 4x+1>25, only to realize there's no x-value that makes both inequalities true.
title: A compound inequality with no solution

description: Sal solves the double inequality -16≤3x+5≤20, which is the same as the compound inequality -16≤3x+5 AND 3x+5≤20.
title: Double inequalities

description: Sal solves several compound linear inequalities.
title: Compound inequalities examples

description: Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.
title: Compound inequalities

description: Learn how to solve linear inequalities with a single variable. For example, solve -3(x+1)>2x-7. Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.
title: One-variable linear inequalities

description: Sal shows how we can treat units of measurement algebraically, and use these tools in order to convert between different units of the same quantity.
title: Intro to dimensional analysis

description: Sal finds an appropriate measurement unit for Power given the formula P=W/t where P is Power, W is Work, and t is Time.
title: Interpreting units in formulas

description: Sal finds an appropriate measurement unit for carrot yield given the formula Y=2C/P where Y is yield, C is # of carrots, and P is # of plants.
title: Interpreting units in formulas: novel units

description: Determine the appropriate unit of a quantity based on a formula containing that quantity.
title: Interpret units in formulas

description: Sal is given the formula K=b/s^2, along with the units of measurement for b and s. He uses the given information to determine the appropriate unit of measurement for K.
title: Appropriate units

description: Learn how to work with units that are arithmetic combinations of more simple units. For example, velocity units are quotients of distance units over time units, which corresponds to the formula v=d/t.
title: Intro to dimensional analysis

description: Sal shows how we can describe the rate 50 km per hour in a variety of different units, using dimensional analysis.
title: Same rate with different units

description: Sal shows how we can describe the length 4.5 yards in a variety of different units.
title: Same length in different units

description: Practice solving word problems that involve the conversion between different units for the same quantity. For example, a rate problem where some rates are in km/h and some are in m/s.
title: Dimensional analysis for converting

description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.
title: Proportion word problems: dimensional analysis

description: In middle school we learn how to solve proportion problems using proportional reasoning. In this tutorial you will learn how to solve those problems using dimensional analysis.
title: Dimensional analysis for proportional reasoning

description: Sal solves a word problem where he finds the cost of gas in a road trip given the car's fuel efficiency, length of the trip, and price of gas.
title: Multiple units word problem: road trip

description: Sal solves a US customary distance word problem involving miles, yards, and feet.
title: Measurement word problem: running laps

description: Solve word problems that contain multiple quantities that are measured in different units.
title: Multiple units word problems

description: Future doctors and nurses out there, take note. This unit conversion word problem deals with converting drug dosage units, something that is commonly done in hospitals. Give it a try with us.
title: Multiple units word problem: drug dosage (advanced)

description: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.
title: Word problems with multiple units

description: Sal determines which statement is reasonable based on the claim that a car has an estimated gas mileage of 24 miles per gallon.
title: Reasonable inferences from estimates

description: This tutorial discusses the delicate relationship between descriptive mathematics (which can be very precise) and the real world it describes (which usually isn't precise at all).
title: Determining precision in descriptive modeling

description: Modeling is an amazing world, full of challenges. In this topic, we will start to think about some general modeling concerns, before we dive into modeling situations with different kinds of functions and equations throughout the Algebra curriculum.
title: Units of measurement in modeling

description: Introduction to 2-variable linear equations and their graphs
title: 2-variable linear equations & their graphs

description: Sal checks whether given ordered pairs are solutions to a given two-variable equation.
title: Solutions to 2-variable equations

description: Sal checks whether given ordered pairs are solutions to a given two-variable equation.
title: Solutions to 2-variable equations

description: Determine which ordered pairs are solutions to equations.
title: Solutions to 2-variable equations

description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.
title: Graphing a linear equation: 5x+2y=20

description: Given a 2-variable equation and the x or y values of a solution, Sal finds the value of the other variable in the solution.
title: Completing solutions to 2-variable equations

description: Given the x or y value of a 2-variable equation solution, find the value for the other variable in the solution.
title: Complete solutions to 2-variable equations

description: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.
title: Ordered-pair solutions to two-variable linear equations

description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.
title: Intro to intercepts

description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards, he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.
title: x-intercept of a line

description: Look at the graph of an equation to find x-intercepts and y-intercepts
title: Intercepts from a graph

description: Sal finds the y-intercept of the graph of a linear function given a table of values.
title: Intercepts from a table

description: Find the intercepts of a line given a table of values.
title: Intercepts from a table

description: Sal finds the x and y-intercepts of -5x + 4y = 20.
title: Intercepts from an equation: -5x+4y=20

description: Solve linear equations for the x-intercept and y-intercept
title: Intercepts from an equation

description: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.
title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts

description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.
title: Intro to slope

description: Sal analyzes what it means for a slope to be positive or negative (spoiler: it affects the direction of the line!)
title: Positive & negative slope

description: Sal uses a clever proof involving similar triangles to show that slope is constant for a line.

description: Find the slope of a line on the coordinate plane.

description: Sal finds the slope of the line that goes through the ordered pairs (4,2) and (-3, 16).
title: Slope from two points: (4,2) & (-3,16)

description: Sal finds the slope of the line that goes through the ordered pairs (7, -1) and (-3, -1).
title: Slope from two points: (7,-1) & (-3,-1)

description: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.
title: Slope

description: Sal introduces the idea of slope-intercept form using simple examples like y = 2x + 3.

description: Find the slope of a line from its equation.

description: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

description: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

description: Find the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph.

description: Find the equation of a line passing through two points

title: Slope from linear standard form

description: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

description: Learn about linear equations that contain two variables, and how these can be represented by graphical lines and tables of values.

description: Functions assign a single unique output for each of their inputs. In this video, Sal gives many examples of various kinds of functions.
