title: Match function inputs to outputs from a formula

description: Sal finds the input value for which g(x)=-2 given the graph of g.
title: How to match function input to output given the graph (example)

description: Sal finds the input value other than -5 for which f(x)=f(-5), given the graph of f.
title: How to find two function inputs with the same output given graph (example)

description: Find all the inputs that correspond to a given function output, using the function's graph.
title: Match function inputs to outputs from a graph

description: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.
title: Inputs and outputs of a function

description: Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions
title: Equations vs. functions

description: Sal find the formula of a function that, given an input value "b," outputs a value "a" that satisfies the equation 4a+7b=-52.
title: How to create a function from an equation (example)

description: Create functions that match one variable to the other in a two-variable equation.
title: Function rules from equations

description: Understand the subtle differences and similarities between functions and equations. In this exercise, we will see how an equation can be turned into a function.
title: Functions and equations

description: Sal interprets the expression M(30)-M(0)=100 where M models an account balance over time.
title: How to interpret an expression with function notation (example with a function that models a bank account)

description: Sal interprets the expression P(5)<P(9) where P models the number of people at the beach over time.
title: How to interpret an expression with function notation (example with a function that models the number of people at the beach)

description: Interpret expressions with function notation in terms of the context that the function models.
title: Function notation interpretation word problems

description: Solve some word problems by interpreting expressions of modeling functions.
title: Interpreting function notation

description: Intervals describe specific sets of numbers and are very useful when discussing domain and range. In this video, Sal introduces the different types of intervals and their notations.
title: Intervals and interval notation

description: Sal introduces the concept of "domain" of a function and gives various examples for functions and their domains.
title: What is the domain of a function?

description: Sal introduces the concept of "range" of a function and gives examples for functions and their ranges.
title: What is the range of a function?

description: Sal solves multiple examples where the graph of a function is given and the question asks for the domain or the range of that function.
title: How to find the domain and the range of a function given its graph (example)

description: Given the graph of a function, determine its domain or range.
title: Domain and range from graph

description: Learn what the domain and the range of a function are. Practice finding the domain and the range of a function given its graph.
title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function

description: Sal finds the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
title: Domain of a radical functions

description: Sal gives many examples where he determines the domains of functions according to mathematical limitations.
title: How to determine the domain of algebraic functions (examples)

description: Determine the domain of a function according to the algebraic limitations of that function.
title: Determine the domain of functions

description: Sal determines the domain of a function that models the height of a plant over time.
title: How to determine the domain of a modeling function (example with a function that is defined over the real numbers)

description: Sal determines the domain of a function that models the price of candy bars.
title: How to determine the domain of a modeling function (example with a function that is defined over the positive integers)

description: Sal determines the domain of a function that models going up and down a ladder.
title: How to determine the domain of a modeling function (example with a function that is defined over negative and positive integers)

description: Use information about a situation to figure out the domain of the function which models it.
title: Function domain word problems

description: Determine the domains of functions according to various considerations.
title: Determining the domain of a function

description: Sal checks whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
title: Checking if a set of points represents a function

description: Sal explains why a vertical line *doesn't* represent a function.
title: Does a vertical line represent a function?

description: Determine whether a given graph represents a function.
title: Recognize functions from graphs

description: Sal checks whether a table of people and their heights can represent a function that assigns a height to a name.
title: Checking if two quantities represents a function: heights

description: Determine whether a table of values of a relationship represents a function.
title: Recognize functions from tables

description: Sal checks whether y can be described as a function of x if y is always three more than twice x.
title: Is this a function? (verbal description of equation)

description: Sal checks whether a description of the price of an order can be represented as a function of the shipping cost.
title: Checking if two quantities represents a function: price & cost

description: Recognizing functions
title: Recognizing functions

description: Sal explains what a piecewise function is, and finds the formula of a piecewise function given its graph.
title: Introduction to piecewise functions

description: Sal evaluates piecewise functions at given inputs, both from a formula and from a graph.
title: How to evaluate a piecewise function from its formula or graph (example)

description: Given the formula of a piecewise function, evaluate it for a specific input.
title: Evaluate piecewise functions from the formula

description: Given the graph of a step function, find the function's outputs for given specific inputs.
title: Evaluate step functions from their graph

description: Sal graphs a piecewise function given its formula. In this case, the function consists of three separate lines.
title: How to graph a piecewise function (example)

description: Draw the graph of a piecewise function or determine its formula from its graph.
title: Graphs of piecewise linear functions

description: Sal finds the domain and range of a piecewise function that is constant in each segment. Such functions are called "step functions."
title: How to find the domain and range of a piecewise function (example with a step function)

description: Sal finds the domain and range of a piecewise function where each segment is linear.
title: How to find the domain and range of a piecewise function (example with a piecewise-linear function)

description: Find the domain and range of a piecewise function given its formula.
title: Domain and range of piecewise functions

description: Introduction to piecewise defined functions
title: Piecewise functions

description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.
title: Introduction to minimum and maximum points

description: Sal gives multiple examples where he identifies relative maximum points, relative minimum points, absolute maximum points, and absolute minimum points.
title: How to recognize relative and absolute maxima and minima (example)

description: Given the graph of a function, find all of its relative maximum and minimum points.
title: Recognize relative maxima and minima

description: Given the graph of a function, find its absolute maximum and minimum points.
title: Recognize absolute maxima and minima

description: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.
title: Maximum and minimum points

description: Sal discusses there Intervals where function is increasing, decreasing, postive or negative and their graphical representation.
title: Introduction to increasing, decreasing, positive or negative intervals

description: Sal gives several example of graphs where he highlights positive or negative intervals of the function.
title: How to identify positive and negative intervals (example)

description: Highlight intervals on the domain of a function where it's entirely positive or entirely negative.
title: Positive and negative intervals

description: Highlight intervals on the domain of a function where it's only increasing or only decreasing.
title: Increasing and decreasing intervals

description: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.
title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing

description: Sal considers the graph of a function that models temperature over time, and matches features of that graph to their real-world meaning.
title: How to match the features of a modeling function to their real-world meaning (example)

description: Sal discusses the meaning of the y-intercept of the graph of a function that models the height of a ball.
title: How to interpret the y-intercept of a graph in context (example)

description: Match features of graphs of modeling functions to their real-world meaning.
title: Graph interpretation word problems

description: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.
title: Interpreting features of graphs

description: Sal explains what's the average rate of change of a function over an interval.
title: Introduction to average rate of change

description: Sal finds the interval in a function's graph where the function has an average rate of change of -4.
title: How to find the average rate of change from a graph (example)

description: Sal finds the average rate of change of a function over the interval -5<x<-2, given a table of values of the function.
title: How to find the average rate of change from a table (example)

description: Given the formula of a function, Sal finds the interval where the function has an average rate of change of 1/2.
title: How to find the average rate of change from a formula (example)

description: Find the average rate of change of a function over a given interval.
title: Finding average rate of change

description: Learn what's the average rate of change of a function and how to find it over given intervals.
title: Average rate of change

description: Sal compares the average rates of a change of a function that models temperature for different time intervals.
title: How to find the average rate of change of a modeling function from a table (example)

description: Given the graph of a skydiver's altitude, Sal finds the average rate of change in altitude over a given time interval.
title: How to estimate the average rate of change of a modeling function from a graph (example)

description: Sal finds the algebraic expression that represents the average rate of change of water in a drained bucket over a given time interval.
title: How to represent the average rate of change of a modeling function as an expression (example)

description: Find and represent the average rate of change of a real-world relationship.
title: Average rate of change word problems

description: Solve word problems that concern the average rate of change of a functional relationship.
title: Average rate of change word problems

description:
Functions are mathematical entities that assign unique outputs to given inputs. Sounds simple? Think again!

In this topic you will evaluate, graph, analyze, and create various types of functions.
title: Functions

description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.
title: Linear equations word problems: earnings

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear equations word problems: volcano

description: Solve word problems about real world relationships that are given in tables.
title: Linear equations word problems: tables

description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.
title: Linear graphs word problems

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear graphs word problem: cats

description: Solve word problems about real world relationships that are given in graphs.
title: Linear equations word problems: graphs

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone filling a glass tank with marbles. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear equations word problem: marbles

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing a top secret file transfer. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear equations word problem: file transfer

description: Solve word problems about real world relationships that are given in formulas.
title: Linear equations word problems

description: Solve word problems where you need to answer a question about a real-world relationship based on its mathematical model.
title: Interpreting linear functions and equations

description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.
title: Comparing linear functions

description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs, and is asked to determine which graph has the same rate of change as the function represented in the table.
title: Comparing linear functions (example 2)

description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs, and is asked to determine which graph increases faster than the function represented in the table.
title: Comparing linear functions (example 3)

description: Compare features of two linear functions represented in different ways.
title: Compare linear functions

description: Sal is given the formula and a table of values that represent two people climbing a wall, and is asked to determine which one started out higher.
title: Comparing linear functions word problem: climb

description: Sal is given a table of values that represents four people walking to school, and is asked to determine which one started out farther from the school.
title: Comparing linear functions word problem: walk

description: Sal is given a table of values that represents a person walking to work, and is asked to determine which verbal description represents someone starting at the same distance from work.
title: Comparing linear functions word problem: work

description: Compare features of two real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear functions, where the functions are represented in different ways.
title: Comparing linear functions word problem

description: Compare features of linear functions, such as slope and intercepts, where the functions are given in different forms—tables, graphs, or formulas.
title: Comparing linear functions

description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.
title: Linear functions word problem: fuel

description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a pool being filled with water, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.
title: Linear functions word problem: pool

description: Graph the line that represents a real-world relationship that is given verbally.
title: Graphing linear functions word problems

description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a melting iceberg, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.
title: Linear functions word problem: iceberg

description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a person painting his room, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.
title: Linear functions word problem: paint

description: Find a linear function that represents a real-world relationship that is given verbally.
title: Writing linear functions word problems

description: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.
title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships

description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.
title: Linear models word problem: book

description: Sal solves a word problem about a person filling a glass tank with marbles, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.
title: Linear models word problem: marbles

description: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.
title: Linear models word problems

description: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.
title: Linear models word problems

description: Solve various word problems that involve real world relationships that can be represented by linear equations or functions.
title: Linear equations and functions word problems

description: Sal explains sequences and gives examples of different sequences, defined either explicitly or recursively.
title: Intro to sequences

description: Sal shows how to evaluate a sequence that is defined with a recursive formula. This definition gives the base case and then defines how to find the subsequent terms using the base case.
title: Evaluating sequences in recursive form

description: Find the first few terms of sequences that are defined recursively.
title: Evaluate sequences in recursive form

description: Learn what sequences are, and about the explicit and recursive definitions of sequences. Evaluate sequences that are defined recursively.
title: Introduction to sequences

description: Sal introduces arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. He gives various examples of such sequences, defined explicitly and recursively.
title: Intro to arithmetic sequences

description: Sal extends the arithmetic sequences -8, -14, -20, -26,... and 2, -1, -4, -7, -10,... to find their next terms.
title: Extending arithmetic sequences

description: Given the first few terms in an arithmetic sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds terms of arithmetic sequences using their explicit and recursive formulas.
title: Using arithmetic sequences formulas

description: Given the formula of an arithmetic sequence, ether in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use arithmetic sequence formulas

description: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.
title: Introduction to arithmetic squences

description: Sal finds the recursive formula of the arithmetic sequence 4, 3⅘, 3⅗, 3⅖,...
title: Recursive formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Find the recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in an arithmetic sequence are 12, 5, -2, and -9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds the 100th term in the sequence 15, 9, 3, -3...
title: Arithmetic sequence problem

description: Sal is given an arithmetic sequence in explicit form and he converts it to recursive form. Then he does so the other way around!
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of arithmetic sequences

description: Given the explicit formula of an arithmetic sequence, find its recursive formula, and vice versa.
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of arithmetic sequences

description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.
title: Constructing arithmetic sequences

description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.
title: Intro to geometric sequences

description: Sal finds the next term in the geometric sequence -1/32, 1/8, -1/2, 2,...
title: Extending geometric sequences

description: Given the first few terms in a geometric sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend geometric sequences

description: Sal finds the 5th term in the geometric sequence whose explicit formula is 3(-¼)^(i-1).
title: Using explicit formulas of geometric sequences

description: Sal finds the 4th term in the sequence whose recursive formula is a(1)=-⅛, a(i)=2a(i-1).
title: Using recursive formulas of geometric sequences

description: Given the formula of a geometric sequence, either in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use geometric sequence formulas

description: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.
title: Introduction to geometric sequences

description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.
title: Explicit & recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in a geometric sequence are 1/3, 1, 3, and 9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for geometric sequences

description: Find the recursive formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of geometric sequences

description: Given the explicit formula of a geometric sequence, find its recursive formula, and vice versa.
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of geometric sequences

description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.
title: Constructing geometric sequences

description: Sal solves two word problems about modeling real-world situations with arithmetic and geometric sequences.
title: Sequences word problems

description: Given a verbal description of a real-world relationship, determine the sequence that models that relationship.
title: Sequences word problems

description: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.
title: Modeling with sequences

description: Learn about the various ways in which we can define sequences; Use and construct arithmetic and geometric sequences.
title: Sequences

description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.
title: Systems of equations: trolls, tolls (1 of 2)

description: Sal checks whether (-1,7) is a solution of the system: x+2y=13 and 3x-y=-11.
title: Testing a solution to a system of equations

description: Verify whether a given pair of values is a solution to a system of equations.
title: Test solutions to systems of equations

description: Learn what "systems of equations" are and what counts as a solution to such a system.
title: Introduction to systems of linear equations

description: Solving the system of equations visually. Now we can save the prince/princess.
title: Systems of equations: trolls, tolls (2 of 2)

description: Sal graphs the following system of equations and solves it by looking for the intersection point: y=7/5x-5 and y=3/5x-1.
title: Systems of equations with graphing: y=7/5x-5 & y=3/5x-1

description: Sal solves a system of two linear equations in standard form, and then approximates the solution of a system whose solution isn't clearly visible.
title: How to solve a system of linear equations, both exactly and approximately (example)

description: Graph a system of equations in slope-intercept or standard form, and find their solution using the graphs.
title: Systems of equations with graphing

description: Learn how to solve a system of equations by considering its graph, which turns out to be a VERY effective method.
title: Graphical representation of systems of equations

description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: King's cupcakes

description: Sal solves the following system of equations by eliminating x: x-4y=-18 and -x+3y=11.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: x-4y=-18 & -x+3y=11

description: Solve systems of equation with one-step elimination (e.g., x-values or y-values cancel each other out).
title: Systems of equations with elimination

description: Sal solves another system of equations using elimination.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: potato chips

description: Sal solves the following system of equations by manipulating it and then eliminating y: 5x-10y=15 and 3x-2y=3.
title: How to solve a system of linear equations with elimination (advanced example)

description: Solve systems of equation with multi-step elimination (e.g., a manipulation is needed in order for x-values or y-values to cancel each other out).
title: Systems of equations with elimination challenge

description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we can subtract one equation from the other in a system of equations.
title: Why can we subtract one equation from the other in a system of equations?

description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.
title: How to identify equivalent systems of equations (example)

description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.
title: How to identify non-equivalent systems of equations (example)

description: Determine whether a couple of given systems of equations are equivalent or not to a third given system.
title: Equivalent systems of equations

description: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!
title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method

description: Sal solves a systems of equations with substitution.
title: Systems of equations with substitution: potato chips

description: Sal solves the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.
title: Systems of equations with substitution: -3x-4y=-2 & y=2x-5

description: Solve systems of equations where one of the equations is solved for one of the variables.
title: Systems of equations with substitution

description: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.
title: Solving systems of equations with substitution

description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!
title: Systems of equations number of solutions: fruit prices (1 of 2)

description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!
title: Systems of equations number of solutions: fruit prices (2 of 2)

description: Sal determines whether a given system is consistent or not. Don't know what "consistent system" means? Watch this!
title: Systems of equations number of solutions: x+2y=13 & 3x-y=-11

description: Sal determines whether a given system is dependent or not. Don't know what "dependent system" means? Watch this!
title: Systems of equations number of solutions: 4x+2y=16 & y=-2x+8

description: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.
title: The possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations

description: Sal is given three lines on the coordinate plane, and identifies one system of two lines that has a single solution, and one system that has no solution.
title: Number of solutions to a system of equations

description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.
title: Systems of equations number of solutions: 10x-2y=4 & 10x-2y=16

description: Determine the number of solutions of a given system of equations by considering its graph.
title: Number of solutions to a system of equations graphically

description: Sal solves several examples where he reasons about the number of solutions of systems of equations using algebraic reasoning.
title: How to determine the number of solutions of a system of equations using algebraic reasoning (example)

description: Determine the number of solutions of a given system of equations by considering its algebraic solution process.
title: Number of solutions to a system of equations algebraically

description: Sal answers this question for you!
title: How many solutions does a system of linear equations have if there are at least two?

description: Learn how to determine the number of solutions a system of equations has, without having to go through the entire solution process.
title: Analyzing the solutions to systems of equations

description: Solve systems of equations with any number of solutions using any solution method.
title: Solve linear systems of equations

description: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!
title: Solving any system of linear equations

description: Sal solves a word problem about distances walking and riding bus to school, by creating a system of equations and solving it.
title: How to solve a word problem with a system of equations (example)

description: Sal answers a word problem about a toy factory and finds that it has no solution.
title: How to solve a word problem about a system of equations with no solution (example)

description: Sal answers a word problem about a vegetable farmer and finds that it has infinite solutions.
title: How to solve a word problem about a system of equations with infinite solutions (example)

description: Solve word problems by modeling them into a system of equations and solving it.
title: Systems of equations word problems

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?
title: Age word problem: Imran

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago, William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?
title: Age word problem: Ben & William

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?
title: Age word problem: Arman & Diya

description: Solve age word problems with a system of equations.
title: Age word problems

description: Sal solves a word problem about the weights of TVs and DVDs by creating a system of equations and solving it.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: TV & DVD

description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of apples and oranges by creating a system of equations and solving it.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: apples and oranges

description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of nickles and quarters in a piggy bank by creating a system of equations and solving it.
title: Systems of equations with substitution: coins

description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of coffee and croissant by creating a system of equations and solving it.
title: Systems of equations with elimination: coffee and croissants

description: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.
title: Systems of linear equations word problems

description: Learn how to interpret solutions to systems of linear equations and solve them.
title: Systems of linear equations

description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
title: Testing solutions to inequalities

description: Given a two-variable linear inequality, check whether a given pair of values is a solution of the inequality.
title: Test solutions to inequalities

description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality, check whether a given pair of values is a solution of the inequality.
title: Test solutions to inequalities: graphically

description: Sal checks whether the ordered pair (2,5) is a solution of the following system: y≥2x+1 and x>1.
title: Testing solutions to systems of inequalities

description: Check whether an ordered pair is a solution of a system of two-variable linear inequalities.
title: Test solutions to systems of inequalities

description: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.
title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities

description: Sal determines which x-values make the ordered pair (x,-7) a solution of 2x-7y<25, both algebraically and graphically.
title: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities

description: Find the range of values of one variable that corresponds to a given value of the other variable in a linear inequality.
title: Constraint solutions of two-variable inequalities

description: Given the graph of a system of inequalities, Sal finds the x-values that make the ordered pair (x,-2) a solution of the system.
title: Constraining solutions of systems of inequalities

description: Find the range of values of one variable that corresponds to a given value of the other variable in a system of two-variable linear inequalities.
title: Constraint solutions of systems of inequalities

description: Given a specific value for one of the variables in a two-variable linear inequality (or system of inequalities), learn how to find the corresponding range of values for the other variable. For example, given that x=3, what are the possible values for y in 2x+y<1 ?
title: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities

description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.
title: Intro to graphing two-variable inequalities

description: Sal graphs the inequality y<3x+5.
title: Graphing two-variable inequalities

description: Graph two-variable linear inequalities.
title: Graphs of two-variable inequalities

description: Sal is given a graph and he analyzes it to find the two-variable inequality it represents.
title: Two-variable inequalities from their graphs

description: Fit an algebraic two-variable inequality to its appropriate graph.
title: Two-variable inequalities from their graphs

description: Learn how to graph systems of two-variable linear inequalities, like "y>x-8 and y<5-x."
title: Intro to graphing systems of inequalities

description: Sal graphs the solution set of the system "y≥2x+1 and y<2x-5 and x>1."
title: Graphing systems of inequalities

description: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.
title: Graphing two-variable inequalities

description: Sal solves a word problem about scores in a chess tournament by creating a two-variable linear inequality.
title: Writing two-variable inequalities word problem

description: Sal analyzes a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about YouTube videos.
title: Interpreting two-variable inequalities word problem

description: Given a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about watering plants, Sal finds how many flowers can be watered.
title: Solving two-variable inequalities word problem

description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about dog biscuits, Sal finds if the dog can get enough biscuits.
title: Graphs of two-variable inequalities word problem

description: Solve word problems that involve linear inequalities in two variables.
title: Two-variable inequalities word problems

description: Sal models a real-world context into an algebraic system of linear inequalities and graphs it.
title: Modeling with systems of inequalities

description: Sal models a word problem about baking cupcakes and muffins by creating a system of linear inequalities.
title: Writing systems of inequalities word problem

description: Given a system of linear inequalities that models a context about making chairs and tables, Sal finds how many can be made.
title: Solving systems of inequalities word problem

description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about chopping vegetables, Sal finds if there's enough time to chop!
title: Graphs of systems of inequalities word problem

description: Solve word problems that involve systems of linear inequalities.
title: Systems of inequalities word problems

description: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.
title: Modeling with linear inequalities

description: In this topic, we study inequalities like x+2y>5 and graph them. This helps us see their solutions. We also explore systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities at the same time) and use them to describe real-world situations.
title: Two-variable linear inequalities

description: Sal introduces absolute value equations (like |x-5|=10) and graphs of absolute value functions (like y=|x+3|).
title: Intro to absolute value equations and graphs

description: Sal solves the equation 8|x+7|+4 = -6|x+7|+6.
title: Solving absolute value equations: two solutions

description: Sal solves the equation |3x-9|=0.
title: Solving absolute value equations: one solution

description: Sal solves the equation 4|x+10|+4 = 6|x+10|+10 to find that it has no possible solution.
title: Solving absolute value equations: no solution

description: Solve equations like 3|x+1| + 7 = 6|x+1| + 6.
title: Solve absolute value equations

description: Learn how to solve absolute-value equations. For example, solve 2|x-1|=5.
title: Solving absolute value equations

description: Sal discusses how the graph of an absolute value function looks, and its relationship with the formula of the function.
title: Intro to graphs of absolute value functions

description: Sal graphs the absolute value function f(x)=4|x+6|-8.
title: Graphing absolute value functions

description: Graph functions that contain absolute value expressions, like f(x)=|x+3|+2.
title: Graph absolute value functions

description: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.
title: Graphs of absolute value functions

description: Sal introduces the concept of inequalities that contain absolute value expressions, and solves a bunch of examples.
title: Intro to absolute value inequalities

description: Sal solves the inequality |h|-19.5 < -12.
title: Solving absolute value inequalities 1

description: Sal solves the inequality |p-12|+4 < 14.
title: Solving absolute value inequalities 2

description: Sal solves the inequality |2r-3 1/4| < 2 1/2.
title: Solving absolute value inequalities: fractions

description: Sal solves the inequality |y|+22 ≤ 13.5 to find that it has no solution.
title: Solving absolute value inequalities: no solution

description: Sal solves a word problem about a carpenter by writing an appropriate absolute value inequality and solving it.
title: Absolute value inequalities word problem

description: Learn how to solve absolute value inequalities. For example, solve |x-12|+4<14.
title: Solving absolute value inequalities

description: Learn how to solve absolute value equations, how to graph absolute value functions, and how to solve absolute value inequalities.
title: Absolute value equations, functions, and inequalities

description: Sal explains what it means to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction, like 1/2, 1/3, etc.
title: Intro to rational exponents

description: Sal explains the relationship between radical notation (like ∜7) and unit-fraction exponents (like 7^¼).
title: Radicals and exponents

description: Evaluate numerical expressions with unit-fraction exponents or radicals, and convert between the two forms of representations.
title: Rational exponents: unit fractions

description: Sal solves several problems about the equivalence of expressions with roots and rational exponents. For example, rewrite ⁶√(g⁵) as g^⅚.
title: Rewriting roots as rational exponents

description: Sal shows how to evaluate 9^(-1/2) and 27^(-1/3).
title: Evaluating rational exponents: negative unit-fraction

description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).
title: Evaluating rational exponents

description: Sal shows how to evaluate (25/9)^(1/2) and (81/256)^(-1/4).
title: Evaluating rational exponents: rational base

description: Sal solves the unknown in 3^a = ⁵√(3^2).
title: Converting from radical to exponential expression

description: Evaluate numerical expressions with rational exponents, and convert between equivalent forms of exponential and radical expressions.
title: Rational exponents

description: In this tutorial you will learn about radicals and about rational exponents and practice how to change back and forth from these two types of notation.
title: Introduction to rational exponents and radicals

description: Sal rewrites 5√117 as 15√13, and finds that 3√26 cannot be simplified further.
title: Simplifying square roots

description: Sal rewrites √(1/200) as 1/(10*√2) and as √2/20.
title: Simplifying square roots of fractions

description: For example, simplify √18 as 3√2.
title: Simplify square roots

description: Sal simplifies sums and products of square roots. For example, he simplifies -√40+√90 as √10.
title: Simplifying square-root expressions: no variables

description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide square roots. For example, simplify √50-√32.
title: Simplify square-root expressions: no variables

description: Sal simplifies elaborate expressions with square roots. For example, he simplifies (4√20-3√45)/√35 as -√(1/7).
title: Simplifying square-root expressions: no variables (advanced)

description: Practice simplifying expressions with multiple radical terms combined by addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division.
title: Simplify square-root expressions: no variables (advanced)

description: Sal manipulates expressions like 1/√2 and 12/(2-√5) so there's no radical in the denominator.
title: Intro to rationalizing the denominator

description: Sal rationalizes the denominator of the expression (16+2x²)/(√8).
title: Rationalizing the denominator

description: Sal simplifies √(2x²)+4√8+3√(2x²)+√8.
title: Simplifying radical expressions (addition)

description: Sal simplifies 4∜(81x⁵)-2∜(81x⁵)-√(x³).
title: Simplifying radical expressions (subtraction)

description: In this tutorial you will simplify numerical expressions with radicals by removing all factors that are perfect squares from inside the radical.
title: Simplifying numerical radical expressions

description: Sal simplifies the complicated expression 256^(4/7) / 2^(4/7)  until he finds that the expression is equal to 16.
title: Simplifying rational exponents

description: Sal simplifies the expression m^(7/9) / m^(1/3) as a single exponential term m^(4/9).
title: Simplifying rational exponent expressions

description: Sal simplifies v^(-6/5)* ⁵√v as v^(-1).
title: Simplifying rational exponent expressions: mixed exponents and radicals

description: Evaluate numerical exponential expressions and simplify variable exponential expressions by using the properties of exponents.
title: Simplify rational exponent expressions

description: Sal simplifies 3√(500x³) as 30x√(5x).
title: Simplifying radical terms

description: Sal simplifies ∛(125x⁶y³) as 5x²y.
title: Simplifying radical terms: two variables

description: Sal simplifies 5∛(2x²)*3∛(4x⁴) as 30x².
title: Simplifying radical expressions

description: Sal simplifies √(60x²y)/√(48x) as ½√(5xy).
title: Simplifying radical expressions: two variables

description: Sal shows how to evaluate 6^(1/2)*(5th root of 6)^3.
title: Evaluating mixed radical and exponential expressions

description: Sal simplifies ∛(27a²b⁵c³) as 3bc∛(a²b²).
title: Simplifying radical expressions: three variables

description: Evaluate numerical radical expressions and simplify variable radical expressions by using the properties of exponents.
title: Simplify radical expressions

description: Sal shows how to rewrite ∜(5a^4b^12) as an exponential expression and then simplify it.
title: Converting from radical to exponential expression: two variables

description: Sal rewrites (r^(2/3)s^3)^2*√(20r^4s^5), once as an exponential expression and once as a radical expression.
title: Simplifying mixed radical and exponential expressions

description: Sal simplifies hairy expressions with rational exponents. For example, he simplifies (125^-⅛*125^⅝)/(5^½) as 5.
title: Simplifying rational exponent expressions (advanced)

description: Evaluate numerical expressions and simplify variable expressions with mixed exponential and radical terms, by using the properties of exponents.
title: Simplify rational exponent expressions (advanced)

description: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents and radicals using the properties of exponents.
title: Rational exponents and the properties of exponents

description: Learn about expressions with rational exponents like x^(2/3), about radical expressions like √(2t^5), and about the relationship between these two forms of representation. Learn how to evaluate and simplify such expression.
title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals

description: Sal introduces and defines exponential functions using the example y = 3^x and graphing it. He also solves an exponential word problem.
title: Intro to exponential functions

description: Get comfortable with the basic ingredients of exponential functions: the Initial value and the common ratio.
title: Initial value & common ratio of exponential functions

description: Sal writes the exponential function whose initial value is -2 and common ratio is 1/7.
title: Writing exponential functions

description: Construct exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a*r^x given the initial value of the function and the ratio by which it increases for each unit.
title: Write exponential functions

description: Sal constructs a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a*r^x, given a table of values of those functions.
title: Writing exponential functions from tables

description: Sal constructs a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a*r^x, given the graphs of those functions.
title: Writing exponential functions from graphs

description: Construct exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a*r^x, either when given a table with two input-output pairs, or when given the graph of the function.
title: Write exponential functions: tables & graphs

description: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.
title: Introduction to exponential growth and decay

description: Sal shows how to graph the exponential equation y=5^x, including a discussion of the end behavior of the function.
title: The graph of y=5^x

description: Sal graphs the basic exponential functions y=27*(1/3)^x and y=-30*2^x using our interactive widget.
title: Graphing basic exponential functions

description: Graph exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a*r^x while considering the end behavior of the function.
title: Graph basic exponential functions

description: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.
title: End behavior and graphs of basic exponential functions

description: Get comfortable with the basic ingredients of exponential functions: the Initial value and the common ratio.
title: Initial value & common ratio of exponential functions

description: Find features of exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a*r^x given their formula. Features in question are the initial value, the common ratio, and output-values that correspond to various input-values.
title: Interpret basic exponential functions

description: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.
title: Interpreting formulas of basic exponential functions

description: Sal is given a table of values of an exponential function and he analyzes it in order to find the common ratio and the initial value.
title: Analyzing tables of exponential functions

description: Given the graph of an exponential function, Sal finds the formula of the function and a value that is outside the graph.
title: Analyzing graphs of exponential functions

description: Given the graph of an exponential function with a negative initial value, Sal finds the formula of the function and solves an equation.
title: Analyzing graphs of exponential functions: negative initial value

description: Find features of exponential functions of the basic form f(x)=a*r^x, either given a table with input-output pairs, or given their graph. Features in question are the initial value, the common ratio, and output-values that correspond to various input-values.
title: Interpret basic exponential functions: graphs & tables

description: Learn how to analyze the graphs, or tables of values, of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.
title: Interpreting graphs and tables of basic exponential functions

description: Sal solves a word problem where he models the growth of a speeding ticket fine over time as an exponential function, and then interprets this model.
title: Modeling with basic exponential functions word problem

description: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.
title: Constructing basic exponential models

description: Sal solves two word problems: one about a radioactive decay, and the other the exponential growth of a fast-food chain.
title: Exponential growth & decay word problems

description: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.
title: Solving basic exponential models

description: Sal sorts various descriptions of real-world situation according to the type of growth they describe: linear or exponential.
title: Linear vs. exponential growth

description: Given a verbal description of a real-world relationship, determine whether that relationship is linear or exponential.
title: Linear vs. exponential growth

description: Sal discusses two functions that model the shipment rate of cars. One function is quadratic and the other is exponential. Which one will eventually exceed the other?
title: Comparing growth of exponential & quadratic models

description: Practice analyzing the end behavior of two functions that model similar real-world relationship, where one function is exponential and the other is polynomial.
title: Compare growth of exponentials & polynomials

description: Learn how distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.
title: Comparing exponential and polynomial functions

description: Learn how to construct, analyze, graph, and interpret basic exponential functions of the form f(x)=a*r^x.
title: Introduction to exponential functions

description: Learn about terms, coefficients, and exponents. The basic ingredients of polynomial expressions!
title: The parts of polynomial expressions

description: Sal evaluates 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.
title: Evaluating polynomials

description: Sal simplifies 3x²-8x+7+2x³-x²+8x-3 as 2x³+2x²+4.
title: Simplifying polynomials

description: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?
title: Intro to polynomials

description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).
title: Adding polynomials

description: Example: Add (2x²-3) and (7x³-4x+1).
title: Add polynomials

description: Sal simplifies (16x+14) - (3x² + x - 9).
title: Subtracting polynomials

description: Example: Evaluate (4x²-3) - (3x³-3x+2).
title: Subtract polynomials

description: Sal subtracts (-2x²+4x-1) from (6x²+3x-9) and shows that the set of polynomials is closed under addition and subtraction.
title: Polynomial subtraction & set closure

description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).
title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials

description: Example: Subtract -2x²+4x-1 from 6x²+3x-9.
title: Add & subtract polynomials challenge

description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.
title: Adding & subtracting polynomials

description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).
title: Adding polynomials: two variables

description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3xy + 25) - (9y²x + 7xy - 20).
title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables (example 2)

description: Example: Subtract (x²+2xy-y) and (3x+5xy+2y²).
title: Add & subtract polynomials: two variables

description: Sal subtracts -6x⁴-3x²y²+5y⁴ from 2x⁴-8x²y²-y⁴.
title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables

description: Example: Subtract a⁴+4a²b²-2b⁴ from -3a⁴+5a^2b²+2b⁴.
title: Add & subtract polynomials: two variables challenge

description: Sal analyzes a polynomial subtraction process to find the step that has an error.
title: Finding an error in polynomial subtraction

description: Choose which step an error was made in adding or subtracting polynomials.
title: Add & subtract polynomials: find the error

description: If you can't get enough of Sal adding and subtracting polynomials, here's a bunch of many more examples.
title: More examples of adding & subtracting polynomials

description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).
title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables

description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.
title: Multiplying monomials

description: Express the product of two monomial expressions as a single monomial
title: Multiply monomials

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4xy and width 2y as a monomial.
title: Multiplying monomials to find area: two variables

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4y and width 2y as a monomial.
title: Multiplying monomials to find area

description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (3x^a)(bx^4)=-24x^6 true for all x-values.
title: Multiplying monomials challenge

description: More challenging multiplying monomial problems like find the area or find missing values to make an equation true.
title: Multiply monomials challenge

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is 4 and width is x²+3x+2.
title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials: area model

description: Use area to understand how to multiply monomials by polynomials.
title: Multiply monomials by polynomials: area model

description: Sal multiplies -4x² by (3x² + 25x - 7).
title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a monomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply monomials by polynomials

description: Sal finds the values of coefficients c, d, and f that make -2y(y²+cy-3)=dy³+12y²+fy true for all y-values.
title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials challenge

description: Example: Find the values of the variables to make the following equation true -11(y²-cy+2) = dy²+33y-f.
title: Multiply monomials by polynomials challenge

description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!
title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is x+2 and width is x+3.
title: Multiplying binomials: area model

description: Sal expresses (x-4)(x+7) as the standard trinomial x²+3x-28 and discusses how the general product (x+a)(x+b) can be written as x²+(a+b)x+a*b.
title: Multiplying binomials intro

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of two binomials as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply binomials intro

description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.
title: Multiplying binomials

description: Multiply binomials of the form (ax + b).
title: Multiply binomials

description: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).
title: Multiplying binomials

description: Sal introduces difference of squares expressions. For example, (x+3)(x-3) is expanded as x²-9.
title: Special products of the form (x+a)(x-a)

description: Sal introduces perfect square expressions. For example, (x+7)² is expanded as x²+14x+49.
title: Squaring binomials of the form (x+a)²

description: Find perfect squares of the forms (x+a)² and (x-a)², and differences of squares of the form (x+a)(x-a).
title: Special products of binomials

description: Sal expand the difference of squares (2x+8)(2x-8) as 4x²-64.
title: Special products of the form (ax+b)(ax-b)

description: Sal expands the perfect square (7x+10)² as 49x^2+140x+100.
title: Squaring binomials of the form (ax+b)²

description: Sal finds the area of a square with side (6x-5y).
title: Special products of binomials: two variables

description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.
title: More examples of special products

description: Find special products (perfect squares and difference of squares) of "advanced" binomials: binomials with leading coefficients other than 1; binomials with higher degrees; and binomials with two variables.
title: Special products of binomials (advanced)

description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.
title: Special products of binomials

description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a binomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply binomials by polynomials

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is y²-6y and width is 3y²-2y+1.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials: area model

description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (2x+4)(5x-9)=ax²+bx-46 true for all x-values.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials challenge

description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials

description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.
title: Polynomial multiplication word problem

description: Sal writes a binomial to express the difference between the area of a rectangle and the area of a circle.
title: Polynomial word problem: rectangle and circle area

description: Sal writes a polynomial to express the total value of p twenty dollar bills, q ten dollar bills, and r five dollar bills.
title: Polynomial word problem: total value of bills

description: Sal writes a polynomial expression that represents the total area of a window made of wood and glass.
title: Polynomial word problem: area of a window

description: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.
title: Polynomials word problems

description: Learn how to add, subtract, and multiply polynomial expressions. For example, write (2x+3)(x-1) as 2x²+x-3.
title: Introduction to polynomials

description: Sal explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial, and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.
title: Intro to factors & divisibility

description: Practice the relationship between products and their factors (spoiler: a product is divisible by its factors)
title: Factors & divisibility

description: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.
title: Introduction to factorization

description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 24x^5 and determines whether they are correct.
title: Monomial factorization

description: Sal finds the missing factor F in the factorization of -30x^5 as (-10x^3)(F).
title: Monomial factorization (example 2)

description: Sal finds the length of a rectangle whose area is 42xy^3 and whose height is 14xy.
title: Monomial factorization: area model

description: Factor monomials as products of smaller monomials.
title: Factor monomials

description: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).
title: Factoring monomials

description: Sal finds the greatest common factor of 10cd^2 and 25c^3d^2.
title: Greatest common factor of monomials

description: Learn about common monomial factors and how to find the greatest common factor of two monomials. For example, find the greatest common factor of 6x^2y and 9xy^2 (answer: 3xy).
title: Common monomial factors

description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).
title: Factoring with the distributive property

description: Sal factors 8x²y+12xy² as (4xy)(2x+3y) by taking out the greatest common factor.
title: Factoring binomials: common factor

description: Sal factors 4x⁴y-8x³y-2x² as 2x²(2x²y-4xy) by taking the greatest common factor.
title: Factoring polynomials: common factor

description: Sal finds the measures of a rectangle whose area is 12x⁴+6x³+15x² by taking the greatest common factor.
title: Factoring polynomials: common factor area model

description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.
title: Factoring polynomials: common binomial factor

description: Practice finding the greatest common factors of polynomials and factoring them out of the polynomials.
title: Factor polynomials: common factor

description: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).
title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors

description: Sal factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.
title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)

description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-1) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).
title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b) (example 2)

description: Can't get enough of Sal factoring simple quadratics? Here's a handful of examples just for you!
title: More examples of factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)

description: Factor quadratics of the form x²+bx+c.
title: Factor quadratics: leading coefficient = 1

description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x²+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).
title: Factoring quadratics 1

description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.
title: Intro to grouping

description: Sal factors 4y^2+4y-15 as (2y-3)(2y+5) by grouping.
title: Factoring quadratics by grouping

description: Factor quadratics of the form ax²+bx+c.
title: Factor quadratics: leading coefficient ≠ 1

description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).
title: Factoring quadratics 2

description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
title: Factoring quadratics: common factor + grouping
Factoring quadratics: negative common factor + grouping

description: Factor polynomials that can be factored as the product of a monomial and a quadratic expression, then further factor the quadratic expression.
title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods

description: Sal factors x^2+4xy-5y^2 as (x-y)(x+5y).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics

description: Sal rearranges 30x^2+11xy+y^2 as y^2+11xy+30x^2 and then factors it as (y+5x)(y+6x).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: rearranging

description: Sal factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: grouping

description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using quadratic factorization methods.
title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods (advanced)

description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).
title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms

description: Sal factors 45x^2-125 as 5(3x+5)(3x-5).
title: Factoring difference of squares: leading coefficient ≠ 1

description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 16x^2-64 and determines whether they are correct.
title: Factoring difference of squares: analyzing factorization

description: Sal analyzes the factorization of 3y^3-100y as 4y(My+g)(My-g) to find the possible values for the missing coefficient g.
title: Factoring difference of squares: missing values

description: Sal finds the binomial factor shared by m^2-4m-45 and 6m^2-150.
title: Factoring difference of squares: shared factors

description: Factor quadratic expressions of the general difference of squares form: (ax)^2-b^2. The factored expressions have the general form (ax+b)(ax-b).
title: Factor differences of squares

description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x²-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).
title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares

description: Sal factors 25x^2-30x+9 as (5x-3)^2 or as (-5x+3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares

description: Sal shows how we can identify that a trinomial has the "perfect square" form.
title: Identifying perfect square form

description: Sal factors 16x^3+24x^2+9x as (x)(4x+3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares: common factor

description: Sal factors -4t^2-12t-9 as -1(2t+3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares: negative common factor

description: Sal analyzes the factorization of x^2+5x+c as (x+d)^2 to find the values of the missing coefficients c and d.
title: Factoring perfect squares: missing values

description: Sal finds the binomial factor shared by 4x^2+12x+9 and 4x^2-9.
title: Factoring perfect squares: shared factors

description: Factor quadratic expressions into the special products of the general forms (x+a)^2, (x-a)^2, and (x+a)(x-a).
title: Factor special products (basic)

description: Factor quadratic expressions of the general perfect square forms: (ax)^2+2abx+b^2 or (ax)^2-2abx+b^2. The factored expressions have the general forms (ax+b)^2 or (ax-b)^2.
title: Factor perfect squares

description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x²+6x+9 as (x+3)². Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x²+28x+49 as (2x+7)².
title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares

description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares: 4th degree polynomial

description: Sal factors x^2-49y^2 as (x+7y)(x-7y).
title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables

description: Sal factors 49x^2-49y^2 as (7x+7y)(7x-7y) or as 49(x+y)(x-y).
title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables (example 2)

description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using special product factorization methods.
title: Factor special products (advanced)

description: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x⁴-30x²+9 as (5x²-3)².
title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms

description: Learn how to write polynomial expressions as the product of linear factors. For example, write x^2+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).
title: Polynomial factorization

description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots

description: Sal solves the equation (x+3)²-4=0 and finds the x-intercepts of f(x)=(x-2)²-9.
title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots examples

description: Solve quadratic equations of the form (x+a)^2-b=0.

description: Sal analyzes a given solution of a quadratic equation, and finds where and what was the error in that process.

description: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

description: Algebra is the language through which we describe patterns. Think of it as a shorthand, of sorts. As opposed to having to do something over and over again, algebra gives you a simple way to express that repetitive process. It's also seen as a "gatekeeper" subject. Once you achieve an understanding of algebra, the higher-level math subjects become accessible to you. Without it, it's impossible to move forward. It's used by people with lots of different jobs, like carpentry, engineering, and fashion design. In these tutorials, we'll cover a lot of ground. Some of the topics include linear equations, linear inequalities, linear functions, systems of equations, factoring expressions, quadratic expressions, exponents, functions, and ratios.
title: Algebra I

We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade.  But that was only dealing with positive coordinate.  Now, however, we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well!

Let's now extend our understanding of area to triangles and more interesting quadrilaterals!

description: Practice interesting area and circumference problems.

description:
You already know about area and perimeter of lots of shapes. Now we'll round out those concepts by applying them to circles. Mathematicians call the distance around a circle its circumference and the space inside a circle its area.
 
In this tutorial, we'll learn that there's another type of pi in the math world, and it's even more awesome than apple pie. We'll use pi to find the circumference and area of any circle in the world, no matter how big or how small!

Common Core Standards: 7.G.B.4
title: Area and circumference of circles

description: Now that you understand lines, you can put lines together to create drawings. A scale drawing depicts an actual object that has been reduced (or enlarged) by a certain amount. The "scale" shows the relationship between those two sizes. After this set of tutorials, you can draw your bedroom "to scale" and practice rearranging your furniture!

description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

description:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.B.6
title: Pythagorean theorem proofs

description: The Pythagorean theorem describes a special relationship between the sides of a right triangle. Even the ancients knew of this relationship. In this topic, we’ll figure out how to use the Pythagorean theorem and prove why it works.

description: We don't normally delve too far into history when talking about math, but sometimes it's important to have perspective about how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

description:
Roughly 2400 years ago, Euclid of Alexandria wrote Elements which served as the world's geometry textbook until recently.  Studied by Abraham Lincoln in order to sharpen his mind and truly appreciate mathematical deduction, it is still the basis of what we consider a first year course in geometry.

This tutorial gives a bit of this background and then lays the conceptual foundation of points, lines, circles and planes that we will use as we journey through the world of Euclid.

description:
Welcome.  I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Angle.  Nice to meet you.  So nice to meet you.  

This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

description:
The triangle inequality theorem is, on some level, kind of simple.  But, as you'll see as you go into high level mathematics, it is often used in fancy proofs.

This tutorial introduces you to what it is and gives you some practice understanding the constraints on the dimensions of a triangle.
title: Triangle inequality theorem

description: Multiple proofs showing that a point is on a perpendicular bisector of a segment if and only if it is equidistant from the endpoints. Using this to establish the circumcenter, circumradius, and circumcircle for a triangle
