description:
In this tutorial, we study lines that are perpendicular to the sides of a triangle and divide them in two (perpendicular bisectors).  As we'll prove, they intersect at a unique point called the cicumcenter (which, quite amazingly, is equidistant to the vertices).  We can then create a circle (circumcircle) centered at this point that goes through all the vertices. 

This tutorial is the extension of the core narrative of the Geometry "course".  After this, you might want to look at the tutorial on angle bisectors.
title: Perpendicular bisectors

description: Thinking about the distance between a point and a line. Proof that a point on an angle bisector is equidistant to the sides of the angle and a point equidistant to the sides is on an angle bisector
title: Distance between a point & line

description: Using angle bisectors to find the incenter and incircle of a triangle
title: Incenter and incircles of a triangle

description: Showing that area is equal to inradius times semiperimeter
title: Inradius, perimeter, & area

description: This tutorial experiments with lines that divide the angles of a triangle in two (angle bisectors).  As we'll prove, all three angle bisectors actually intersect at one point called the incenter (amazing!).  We'll also prove that this incenter is equidistant from the sides of the triangle (even more amazing!).  This allows us to create a circle centered at the incenter that is tangent to the sides of the triangle (not surprisingly called the "incircle").
title: Angle bisectors

description: Seeing that the centroid is 2/3 of the way along every median
title: Triangle medians & centroids

description: Showing that the centroid is 2/3 of the way along a median
title: Triangle medians and centroids (2D proof)

description: Showing that the three medians of a triangle divide it into six smaller triangles of equal area. Brief discussion of the centroid as well
title: Dividing triangles with medians

description: What a medial triangle is and its properties
title: Exploring medial triangles

description: Showing that the centroid divides each median into segments with a 2:1 ratio (or that the centroid is 2/3 along the median)
title: Centroid & median proof

description: Example involving properties of medians
title: Median, centroid example

description: You've explored perpendicular bisectors and angle bisectors, but you're craving to study lines that intersect the vertices of a a triangle AND bisect the opposite sides.  Well, you're in luck because that (medians) is what we are going to study in this tutorial.  We'll prove here that the medians intersect at a unique point (amazing!) called the centroid and divide the triangle into six mini triangles of equal area (even more amazing!).  The centroid also always happens to divide all the medians in segments with lengths at a 1:2 ration (stupendous!).
title: Medians & centroids

description: Showing that any triangle can be the medial triangle for some larger triangle. Using this to show that the altitudes of a triangle are concurrent (at the orthocenter).
title: Proof: Triangle altitudes are concurrent (orthocenter)

description: Showing that a triangle with the same point as the orthocenter and centroid is equilateral
title: Common orthocenter and centroid

description: Ok.  You knew triangles where cool, but you never imagined they were this cool!  Well, this tutorial will take things even further.  After perpendicular bisectors, angle bisector and medians, the only other thing (that I can think of) is a line that intersects a vertex and the opposite side (called an altitude).  As we'll see, these are just as cool as the rest and, as you may have guessed, intersect at a unique point called the orthocenter (unbelievable!).
title: Altitudes

description: Comparing perpendicular bisectors to angle bisectors to medians to altitudes
title: Review of triangle properties

description: The magic and mystery of the Euler Line
title: Euler line

description: Proving the somewhat mystical result that the circumcenter, centroid and orthocenter
title: Euler's line proof

description: This tutorial brings together all of the major ideas in this topic.  First, it starts off with a light-weight review of the various ideas in the topic.  It then goes into a heavy-weight proof of a truly, truly, truly amazing idea.  It was amazing enough that orthocenters, circumcenters, and centroids exist , but we'll see in the videos on Euler lines that they sit on the same line themselves (incenters must be feeling lonely)!!!!!!!
title: Bringing it all together

description: You probably like triangles.  You think they are useful.  They show up a lot.  What you'll see in this topic is that they are far more magical and mystical than you ever imagined!

description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.
title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram

description: Find missing angle measures in quadrilaterals.
title: Quadrilateral angles

description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.
title: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors

description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.
title: Proof: Rhombus area

description: Guess what's interesting about the opposite sides of a parallelogram? That's right....they are parallel! Let's find the area--base times height
title: Area of parallelogram proof

description: Proving whether a special quadrilateral can exist or not.
title: Whether a special quadrilateral can exist

description: Proof that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular bisectors of each other
title: Rhombus diagonals

description: Not all things with four sides have to be squares or rectangles!  We will now broaden our understanding of quadrilaterals.
title: Quadrilateral proofs & angles

description: Sal introduces geometric transformations! Specifically, he explains what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the "rigid" transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.
title: Intro to geometric transformations

description: Sal shows how to perform a translation on a triangle using our interactive widget!
title: Performing translations

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform translations.
title: Perform translations

description: Sal shows how to perform a rotation on a pentagon using our interactive widget!
title: Performing rotations

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform rotations.
title: Perform rotations

description: Sal shows how to perform a reflection on a quadrilateral using our interactive widget!
title: Performing reflections

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform reflections.
title: Perform reflections

description: The three rigid transformations are translations, rotations, and reflections. Get to know them and gain some experience in performing them on different figures.
title: Introduction to rigid transformations

description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.
title: Translating shapes

description: Given a figure and a definition of a translation, manually draw the image.
title: Translate shapes

description: Sal is given two triangles on the coordinate plane, and determines the translation that maps one of them into the other.
title: Determining translations

description: Given two figures on the coordinate plane, find the formal definition of the translation that takes one figure to another.
title: Determine translations

description: A translation acting on the coordinate plane takes the point (-169,434) to point (-203, -68). What are the coordinates of the image of point (31, -529) under this translation?
title: Translation challenge problem

description: Learn how to find the translation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a translation.
title: Translations

description: Sal is given two pairs of line segments and a center of a dilation. He finds the angle for the rotation that maps one pair of segments to another.
title: Determining rotations

description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.
title: Determine rotations

description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.
title: Rotating shapes

description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, manually draw the image of that rotation.
title: Rotate shapes

description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about an arbitrary point, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.
title: Rotating shapes: center ≠ (0,0)

description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about an arbitrary point, manually draw the image of that rotation.
title: Rotate shapes: center ≠ (0,0)

description: Learn how to find the rotation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a rotation.
title: Rotations

description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.
title: Reflecting shapes

description: Given a figure and a definition of a reflection, manually draw the image.
title: Reflect shapes

description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane, and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.
title: Determining reflections

description: Given two figures on the coordinate plane, find the formal definition of the reflection that takes one figure to another.
title: Determine reflections

description: Find the reflection that maps a given figure to another and draw the image of a reflection. The lines of reflection in this exercise have a wide range of slopes.
title: Advanced reflections

description: Learn how to find the reflection that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a reflection.
title: Reflections

description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!
title: Performing dilations

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform dilations.
title: Perform dilations

description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the triangle under a dilation with scale factor 1/2 about the origin.
title: Dilating shapes: shrinking

description: Sal is given a rectangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the rectangle under a dilation with scale factor 1 2/3 about an arbitrary point.
title: Dilating shapes: expanding

description: Given a figure and a definition of a dilation, manually draw the image.
title: Dilate shapes

description: Sal shows how we can use dilations to map a line into another, parallel, line.
title: Determining dilations

description: Find both the center and the scale factor of a dilation that maps a given figure to another one.
title: Determine dilations

description:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.
title: Dilations or scaling around a point

description: Given a description of a sequence of transformations, determine whether it preserves segment length or angle measure.
title: Sequences of transformations

description: Learn how to analyze a sequence of different transformations performed in order.
title: Sequences of transformations

description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.
title: Identifying type of transformation

description: Given a description of the effect of a transformation, determine which rigid transformation it is.
title: Identify transformations

description: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.
title: Properties and definitions of transformations

description: Sal introduces the concept of an "axis of symmetry."
title: Intro to reflective symmetry

description: Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.
title: Intro to rotational symmetry

description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0,9) and (3,4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.
title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries

description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4,-2) and (0,5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.
title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries (example 2)

description: Analyze various shapes according to their reflective and rotational symmetries.
title: Symmetry of 2D shapes

description: Learn about different kinds of symmetries of two-dimensional shapes, and analyze various shapes according to their symmetries.
title: Symmetry

description:
In this topic you will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations, specifically translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

You will learn how to perform the transformations, and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.
title: Transformations

description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.
title: Congruent shapes & transformations

description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are not congruent by showing it's not possible to map one onto the other using rigid transformations.
title: Non-congruent shapes & transformations

description: Given a pair of figures in the coordinate plane, try to map one onto the other and determine whether they are congruent.
title: Congruence & transformations

description: Sal reflects and then translates a given pentagon, and determines whether the resulting figure is congruent to the source figure.
title: Performing sequences of transformations

description: Sal maps a given quadrilateral onto another using a translation, a dilation, and a reflection. The quadrilaterals are not congruent because a dilation was used.
title: Determining mappings (incl. dilations)

description: Map a given shape to another one using rigid transformations and dilations. Determine whether the shapes are congruent.
title: Determine mappings

description: Two figures are congruent if you can go from one to another through some combination of translations, reflections and rotations.  In this tutorial, we'll really internalize this by working through the actual transformations.
title: Transformations and congruence

description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.
title: Congruent triangles & the SSS postulate/criterion

description: Sal introduces and justifies the SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA, better to watch next video.
title: Triangle congruence postulates/criteria

description: There are some cases when SSA can imply triangle congruence, but not always. This is why it's not like the other triangle congruence postulates/criteria.
title: Why SSA isn't a congruence postulate/criterion

description: Sal uses the SSS, ASA, SAS, and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.
title: Determining congruent triangles

description: Use the triangle congruence criteria SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS to determine that two triangles are congruent.
title: Determine congruent triangles

description: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.
title: Triangle congruence

description: Sal gives a formal proof that the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.
title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof

description: Sal proves that the base angles in isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely, that triangles with congruent base angles are isosceles. He also proves that the perpendicular to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects it.
title: Proofs concerning isosceles triangles

description: Sal proves that the angles of an equilateral triangle are all congruent (and therefore they all measure 60°), and conversely, that triangles with all congruent angles are equilateral.
title: Proofs concerning equilateral triangles

description: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.
title: Theorems concerning triangle properties

description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts of corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.
title: Corresponding angles in congruent triangles

description: Given two triangles, determine whether they are congruent and use that to find missing angle measures.
title: Find angles in congruent triangles

description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving, by Richard Rusczyk).
title: Isosceles & equilateral triangles problems

description: The measures of two angles of an isosceles triangle are 3x+5 and x+16. Find all possible values of x.
title: Finding angles in isosceles triangles

description: Sal combines what we know about isosceles triangles and parallel lines with the power of algebra to solve the angles of an isosceles triangle.
title: Finding angles in isosceles triangles (example 2)

description: Find missing angle measures in triangles using the properties of general triangles, isosceles triangles, and equilateral triangles.
title: Find angles in triangles

description: Learn how to solve different geometric problems using triangle congruence.
title: Working with triangles

description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.
title: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram

description: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.
title: Proof: Diagonals of a parallelogram

description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.
title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram

description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a kite are perpendicular, by using the SSS and SAS triangle congruence criteria.
title: Proof: The diagonals of a kite are perpendicular

description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.
title: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors

description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.
title: Proof: Rhombus area

description: Triangle congruence is not only useful when working with triangles, it's also useful with any other kind of polygon! Prove a few theorems about the properties of parallelograms using triangle congruence.
title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties

description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.
title: Geometry proof problem: midpoint

description: Sal proves that two pairs of segments are congruent using the ASA and AAS congruence criteria.
title: Geometry proof problem: congruent segments

description: Sal finds a missing angle using triangle congruence in a diagram that contains sector of a circle inscribed within a square.
title: Geometry proof problem: squared circle

description: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.
title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence

description: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent, and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.
title: Congruence

description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.
title: Similar shapes & transformations

description: Given two polygons, try to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations, and determine whether they are similar. Transformations are done in "intuitive mode."
title: Similarity & transformations

description: Given two polygons, try to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations, and determine whether they are similar. Transformations are done in "formal mode."
title: Similarity & transformations (advanced)

description: Sal solves a problem about the conditions for two quadrilaterals to be similar, based on the definition that two polygons are similar if all their angles are congruent.
title: Angles of similar quadrilaterals

description: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.
title: Definitions of similarity

description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.
title: Intro to triangle similarity

description: Sal reviews all the different ways we can determine that two triangles are similar. This is similar to the congruence criteria, only for similarity!
title: Triangle similarity postulates/criteria

description: Given two triangles with some of their angle measures, determine whether the triangles are similar or not.
title: Determine similar triangles: AA

description: Multiple examples where Sal analyzes the similarity of triangles.
title: Determining similar triangles

description: Given two triangles with some of their side measures, determine whether the triangles are similar or not.
title: Determine similar triangles: SSS

description: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.
title: Introduction to triangle similarity

description: Given two similar triangles and some of their side lengths, find a missing side length.
title: Solve similar triangles (basic)

description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.
title: Solving similar triangles

description: Given two similar triangles and some of their side lengths, find a missing side length.
title: Solve similar triangles (advanced)

description: Sal finds a missing side length ni a problem where the same side plays different roles in two similar triangles.
title: Solving similar triangles: same side plays different roles

description: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.
title: Solving similar triangles

description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.
title: Intro to angle bisector theorem

description: Sal uses the angle bisector theorem to solve for sides of a triangle.
title: Using the angle bisector theorem

description: Use the angle bisector theorem to find missing side lengths in triangles.
title: Solve triangles: angle bisector theorem

description: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.
title: Angle bisector theorem

description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.
title: Using similar & congruent triangles

description: Solve geometry problems with various polygons by using all you know about similarity and congruence.
title: Use similar & congruent triangles

description: Interesting similarity problem where we don't have a lot of information to work with
title: Challenging similarity problem

description: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!
title: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles

description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!
title: Geometry word problem: the golden ratio

description: Similarity and the Golden ratio join forces again, this time to save the Earth! (Or maybe just finding its radius)
title: Geometry word problem: Earth & Moon radii

description: Sal uses triangle similarity to plan the perfect shot in a pool game.
title: Geometry word problem: a perfect pool shot

description: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!
title: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles

description: Learn what it means for two figures to be similar, and how to determine whether two figures are similar or not. Use this concept to prove geometric theorems and solve some problems with polygons.
title: Similarity

description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!
title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 1

description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!
title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.
title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: fishing boat

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.
title: Pythagorean theorem example

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.
title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet

description: Find the leg or hypotenuse of a right triangle using the Pythagorean theorem.
title: Pythagorean theorem

description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using the Pythagorean Theorem!
title: Pythagorean theorem word problems

description: Right triangles and the Pythagorean Theorem
title: Introduction to the Pythagorean theorem

description: More Pythagorean Theorem examples. Introduction to 45-45-90 triangles.
title: Pythagorean theorem II

description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.
title: Pythagorean theorem

description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.
title: Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean theorem

description: An elegant visual proof of the Pythagorean Theorem developed by the 12th century Indian mathematician Bhaskara.
title: Bhaskara's proof of the Pythagorean theorem

description: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity
title: Pythagorean theorem proof using similarity

description: Visually proving the Pythagorean Theorem
title: Another Pythagorean theorem proof

description: The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.
title: Pythagorean theorem proofs

description: A few more 45-45-90 examples and an introduction to 30-60-90 triangles.
title: Intro to 30-60-90 triangles

description: Proving the ratios between the sides of a 30-60-90 triangle
title: 30-60-90 triangle side ratios proof

description: Using what we know about 30-60-90 triangles to solve what at first seems to be a challenging problem
title: 30-60-90 triangle example problem

description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles
title: 45-45-90 triangles

description: Showing the ratios of the sides of a 45-45-90 triangle are 1:1:sqrt(2)
title: 45-45-90 triangle side ratios

description: Use your knowledge of 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles to solve some problems.
title: Special right triangles

description: Using what we know about triangles to find the area of a regular hexagon
title: Area of a regular hexagon

description: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).
title: Special right triangles

description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.
title: Intro to the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.
title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles

description: Given the side lengths of a right triangle, find the sine, cosine, or tangent of one of the acute angles.
title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles

description: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.
title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
title: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry

description: Given one side length and an acute angle in a right triangle, find another side using trigonometry.
title: Solve for a side in right triangles

description: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.
title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

description: Given two sides in a right triangle, find one of the acute angles using trigonometry.
title: Solve for an angle in right triangles

description: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.
title: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.
title: Right triangle word problem

description: Solve word problems by modeling real-world (and not-so-real) situations as right triangles and using trigonometry.
title: Right triangle word problems

description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.
title: Modeling with right triangles

description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.
title: Triangle similarity & the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to verify identities relating to trig ratios in those triangles.
title: Trig challenge problem: verify identities

description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.
title: Trig challenge problem: trig values & side ratios

description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.
title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity

description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles

description: Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53, find sin(32°).
title: Using complementary angles

description: Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
title: Trig word problem: complementary angles

description: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.
title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles

description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solving for a side with the law of sines

description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure, and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solving for an angle with the law of sines

description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solve triangles using the law of sines

description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.
title: Proof of the law of sines

description: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.
title: The law of sines

description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and the contained angle measure, and he finds the missing side length using the law of cosines.
title: Solving for a side with the law of cosines

description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure, and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.
title: Solving for an angle with the law of cosines

description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of cosines.
title: Solve triangles using the law of cosines

description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.
title: Proof of the law of cosines

description: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.
title: The law of cosines

description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.
title: Trig word problem: stars

description: Solve word problems that involve general triangles using trigonometry.
title: General triangle word problems

description: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.
title: Solving general triangles

description: Triangles are not always right (although they are never wrong), but when they are it opens up an exciting world of possibilities.  Not only are right triangles cool in their own right (pun intended), they are the basis of very important ideas in analytic geometry (the distance between two points in space) and trigonometry.
title: Right triangles and trigonometry

description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs
title: Circles glossary

description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.
title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π

description: Watch Sal informally prove that all circles are similar by showing how we can translate then dilate any circle onto another.
title: Proof: all circles are similar

description: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.
title: Circle basics

description: Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.
title: Intro to arc measure

description: Watch Sal solve a few problems where he finds a missing arc measure.
title: Finding arc measures

description: Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees to find missing arc measures.
title: Arc measure

description: Sal solves a few items where arc measures are given in equations, we have to find a variable, then use it to find an arc measure.
title: Finding arc measures with equations

description: Use the fact that the arc measures of a circle must sum to 360 degrees to find missing arc measures by setting up equations.
title: Arc measure with equations

description: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.
title: Arc measure

description: Sal finds the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.
title: Arc length from subtended angle

description: Watch Sal solve an example where he finds the central angle given arc length.
title: Subtended angle from arc length

description: Relate the length of an arc to the circumference of a whole circle and the central angle subtended by the arc.
title: Arc length

description: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.
title: Arc length (degrees)

description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.
title: Intro to radians

description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.
title: Degrees to radians

description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.
title: Radians to degrees

description: Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.
title: Introduction to radians

description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.
title: Arc length as fraction of circumference

description: Sal finds the length of an arc using the radius and the radian measure of the angle subtended by the arc.
title: Arc length from subtended angle: radians

description: Solve problems related to radians and arc length like finding an arc length given the central angle and radius.
title: Radians & arc length

description: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.
title: Arc length (radians)

description: Sal finds the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.
title: Area of a sector

description: Relate the area of a sector to the area of a whole circle.
title: Area of a sector

description: Learn how to find the area of a sector.
title: Sectors

description: Sal finds a missing inscribed angle using the inscribed angle theorem.
title: Inscribed angles

description: Practice the relationship between inscribed & central angles that are subtended by the same arc length.
title: Inscribed angles

description: Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.
title: Inscribed angle theorem proof

description: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.
title: Inscribed angles

description: Proof showing that a triangle inscribed in a circle having a diameter as one side is a right triangle
title: Proof: Right triangles inscribed in circles

description: Find the diameter of a circle using an inscribed right triangle.
title: Inscribed shapes: find diameter

description: One method using an inscribed angle intercepting a diameter of a circle.
title: Inscribed shapes: angle subtended by diameter

description: Using either the inscribed angle theorem or the fact that two inscribed angles that intercept the same arc must be congruent.
title: Inscribed shapes: find inscribed angle

description: Find missing angles and lengths in inscribed shapes.
title: Inscribed shapes

description: Sal uses the inscribed angle theorem and some algebra to prove that opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.
title: Inscribed quadrilaterals proof

description: Example showing supplementary oppositie angles in inscribed quadrilateral.
title: Solving inscribed quadrilaterals

description: Use the fact that opposite angles in an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary to solve a few problems.
title: Quiz: Inscribed quadrilaterals

description: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties some fun problem solving!
title: Inscribed shapes problem solving

description: Sal proves that the radius that connects the intersection point of a tangent line with the circle is perpendicular to the tangent line.
title: Proof: Radius is perpendicular to tangent line

description: Sal proves that two tangent segments to a circle that are drawn from the same outside point are congruent.
title: Proof: Segments tangent to circle from outside point are congruent

description: Sal finds missing angles using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
title: Tangents of circles problem (example 1)

description: Sal finds a missing angle using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
title: Tangents of circles problem (example 2)

description: Sal finds a missing length using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.
title: Tangents of circles problem (example 3)

description: Solve problems related to tangents of circles.
title: Tangents of circles problems

description: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.
title: Properties of tangents

description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.
title: Proof: radius is perpendicular to a chord it bisects

description: Simple proof using RSH postulate to show that a radius perpendicular to a chord bisects it
title: Proof: perpendicular radius bisects chord

description: Problem that requires us to figure out the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed in a circle (A little trigonometry used)
title: Area of inscribed equilateral triangle

description: This more advanced (and very optional) tutorial is fun to look at for enrichment.  It builds to figuring out the formula for the area of a triangle inscribed in a circle!
title: Area of inscribed triangle

description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.
title: Features of a circle from its standard equation

description: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in standard form.
title: Features of a circle from its standard equation

description: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.
title: Graphing a circle from its standard equation

description: Given the standard form equation of a circle, graph the circle.
title: Graph a circle from its standard equation

description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².
title: Writing standard equation of a circle

description: Given the graph of a circle or its features, find its standard equation.
title: Write standard equation of a circle

description: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.
title: Standard equation of a circle

description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.
title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

description: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in expanded form.
title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

description: Given an expanded equation of a circle, graph it.
title: Graph a circle from its expanded equation

description: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.
title: Expanded equation of a circle

description: Explore, prove, and apply important properties of circles that have to do with things like arc length, radians, inscribed angles, and tangents.
title: Circles

description: Great geometry primer on perimeter and area. Listen carefully. Sal explains the concepts so you'll understand them.
title: Intro to perimeter & area

description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.
title: Area of triangles intuition

description: Practice finding the area of right, acute, and obtuse triangles from a diagram.
title: Area of triangles

description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.
title: Area of parallelograms intuition

description: Practice finding the area of parallelograms given base and height.
title: Area of parallelograms

description: A trapezoid is a cousin of the parallelogram. However, in trapezoid only two of the opposing sides are parallel to each other. Here's we explain how to find its area.
title: Area of trapezoids

description: Practice finding the areas of trapezoids.
title: Area of trapezoids

description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.
title: Area of kites

description: You first learned about perimeter and area when you were in grade school.  In this tutorial, we will revisit those ideas with a more mathy lens.  We will use our prior knowledge of congruence to really start to prove some neat (and useful) results (including some that will be useful in our study of similarity).
title: Basic area

description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.
title: Area of a triangle on a grid

description: Again, some quadrilaterals can be oddly shaped so break it up into shapes where finding the area is more easily determined.
title: Area of a quadrilateral on a grid

description: Practice finding the areas of triangles and quadrilaterals on grids.
title: Areas of shapes on grids

description: Don't be intimidated by odd looking geometric figures and being asked to find its area. In this example you'll understand that breaking up the figure into smaller geometric shapes that are regular make the task a lot easier.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: Perimeter and Area of a Non-Standard Polygon
title: Perimeter & area of composite shapes

description: Practice finding the areas of complex shapes that are composed of smaller shapes.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: Three example problems involving perimeter and area
title: Challenge problems: perimeter & area

description: Not everything in the world is a rectangle, circle or triangle.  In this tutorial, we give you practice at finding the perimeters and areas of these less-than-standard shapes!
title: Advanced perimeter and area

description: Proving that the area of any triangle is 1/2 b x h
title: Area of triangle proof

description: Guess what's interesting about the opposite sides of a parallelogram? That's right....they are parallel! Let's find the area--base times height
title: Area of parallelogram proof

description: See how to prove some of the basic area formulas you've been working with like the area of a triangle.
title: Area formula proofs

description: Finding the formula for the area of an equilateral triangle with side s
title: Area of equilateral triangle

description: Sal finds a shaded area defined by two equilateral triangles whose side lengths are given.
title: Area of equilateral triangle (advanced)

description: Watch Sal prove that the areas of the pairs of triangles generated by the diagonals of a rectangle are equal.
title: Area of diagonal-generated triangles

description: Learn about, prove, and apply area properties of specific types of triangles.
title: Advanced area with triangles

description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.
title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π

description: Practice finding the radius, diameter, or circumference of a circle. For example, if the diameter of a circle is 16, what is its circumference?
title: Radius, diameter, & circumference

description: In this example, we solve for the area of a circle when given the diameter. If you recall, the diameter is the length of a line that runs across the circle and through the center.
title: Area of a circle

description: Find the area of a circle given its radius, diameter, or circumference.
title: Area of a circle

description: Find the areas of shaded regions which are combinations of squares, triangles, and circles.
title: Shaded areas

description: Sal finds the radius and diameter of a circle given the circumference.
title: Radius & diameter from circumference

description: You'll be given the circumference or the area of a circle, and it will be up to you to figure out the radius or the diameter.

description: Using triangles to create an informal argument for the area of a circle formula.
title: Area of a circle intuition

description: Circles are everywhere.  How can we measure how big they are?  Well, we could think about the distance around the circle (circumference).  Another option would be to think about how much space it takes up on our paper (area).  Have fun!

description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, muti-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

description: Sal solves a problem about whether or not a certain net could be folded up into a certain rectangular prism.

description: Practice matching 2D nets to the 3D shapes the fold up into.

description: Practice using the net of a 3D figure to find surface area.

description: Practice finding the surface area of 3D objects.
title: Surface area

description: Learn all about the surface area of 3D objects.
title: Surface area

description: In this tutorial we'll practice finding solid geometry volume. Keep paper and pencil nearby in case you want to remember the formulas.

description: Sal introduces and explains the formula for the volume of a cone, V=1/3hπr².

description: Finding the volume and surface area of a cylinder

description: Sal introduces and uses the formula for the volume of a sphere, V=4/3πr³.

description: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

description: Named after Helge von Koch, the Koch snowflake is one of the first fractals to be discovered. It is created by adding smaller and smaller equilateral bumps to an existing equilateral triangle.  Quite amazingly, it produces a figure of infinite perimeter and finite area!

description: Sal proves Heron's Formula for finding the area of a triangle solely from its side lengths.

description: Named after Heron of Alexandria, Heron's formula is a power (but often overlooked) method for finding the area of ANY triangle.  In this tutorial we will explain how to use it and then prove it!

description: With just a compass and a straightedge  (or virtual versions of them), you'll be amazed by how many geometric shapes you can construct perfectly.  This tutorial gets you started with the building block of how to bisect angle and lines (and how to construct perpendicular bisectors of lines).

description: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

description: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

description: We now have fancy computers to help us perfectly draw things, but have you ever wondered how people drew perfect circles or angle bisectors or perpendicular bisectors back in the day.  Well this tutorial will have you doing just as your grandparents did (actually, a little different since you'll still be using a computer to draw circles and lines with a virtual compass and straightedge).

description: Sal does the 80 problems from the released questions from the California Standards Test for Geometry.  Basic understanding of Algebra I necessary.
title: Worked examples

description: We are surrounded by space. And that space contains lots of things. And these things have shapes. In geometry we are concerned with the nature of these shapes, how we define them, and what they teach us about the world at large--from math to architecture to biology to astronomy (and everything in between). Learning geometry is about more than just taking your medicine ("It's good for you!"), it's at the core of everything that exists--including you. Having said all that, some of the specific topics we'll cover include angles, intersecting lines, right triangles, perimeter, area, volume, circles, triangles, quadrilaterals, analytic geometry, and geometric constructions. Wow. That's a lot. To summarize: it's difficult to imagine any area of math that is more widely used than geometry.
title: Geometry

description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).
title: Adding functions

description: Given that f(x)=2x√5-4 and g(x)=x^2+2x√5-1, Sal finds (g-f)(x).
title: Subtracting functions

description: Sal solves the following problem: given that f(x)=7x-5 and g(x)=x^3+4x, find (f*g)(x). He explains that generally, (f*g)(x)=f(x)*g(x).
title: Multiplying functions

description: Sal solves the following problem: given that f(x)=2x^2+15x-8 and g(x)=x^2+10x+16, find (f/g)(x). He explains that generally, (f/g)(x)=f(x)/g(x).

description: Learn how to take two basic functions and combine them into a new function which is their sum, difference, product, or quotient.

description: Sal explains what it means to compose two functions. He gives examples for finding the values of composite functions given the equations, the graphs, or tables of values of the two composed functions.

title: Verify inverse functions

description: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.
title: Verifying that functions are inverses

description: Sal analyzes the mapping diagram of a function to see if the function is invertible.
title: Determining if a function is invertible

description: Given the table of values of a function, determine whether it is invertible or not.
title: Determine if a function is invertible

description: Sal is given the graph of a trigonometric function, and he discusses ways in which he can change the function to make it invertible.
title: Restricting domains of functions to make them invertible

description: Given the graph of a function, find ways to restrict its domain in order to make it invertible.
title: Restrict domains of functions to make them invertible

description: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.
title: Determining whether a function is invertible

description: A great cook knows how to take basic ingredients and prepare a delicious meal. In this topic, you will become function-chefs! You will learn how to combine functions with arithmetic operations and how to compose functions. You will also learn how to transform functions in ways that shift, reflect, or stretch their graphs. Finally, you will learn about inverse functions and how to find them!
title: Manipulating functions

description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.
title: Intro to the imaginary numbers

description: Sal simplifies √(-52) as 2i√(52).
title: Simplifying roots of negative numbers

description: Rewrite square roots of negative numbers as imaginary numbers.
title: Simplify roots of negative numbers

description: Sal gives several examples of how we simplify high powers of i. For instance, i^100=1.
title: Powers of the imaginary unit

description: Simplify expressions with base i (the imaginary unit) raised to a positive exponent.
title: Powers of the imaginary unit

description: The formal definition of i is i^2=-1 and not √-1=i, and there's a good reason for this (although it's a bit technical). See Sal explain why.
title: i as the principal root of -1

description: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).
title: What are the imaginary numbers?

description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.
title: Intro to complex numbers

description: Determine the real and the imaginary parts of complex numbers
title: Parts of complex numbers

description: Classify numbers as real, pure imaginary, or complex.
title: Classify complex numbers

description: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).
title: What are the complex numbers?

description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.
title: Plotting numbers on the complex plane

description: Given a complex number, plot its corresponding point on the complex plane.
title: Plot numbers on the complex plane

description: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!
title: The complex plane

description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
title: Adding complex numbers

description: Sal subtracts (6-18i) from (2-3i).
title: Subtracting complex numbers

description: Practice addition and subtraction with complex numbers.
title: Add & subtract complex numbers

description: Add or subtract complex numbers, and plot the result in the complex plane.
title: Graphically add & subtract complex numbers

description: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).
title: Adding and subtracting complex numbers

description: Multiply complex numbers by single terms that are either real or pure imaginary.
title: Multiply complex numbers (basic)

description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
title: Multiplying complex numbers

description: Given two complex numbers, find their product.
title: Multiply complex numbers

description: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).
title: Multiplying complex numbers

description: Learn about complex numbers and how to add, subtract, and multiply them. This will come in useful when working with polynomials.
title: Introduction to complex numbers

description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).
title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials

description: Example: Add (2x²-3) and (7x³-4x+1).
title: Add polynomials

description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3xy + 25) - (9y²x + 7xy - 20).
title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables (example 2)

description: Example: Subtract (x²+2xy-y) and (3x+5xy+2y²).
title: Add & subtract polynomials: two variables

description: Learn how to add and subtract two polynomials to obtain another polynomial. For instance, express (3x^3+2x-1)+(2x^4-x^3+7x) as a polynomial in standard form.
title: Adding and subtracting polynomials

description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a binomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply binomials by polynomials

description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.
title: More examples of special products

description: Find special products (perfect squares and difference of squares) of "advanced" binomials: binomials with leading coefficients other than 1; binomials with higher degrees; and binomials with two variables.
title: Special products of binomials (advanced)

description: Learn how to multiply two polynomials to obtain another polynomial. For instance, express (2x^2+5)*(x^3-2x+6) as a polynomial in standard form.
title: Multiplying polynomials

description: Sal explains what polynomial long division is, and gives various examples of polynomial long divisions.
title: Intro to long division of polynomials

description: Sal divides (x^2-3x+2) by (x-2) and then checks the solution.
title: Dividing polynomials: long division

description: Learn how to divide two polynomials using long division.
title: Long division of polynomials

description: Sal shows how synthetic division of polynomials works.
title: Intro to polynomial synthetic division

description: Sal divides (2x^5-x^3+3x^2-2x+7) by (x-3) using synthetic division.
title: Dividing polynomials: synthetic division

description: Sal explains why synthetic division gives you the same result as traditional algebraic long division.
title: Why synthetic division works

description: Learn how to divide polynomials using long division.
title: Synthetic division of polynomials

description: Sal divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.
title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors

description: Sal divides (7x^6+x^3+2x+1) by X^2, and writes the solution as q(x)+r(x)/x^2, where the degree of the remainder, r(x), is less than the degree of x^2.
title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors (example 2)

description: Rewrite expressions of the form a(x)/b(x), where a is a polynomial b is a monomial, in the form q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where q and r are polynomials and the degree of r is less than the degree of b.
title: Divide polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors

description: Sal divides (x^3+5x-4) by (x^2-x+1) using long division.
title: Dividing polynomials with remainders

description: Rewrite expressions of the form a(x)/b(x), where a is a polynomial b is a linear binomial, in the form q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where q and r are polynomials and the degree of r is less than the degree of b.
title: Divide polynomials with remainders: binomial divisors

description: Rewrite expressions of the form a(x)/b(x), where a and b are polynomials, in the form q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where q and r are polynomials and the degree of r is less than the degree of b.
title: Divide polynomials with remainders

description: After learning about the different methods in which we can find the quotient and the remainder of two polynomials, gain some practice with actually performing polynomial division yourself.
title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders

description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!
title: Intro to the Polynomial Remainder Theorem

description: Sal finds the remainder of (-3x^3-4x^2+10x-7) divided by (x-2) using the PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem).
title: Using the Polynomial Remainder Theorem: finding remainders

description: Sal checks whether (x-3) is a factor of (2x^4-11x^3+15x^2+4x-12) using the PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem).
title: Using the Polynomial Remainder Theorem: checking factors

description: Sal determines the value of coefficient c in p(x)=x^3+2x^2+cx+10, in order for (x-5) to be a factor of p. The key is using the PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem)!
title: Using the Polynomial Remainder Theorem: finding coeffcients

description: Use the PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem) to determine the factors of polynomials and their remainders when divided by linear expressions.
title: Use the Polynomial Remainder Theorem

description: The PRT (Polynomial Remainder Theorem) may seem crazy to prove, but Sal shows how you can do it in less than six minutes!
title: Proof of the Polynomial Remainder Theorem

description: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.
title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem

description: Learn how to add, subtract, multiply, and even divide polynomials.
title: Arithmetic with polynomials

description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.
title: Intro to the Binomial Theorem

description: Sal introduces Pascal's triangle, and shows how we can use it to figure out the coefficients in binomial expansions.
title: Pascal's triangle and binomial expansion

description: Sal expands (3y^2+6x^3)^5 using the binomial theorem and Pascal's triangle.
title: Expanding binomials

description: Use the binomial theorem in order to expand integer powers of binomial expressions.
title: Expand binomials

description: Sal gives a "trick" for expanding large powers of binomials, without using Pascal's triangle.
title: Expanding binomials w/o Pascal's triangle

description: Learn how to expand powers of binomial expressions (which are polynomial expressions with exactly two terms). This is done using the binomial theorem!
title: The binomial theorem

description: Sal explains why we use the combinatorial formula for (n choose k) to expand binomial expressions.
title: Binomial expansion & combinatorics

description: Sal shows how generating the values in Pascal's triangle is related to the combinatorial formula (n choose k).
title: Pascal's triangle & combinatorics

description: An old video of Sal explaining why we use the combinatorial formula for (n choose k) to expand binomial expressions.
title: Binomial expansion & combinatorics (old)

description: Now that you know how to use the binomial theorem in order to expand powers of binomial expressions, let's gain further insight into why this actually works!
title: Understanding the binomial theorem

description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-1) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).
title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b) (example 2)

description: Can't get enough of Sal factoring simple quadratics? Here's a handful of examples just for you!
title: More examples of factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)

description: Factor quadratics of the form x²+bx+c.
title: Factor quadratics: leading coefficient = 1

description: Sal factors t^2+8t+15 as (t+3)(t+5), first using the "sum-product" method, then using the grouping method.
title: Introduction to grouping

description: Sal factors 4y^2+4y-15 as (2y-3)(2y+5) by grouping.
title: Factoring quadratics by grouping

description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.
title: Intro to grouping

description: Factor quadratics of the form ax²+bx+c.
title: Factor quadratics: leading coefficient ≠ 1

description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
title: Factoring quadratics: common factor + grouping
Factoring quadratics: negative common factor + grouping

description: Factor polynomials that can be factored as the product of a monomial and a quadratic expression, then further factor the quadratic expression.
title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods

description: Sal factors x^2+4xy-5y^2 as (x-y)(x+5y).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics

description: Sal rearranges 30x^2+11xy+y^2 as y^2+11xy+30x^2 and then factors it as (y+5x)(y+6x).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: rearranging

description: Sal factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).
title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: grouping

description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using quadratic factorization methods.
title: Factor polynomials: quadratic methods (advanced)

description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic.
title: Factoring polynomials - Quadratic forms

description: Factor quadratic expressions into the special products of the general forms (x+a)^2, (x-a)^2, and (x+a)(x-a).
title: Factor special products (basic)

description: Sal factors x^2-49y^2 as (x+7y)(x-7y).
title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables

description: Sal factors 45x^2-125 as 5(3x+5)(3x-5).
title: Factoring difference of squares: leading coefficient ≠ 1

description: Factor quadratic expressions of the general difference of squares form: (ax)^2-b^2. The factored expressions have the general form (ax+b)(ax-b).
title: Factor differences of squares

description: Sal factors -4t^2-12t-9 as -1(2t+3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares: negative common factor

description: Sal factors 25x^2-30x+9 as (5x-3)^2 or as (-5x+3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares

description: Factor quadratic expressions of the general perfect square forms: (ax)^2+2abx+b^2 or (ax)^2-2abx+b^2. The factored expressions have the general forms (ax+b)^2 or (ax-b)^2.
title: Factor perfect squares

description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.
title: Factoring perfect squares: 4th degree polynomial

description: Sal factors 49x^2-49y^2 as (7x+7y)(7x-7y) or as 49(x+y)(x-y).
title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables (example 2)

description: Factor "advanced" polynomials (i.e. polynomials of various degrees and or with two variables) using special product factorization methods.
title: Factor special products (advanced)

description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form and the "difference of squares" form. Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic.
title: Factoring polynomials - Special product forms

description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.
title: Factoring higher-degree polynomials

description: Sal factors 27x^6+125 as (3x^2+5)(9x^4-15x^2+25) using a special product form for a sum of cubes.
title: Factoring sum of cubes

description: Sal factors 40c^3-5d^3 as 5(2x-d)(4c^2+2cd+d^2) using a special product form for a difference of cubes.
title: Factoring difference of cubes

description: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.
title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods

description: Sal considers two cases of polynomial identities and their proofs.
title: Analyzing polynomial identities

description: Determine whether given polynomial identities are true, and whether given proofs of such identities are valid.
title: Prove polynomial identities

description: Practice proving polynomial identities, using all the factorization and expansion methods you know.
title: Proving polynomial identities

description: Learn how expressions of the form x^2+y^2 can be factored into linear factors. This would not be possible without the aid of complex numbers!
title: Complex numbers & sum of squares factorization

description: Sal factors 36a^8+2b^6 as (6a^4-i*√2b^3)(6a^4+i*√2b).
title: Factoring sum of squares

description: Identify correctly factored forms of given polynomials. Factorizations may use complex numbers.
title: Factor polynomials: complex numbers

description: Prove more polynomial identities, this time including complex numbers!
title: Polynomial identities with complex numbers

description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+5=6x using the quadratic formula, and finds that the solutions are complex numbers.
title: Solving quadratic equations: complex roots

description: Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula. some of the equations have real solutions while others have complex solutions.
title: Solve quadratic equations: complex solutions

description: Remember all these quadratic equations with "no real solution"? Well, it turns out those equations do have a solution, it's just a complex number! Solve a bunch of those here.
title: Quadratic equations with complex numbers

description: Sal introduces the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, which, as is reflected in its name, is a very important theorem about polynomials.
title: The Fundamental theorem of Algebra

description: The proof of the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra for any degree of polynomial is really tough. For now, let's note that it indeed holds for polynomials of the second degree (i.e. quadratics).
title: Quadratics & the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra

description: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra can be used in order to determine how many real roots a given polynomial has. Check it out!
title: Number of possible real roots of a polynomial

description: You may already have noticed that quadratic equations always have a solution when including complex number solutions. It turns out this is true for any polynomial equation, of any degree! Learn about this and more, right here.
title: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra

description: Sal finds all the zeros (which is the same as the roots) of p(x)=x⁵+9x³-2x³-18x=0.
title: Finding zeros of polynomials (1 of 2)

description: Sal uses an alternative method to find the zeros of p(x)=x⁵+9x³-2x³-18x=0.
title: Finding zeros of polynomials (2 of 2)

description: Sal finds all the zeros (which is the same as the roots) of p(x)=(3x⁴-8x³+15x-40)(3x-8)².
title: Finding zeros of polynomials (example 2)

description: Use various methods in order to find all the zeros of polynomial expressions or functions.
title: Find zeros of polynomials

description: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).
title: Finding zeros of polynomials

description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.
title: Zeros of polynomials & their graphs

description: Select the graph that best suits a polynomial equation by considering the zeros of the polynomial.
title: Zeros of polynomials & their graphs

description: Given a polynomial, determine the intervals in which it is positive or negative.
title: Positive & negative intervals of polynomials

description: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.
title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs

description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.
title: Intro to end behavior of polynomials

description: Sal picks a function that has a given end behavior based on its graph.
title: End behavior of functions & their graphs

description: Analyze polynomial functions to determine how they behave as the input variable increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity.
title: End behavior of polynomials

description: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.
title: End behavior of polynomial functions

description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.
title: Intro to function symmetry

description: Sal picks the function that is odd among three functions given by their graphs.
title: Graphical symmetry of functions

description: Given the graph of a function, determine if it's even, odd, or neither.
title: Even & odd functions

description: The connection between even and odd functions to even and odd numbers.
title: Even/odd functions & numbers

description: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!
title: Introduction to symmetry of functions

description: Sal analyzes three different polynomials to see if they are even, odd, or neither.
title: Even & odd polynomials

description: Given the formula of a polynomial function, determine whether that function is even, odd, or neither.
title: Even & odd polynomials

description: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.
title: Symmetry of polynomial functions

description: Learn how to manipulate polynomials in order to prove identities and find the zeros of those polynomials. Use this knowledge to solve polynomial equations and graph polynomial functions. Learn about symmetry of functions.
title: Polynomial expressions, equations, and functions

description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.
title: Intro to square-root equations & extraneous solutions

description: Sal solves the equation √(5x^2-8)=2x.
title: Solving square-root equations (basic)

description: Solve square-root equations by taking the square of both sides.
title: Solve square-root equations (basic)

description: Sal solves the equation 3+√(5x+6)=12.
title: Solving square-root equations: one solution

description: Sal solves the equation 6+3w=√(2w+12)+2w which has two solutions.
title: Solving square-root equations: two solutions

description: Sal solves the equation √(3x-7)+√(2x-1)=0, only to find out that the single solution is extraneous, which means the equation has no solution.
title: Solving square-root equations: no solution

description: Solve square-root equations by first arranging them and then taking the square of both sides.
title: Solve square-root equations

description: Learn how to solve equations with square-root expressions in them. For example, solve √(2x-5)=√(7-3x).
title: Solving square-root equations

description: Sal gives an example of how an extraneous solution arises when solving 2x-1=√(8-x).
title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations

description: Sal finds the value of d for which √(3x+25)=d+2x has an extraneous solution at x=-3.
title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations (example 2)

description: Practice some problems that involve thinking about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.
title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations

description: Learn about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.
title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations

description: Sal solves the equation -∛y=4∛y+5.
title: Solving cube-root equations

description: Learn how to solve equations with cube-root expressions in them. For example, solve ∛(2-6x)=x+3.
title: Solving cube-root equations

description: Sal finds the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
title: Domain of a radical functions
