description: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.
title: Domain of radical functions

description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.
title: Transforming the square-root function

description: Sal graphs y=√x. Then, he shows a few examples of how we can shift and stretch the graphs of y=√x and y=x^2, and how the equations of those graphs look.
title: Graphs of square-root functions

description: Sal is given a drawing with four graphs and four formulas of square-root functions. He uses transformations to match each formula with its appropriate graph.
title: Square-root functions & their graphs

description: Given the formula of a square-root or a cube-root function, find the appropriate graph.
title: Radical functions & their graphs

description: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).
title: Graphs of radical functions

description: In this topic you will learn how to solve radical equations (which are equations with radical expressions in them) while avoiding extraneous solutions. You will also learn how to graph radical functions.
title: Radical equations and functions

description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!
title: Intro to rational expression simplification

description: Sal simplifies the rational expressions (14x²+7x)/(14x) and (17z³+17z²)/(34z³-51z²) by taking common factors and canceling them.
title: Simplifying rational expressions: common monomial factors

description: Factor the numerator and the denominator of a rational expression and cancel out common monomial factors.
title: Simplify rational expressions: common monomial factors

description: Given a rectangle with length a²+6a+27 and width a²-9, Sal writes the ratio of the width to the length as a simplified rational expression.
title: Simplifying rational expressions: common binomial factors

description: Sal simplifies and states the domain of (x^2-36)/(6-x).
title: Simplifying rational expressions: opposite common binomial factors

description: Factor the numerator and the denominator of a rational expression and cancel out common binomial terms.
title: Simplify rational expressions: common binomial factors

description: Sal simplifies and states the domain of (2x^2+13x+20)/(2x^2+17x+30).
title: Simplifying rational expressions: grouping

description: Sal simplifies & states the domain of (x⁴+8x²+7)/(3x⁵-3x).
title: Simplifying rational expressions: higher degree terms

description: Sal simplifies & states the domain of (5x²+20xy+20y²)/(x²-xy-6y²).
title: Simplifying rational expressions: two variables

description: Factor the numerator and the denominator of a rational expression using advanced methods, and cancel out common terms.
title: Simplify rational expressions (advanced)

description: Sal simplifies (28b^6)/(7b) as 4b^5.
title: Simplifying rational expressions (old video)

description: Learn how to simplify rational expressions by canceling factors that are shared by the numerator and the denominator. Sometimes this calls for factoring the numerator and the denominator in various ways.
title: Simplifying rational expressions

description: Sal multiplies (6x³/5) X (2/3x) and divides (2x⁴/7) ➗ (5x⁴/4).
title: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions: monomials

description: Example: Multiply and simplify (6x³/5)*(2/3x).
title: Multiply & divide rational expressions (basic)

description: Sal multiplies and simplifies (a²-4)/(a²-1) X (a+1)/(a+2).
title: Multiplying rational expressions

description: Sal divides and simplifies (2p+6)/(p+5) ➗ (10)/(4p+20).
title: Dividing rational expressions

description: Example: Multiply and simplify (a²-4)/(a²-1) X (a+1)/(a+2).
title: Multiply & divide rational expressions

description: Sal multiplies and simplifies (3x²y)/(2ab) X (14a²b)/(18xy²).
title: Multiplying rational expressions: multiple variables

description: Sal finds the polynomial D for which (20y²-80)/D ÷ (4y²-8y)/(y³+9y²)=1 is true for all values of y for which it's defined.
title: Dividing rational expressions: unknown expression

description: Example: Multiply and simplify (3x²y)/(2ab) X (14a²b)/(18xy²).
title: Multiply & divide rational expressions (advanced)

description: Learn how to multiply and divide rational expressions. You will be surprised to see how similar it is to multiplying and dividing fractions!
title: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions

description: Sal adds 6/(2x²-7) + (-3x-8)/(2x²-7) and subtracts (9x²+3)/(14x²-9) - (-3x²+5)/(14x²-9).
title: Adding & subtracting rational expressions: like denominators

description: Example: Add and simplify 6/(2x²-7) + (-3x-8)/(2x²-7).
title: Add & subtract rational expressions: like denominators

description: Sal rewrites a/b+c/d as a single rational expression.
title: Intro to adding rational expressions with unlike denominators

description: Add and subtract rational expressions with relatively prime denominators by manipulating them to have the same denominators.
title: Add & subtract rational expressions: unlike denominators

description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 12 and 36, and of 12 and 18. He shows how to do that using the prime factorization method, which is a just great!
title: Least common multiple

description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 25 and 30.
title: Least common multiple: repeating factors

description: Find the lcm (least common multiple) of pairs of integers.
title: Least common multiple

description: Sal subtracts two rational expressions whose denominators are factored. The denominators aren't the same but they share a factor.
title: Subtracting rational expressions: factored denominators

description: Sal finds the least common multiple (LCM) of 3z³-6z²-9z and 7z⁴+21z³+14z².
title: Least common multiple of polynomials

description: Example: Add and simplify x/(2x+1)(x-7) + 2x²/(2x-3)(x-7).
title: Add & subtract rational expressions: factored denominators

description: Sal subtracts and simplifies (a-2)/(a+2) - (a-3)/(a²+4a+4).
title: Subtracting rational expressions

description: Example: Subtract and simplify (a-2)/(a+2) - (a-3)/(a²+4a+4).
title: Add & subtract rational expressions

description: Learn how to add and subtract rational expressions. Like multiplication and division, this skill has a remarkable affinity to adding and subtracting fractions!
title: Adding & subtracting rational expressions

description: Sal starts with a simple case of multiplying two fractions and proceeds to simplifying a nested fraction expression.
title: Nested fractions

description: Simplify rational expressions that contain rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.
title: Nested fractions

description: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.
title: Nested fractions

description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.
title: Equations with one rational expression

description: Solve equations that have one rational expression whose numerator and denominator are linear expressions.
title: Equations with one rational expression

description: Sal solves the following equation by first simplifying the rational expression: x^2-(x^2-4)/(x-2)=4.
title: Equations with one rational expression (advanced)

description: Solve equations that have one rational expression whose numerator and denominator are polynomial expressions.
title: Equations with one rational expression (advanced)

description: Sal solves (x²-10x+21)/(3x-12)=(x-5)/(x-4), which has one real solution and one extraneous solution.
title: Equations with rational expressions

description: Solve advanced rational equations with multiple expressions.
title: Equations with two rational expressions

description: Sal solves the equation 4/(p-1)=5/(p+3).
title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example)

description: Sal solves the equation 5/(2x)-4/(3x)=7/18 by first finding the LCM (least common multiple) of 2x and 3x.
title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example 2)

description: Sal solves the following equation and eliminates the resulting extraneous solution: (x^2)/(x+2)=4/(x+2).
title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example 3)

description: Learn how to solve equations that have a rational expression, or a few of those.
title: Solving rational equations

description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.
title: Intro to direct & inverse variation

description: Sal gives many examples of two-variable equations where the variables vary directly, inversely, or neither.
title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation

description: Given a few two-variable equations, find those that show direct or inverse variation.
title: Recognize direct & inverse variation

description: Sal is given a table with a few values of the variables x and y, and determines whether the variables vary directly or inversely.
title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation: table

description: Sal models a context about lengths of strings and the frequency of their vibrations! with an inverse variation equation.
title: Inverse variation word problem: string vibration

description: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.
title: Direct and inverse variation

description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of several rational functions, that together cover all cases types of end behavior.
title: End behavior of rational functions

description: Given a rational function, determine how it behaves as x approaches +∞ or -∞.
title: End behavior of rational functions

description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.
title: End behavior of rational functions

description: Sal analyzes two rational functions to find their vertical asymptotes & removable discontinuities. He distinguishes those from the zeros of the functions.
title: Discontinuities of rational functions

description: Given a rational function, sort given input values according to zeros, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.
title: Rational function points of discontinuity

description: Sal analyzes the behavior of q(x)=(x²+3x+2)/(x+3) around its vertical asymptote at x=-3.
title: Analyzing vertical asymptotes of rational functions

description: Given the formula of a rational function, determine how it behaves around its vertical asymptote.
title: Analyze vertical asymptotes of rational functions

description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.
title: Discontinuities of rational functions

description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.
title: Graphing rational functions according to asymptotes

description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(ax^m+bx+12)/(cx^m+dx+12) based on its y-intercept.
title: Graphs of rational functions: y-intercept

description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(-x²+ax+b)/(x²+cx+d) based on its horizontal asymptote.
title: Graphs of rational functions: horizontal asymptote

description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=g(x)/(x²-x-6) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its discontinuities.
title: Graphs of rational functions: vertical asymptotes

description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(2x²-18)/g(x) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its zeros.
title: Graphs of rational functions: zeros

description: Determine which of four graphs fits the formula of a given function.
title: Graphs of rational functions

description: Sal matches three graphs of rational functions to three formulas of such functions by considering asymptotes and intercepts.
title: Graphs of rational functions (old example)

description: Sal graphs f(x)=(2x+10)/(5x-15).
title: Graphing rational functions 1

description: Sal graphs y=(2x)/(x+1).
title: Graphing rational functions 2

description: Sal graphs y=(x^2)/(x^2-16).
title: Graphing rational functions 3

description: Sal graphs y=(x)/(x^2-x-6).
title: Graphing rational functions 4

description: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!
title: Graphs of rational functions

description: Sal solves a word problem about the combined leaf-bagging rates of Ian and Kyandre, by creating a rational equation that models the situation.
title: Rational equations word problem: combined rates

description: Sal solves a word problem about the combined deck-staining rates of Anya and Bill, by creating a rational equation that models the situation.
title: Rational equations word problem: combined rates (example 2)

description: Sal solves a word problem about the combined pool-filling rates of two water hoses, by creating a rational equation that models the situation. The equation has a solution that is eliminated due to the context.
title: Rational equations word problem: eliminating solutions

description: See some examples of how rational functions and equations can come in handy when solving real-world word problems.
title: Modeling with rational functions

description: Rational expressions are like fractions, but instead of integers in the numerator and the denominator, you have variable expressions! Learn how to work with such expressions. Namely, simplify, add, subtract, multiply, and divide them (much like fractions!). Then, solve some equations with rational expressions in them, and analyze the behavior of rational functions.
title: Rational expressions, equations, and functions

description: Sal simplifies the expression 10*9^(0.5t+2)*5^(3t) as 810*375^t.
title: Simplifying exponential expressions

description: Determine whether pairs of exponential expressions are equivalent.
title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions

description: Rewrite a given exponential expression in a specific desired form.
title: Rewrite exponential expressions

description: Learn how to manipulate exponential expressions in different ways. For example, rewrite 8^x as 2^(3x).
title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions

description: Sal solves equations like 26^(9x+5) = 1 and 2^(3x+5) = 64^(x-7).
title: Solving exponential equations using exponent properties

description: Example: Solve 2^(3x+5) = 64^(x-7).
title: Solve exponential equations using exponent properties

description: Sal solves equations like 32^(x/3) = 8^(x-12) and 5^(4x+3) / 25^(9-x) = 5^(2x+5).
title: Solving exponential equations using exponent properties (advanced)

description: Example: Solve 32^(x/3) = 8^(x-12).
title: Solve exponential equations using exponent properties (advanced)

description: Learn how to solve advanced exponential equations by manipulating the expressions in the equations using the properties of exponents. For example, solve 2^(x+1)=8^x by rewriting 8^x as 2^(3x) and then equating x+1=3x.
title: Solving exponential equations using properties of exponents

description: Sal solves two word problems: one about a radioactive decay, and the other the exponential growth of a fast-food chain.
title: Exponential growth & decay word problems

description: Learn about different ways of describing the rate of change of exponential functions.
title: Introduction to rate of exponential growth and decay

description: Sal finds the factor by which a quantity changes over a single time unit in various exponential models.
title: Interpreting change in exponential models

description: Given a function that models an exponential situation, find the factor by which the quantity changes per unit time interval.
title: Interpret change in exponential models

description: Sal finds the time interval over which a quantity changes by a given factor in various exponential models.
title: Interpreting time in exponential models

description: Given a function that models an exponential situation, find the time interval over which the quantity changes by a given factor.
title: Interpret time in exponential models

description: Learn how to analyze exponential modeling functions in order to find their rate of change.
title: Interpreting the rate of change of exponential models

description: Sal models the distribution of a chain letter using an exponential function.
title: Constructing exponential models

description: Sal models the decay of a Carbon-14 sample using an exponential function.
title: Constructing exponential models: half life

description: Sal models a population of narwhals using an exponential function.
title: Constructing exponential models: percent change

description: Given a verbal description of the rate of change of a real world situation, find the exponential function that models it.
title: Construct exponential models

description: Sal constructs a function to model the decay of a radioactive element.
title: Constructing exponential models (old example)

description: Learn how to find the modeling function of an exponential real world context, according to the description of its rate of change.
title: Constructing exponential models according to rate of change

description: Sal analyzes the rate of change of various exponential models, where the function that models the situation needs some manipulation.
title: Interpreting change in exponential models: with manipulation

description: Given a function that models an exponential situation, rewrite the function in order to analyze its rate of change.
title: Interpret change in exponential models: with manipulation

description: Sal analyzes the rate of change of various exponential models for different time units by manipulating the functions that model the situations.
title: Interpreting change in exponential models: changing units

description: Given a function that models an exponential situation, rewrite the function in order to find its change for a different time unit.
title: Interpret change in exponential models: changing units

description: Learn how to interpret an exponential modeling function by first manipulating it according to your needs. For example, rewrite 5^(2x+1) as 5*25^x to find that the unit growth factor is 25.
title: Advanced interpretation of exponential models

description: Sal constructs functions that model the growth of trees over time. To do that, he identifies which growth is linear and which is exponential.
title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data

description: Sal constructs a function that models cooling water. To do that, he decides whether the function is linear or exponential.
title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data (example 2)

description: Given a table with values of two quantities over time, determine whether the quantities form grow linearly or exponentially.
title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data

description: Learn how to analyze real-world quantitative relationships given as tables of values to determine whether they represent linear growth or exponential growth.
title: Distinguishing between linear and exponential growth

description: Learn how to analyze and manipulate exponential functions and expressions in order to study their rate of change.
title: Exponential growth and decay

description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.
title: Intro to logarithms

description: Evaluate basic logarithmic expressions by using the fact that a^x=b is equivalent to log_a(b)=x.
title: Evaluate logarithms

description: Sal evaluates log₂(8), log₈(2), log₂(⅛), and log₈(½).
title: Evaluating logarithms (advanced)

description: Evaluate advanced logarithmic expressions by using the fact that a^x=b is equivalent to log_a(b)=x.
title: Evaluate logarithms (advanced)

description: Sal rewrites 100=10^2 as a logarithmic equation and log_5(1/125)=-3 as an exponential equation.
title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms

description: Given a few points on the graph of an exponential function, Sal plots the corresponding points on the graph of the corresponding logarithmic function.
title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: graphs

description: Given incomplete tables of values of b^x and its corresponding inverse function, log_b(y), Sal uses the inverse relationship of the functions to fill in the missing values.
title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: tables

description: Solve various problems that focus on the relationship between a^x=b and log_a(b)=x.
title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms

description: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.
title: Introduction to logarithms

description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant e.
title: e and compound interest

description: Sal continues the discussion on e, this time digging deeper into the mathematical definition of e.
title: e as a limit

description: Sal evaluates log_e(67) (which is more commonly written as ln(67) ) using a calculator.
title: Evaluating natural logarithm with calculator

description: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.
title: The constant e and the natural logarithm

description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.
title: Intro to logarithm properties (1 of 2)

description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for multiplication of logarithm by a constant, and the change of base rule.
title: Intro to logarithm properties (2 of 2)

description: Sal rewrites log₃(27x) as log₃(27)+log_3(x), which is simplified as 3+log₃(x).
title: Using the logarithmic product rule

description: Sal rewrites log₅(x³) as 3log₅(x).
title: Using the logarithmic power rule

description: Use the properties of logarithms in order to rewrite a given expression in an equivalent, different form.
title: Use the properties of logarithms

description: Sal rewrites log_5([25^x]/y) as 2x-log_5(y) by using both the log subtraction property and the log multiplied by a constant property.
title: Using the properties of logarithms: multiple steps

description: Sal proves the logarithm addition property, log(a) + log(b) = log(ab).
title: Proof of the logarithm product rule

description: Sal proves the logarithm quotient rule, log(a) - log(b) = log(a/b), and the power rule, k⋅log(a) = log(aᵏ).
title: Proof of the logarithm quotient and power rules

description: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).
title: Properties of logarithms

description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
title: Evaluating logarithms: change of base rule

description: Evaluate any logarithm in a calculator with the use of the change of base formula. Example: Evaluate log₅(100).
title: Evaluate logarithms: change of base rule

description: Sal rewrites logarithmic expressions like 1/(logₐ4) or logₐ(16)*log₂(a) using the change of base rule.
title: Using the logarithm change of base rule

description: Find the logarithmic variable expression that is equivalent to a given logarithmic expression.
title: Use the logarithm change of base rule

description: Sal proves the logarithmic change of base rule, logₐ(b)=logₓ(b)/logₓ(a).
title: Proof of the logarithm change of base rule

description: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.
title: The change of base formula for logarithms

description: Sal solves the equation log(x)+log(3)=2log(4)-log(2).
title: Logarithmic equations: variable in the argument

description: Sal solves the equation 4=log_b(81).
title: Logarithmic equations: variable in the base

description: Learn how to solve equations that contain logarithmic expressions. For example, solve log(x)+log(3)=log(7).
title: Logarithmic equations

description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.
title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-10

description: Solve exponential equations that have 10 or e at the base of the exponential term.
title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-10 and base-e

description: Sal solves the equation 5*2^t=1111.
title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-2

description: Solve exponential equations that have 2 or other numbers at the base of the exponential term.
title: Solve exponential equations using logarithms: base-2 and other bases

description: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).
title: Solving exponential equations with logarithms

description: Sal solves an exponential equation in order to answer a question about an exponential model.
title: Exponential model word problem: medication dissolve

description: Sal evaluates an exponential function at a specific value in order to answer a question about an exponential model.
title: Exponential model word problem: bacteria growth

description: Solve word problems about exponential situations.
title: Exponential model word problems

description: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.
title: Solving exponential models

description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=2⁻ˣ-5, which is a horizontal reflection and shift of y=2ˣ.
title: Transforming exponential graphs

description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=-1*2&(x+3)+4, which is a vertical reflection and a shift of y=2ˣ.
title: Transforming exponential graphs (example 2)

description: Sal graphs y=-2*3ˣ+5 using our interactive graphing widget.
title: Graphing exponential functions

description: Graph exponential functions and find the appropriate graph given the function.
title: Graphs of exponential functions

description: Sal shows how to graph the exponential equation y=5^x, including a discussion of the end behavior of the function.
title: The graph of y=5^x

description: Sal matches the following four functions to their appropriate graphs: y=2^x, y=-3^x, y=2-(1/3)^x, y=(1/2)^x-2.
title: Graphs of exponential functions (old example)

description: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.
title: Graphs of exponential functions

description: Sal graphs y=2^x and y=log_2(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how their relate as graphs of inverse functions.
title: Graphs of logarithms & exponentials

description: Sal graphs y=log_5(x).
title: Graphing basic logarithmic functions

description: Sal is given a graph of a logarithmic function with four possible formulas, and finds the appropriate one.
title: Graphs of logarithmic functions

description: Graph logarithmic functions and find the appropriate graph given the function.
title: Graphs of logarithmic functions

description: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.
title: Graphs of logarithmic functions

description: Vi Hart and Sal talk about how we humans perceive things nonlinearly
title: Logarithmic scale (with Vi Hart)

description: Sal discusses the differences between linear and logarithmic scale.
title: Logarithmic scale

description: Sal explains the basics of the Richter scale (Moment magnitude scale) and uses this to compare the magnitude of 4 famous earthquakes.
title: Richter scale

description: Vi Hart visits Khan Academy and talks about the mysteries of Benford's Law with Sal
title: Benford's law (with Vi Hart, 1 of 2)

description: Vi Hart visits Khan Academy and talks about the mysteries of Benford's Law with Sal
title: Benford's law (with Vi Hart, 2 of 2)

description: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.
title: Logarithmic scale

description: Learn about logarithms, which are the inverses of exponents. Use logarithms to solve various equations. Then analyze both logarithmic and exponential functions and their graphs.
title: Exponential and logarithmic functions

description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.
title: Intro to radians

description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.
title: Degrees to radians

description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.
title: Radians to degrees

description: Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Sal determines the quadrant at which a ray falls after a rotation by a certain measure of radians.
title: Radian angles & quadrants

description: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).
title: Introduction to radians

description: Sal shows how we can extend SOH CAH TOA so that we can define trig functions (sine, cosine, & tangent) for all real numbers.
title: Unit circle definition of trig functions

description: Sal shows how, for acute angles, the two different definitions of the trigonometric values (SOH CAH TOA and the unit circle definition) result in the same values.
title: The trig functions & right triangle trig ratios

description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.
title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal draws the graph of the sine function to learn about its domain and range.
title: Graph of y=sin(x)

description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.
title: Graph of y=tan(x)

description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.
title: Intersection points of y=sin(x) and y=cos(x)

description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.
title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.
title: Sine & cosine identities: symmetry

description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for tangent by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.
title: Tangent identities: symmetry

description: Sal finds trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering angle rotations on the unit circle.
title: Sine & cosine identities: periodicity

description: Sal solves a problem by considering the periodicity of the tangent function.
title: Tangent identities: periodicity

description: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.
title: Basic trigonometric identities

description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.
title: Trig values of special angles

description: Find the sine and cosine of special angles, which are angles whose trig values we can determine without the use of a calculator.
title: Trig values of special angles

description: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.
title: Trigonometric values of special angles

description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.
title: Proof of the Pythagorean trig identity

description: Given that sin(θ)=1/2 and that θ is in the third quadrant, Sal finds tan(θ) using the Pythagorean identity.
title: Using the Pythagorean trig identity

description: Given the sine (or cosine) of an angle, find its cosine (or sine) using the Pythagorean identity.
title: Use the Pythagorean identity

description: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.
title: The Pythagorean identity

description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.
title: Features of sinusoidal functions

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.
title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.
title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.
title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.
title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.
title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.
title: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.
title: Period of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.
title: Period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.
title: Period of sinusoidal functions

description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
title: Transforming sinusoidal graphs: vertical stretch & horizontal reflection

description: Sal graphs y=-2.5*cos(1/3*x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and reflection, and a horizontal stretch, of y=cos(x).
title: Transforming sinusoidal graphs: vertical & horizontal stretches

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx)+d, draw its graph.
title: Graph sinusoidal functions

description: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.
title: Graphing sinusoidal functions

description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.
title: Sinusoidal function from graph

description: Given a few features of a sinusoidal function, find its formula.
title: Construct sinusoidal functions

description: Sal solves a word problem about the daily change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.
title: Trig word problem: modeling daily temperature

description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.
title: Trig word problem: modeling annual temperature

description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it.
title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions

description: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.
title: Constructing sinusoidal functions

description: Learn about the definition of the basic trigonometric functions (sin(x), cos(x), and tan(x)), and use advanced trigonometric functions for various purposes.
title: Trigonometric functions

description: Sal interprets the intersection point of the graphs of functions f and g as the solution of the equation f(x)=g(x).
title: Interpreting equations graphically

description: Sal finds the coordinates of points on a graph that are solutions to a given equation.
title: Interpreting equations graphically (example 2)

description: Practice the connection between the graphical representation of equations and their algebraic solutions.
title: Interpret equations graphically

description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].
title: Solving equations graphically (1 of 2)

description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].
title: Solving equations by graphically (2 of 2)

description: Solve advanced and complicated equations using the power of graphs.
title: Solve equations grapically

description: Learn how to approximate the solution to any equation by using the power of graphs.
title: Solving equations by graphing

description: Sal solves x^2+3x>10.
title: Quadratic inequalities

description: Sal solves -x(2x-14)≥24.
title: Quadratic inequalities (example 2)

description: Sal solves a few quadratic inequalities by moving all terms to one side of the inequality and graphing the resulting expression.
title: Quadratic inequalities: graphical approach

description: Learn how to solve inequalities that contain quadratic expressions. For instance, solve x^2+3x+2>0.
title: Quadratic inequalities

description: Sal shows two ways to solve the inequality (x-1)/(x+2)>0.
title: Rational inequalities: one side is zero

description: Sal solves the rational inequality (x-3)/(x+4)≥2.
title: Rational inequalities: both sides are not zero

description: Learn how to solve inequalities that contain rational expressions. For instance, solve (x-3)/(x+4)≥2..
title: Rational inequalities

description: Sal discusses how we approach solving systems of three variables algebraically, and how we visualize it graphically.
title: Intro to linear systems with 3 variables

description: Sal solves a system of three variables using elimination.
title: Solving linear systems with 3 variables

description: Sal solves a system with three variables that turns out to have no solution.
title: Solving linear systems with 3 variables: no solution

description: Sal solves a word problem about the angles of a given triangle by modeling the given information as a system of three equations and variables.
title: 3-variable linear system word problem

description: Learn how to make the most out of the familiar algebraic techniques in order to solve systems of three equations with three variables.
title: Systems with three variables

description: Learn how to approximate the solution to any kind of equation by graphing; Learn how to solve non-linear inequalities; Learn how to solve systems with more than two equations.
title: Advanced equations and inequalities

description: Sal covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.
title: Domain of advanced functions

description: Determine the domain of functions whose expressions are a combination of different types of assignment rules.
title: Domain of advanced functions

description: Determine the domain of piecewise functions whose assignment rules have different expression types.
title: Domain of advanced piecewise functions

description: Learn how to determine the domain of piecewise functions with different function rules.
title: Determining the domain of advanced functions

description: Sal finds the domain and the range of f(x)=3x^2+6x-2.
title: Domain and range of quadratic functions

description: Given the equation of a quadratic function, determine its range.
title: Range of quadratic functions

description: Learn how to find the range of a function, which is the set of all of the function's possible outputs.
title: Determining the range of a function

description: Sal is given the graph of a piecewise function and several possible formulas. He determines which is the correct formula.
title: Graphs of nonlinear piecewise functions

description: Given the graph of a nonlinear piecewise function, find its formula.
title: Graphs of nonlinear piecewise functions

description: Learn how to graph piecewise functions whose assignment rules are not linear.
title: Graphing nonlinear piecewise functions

description: Sal interprets the significance of modeling function being even.
title: Symmetry of algebraic models

description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their symmetry.
title: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models

description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of graphs that model real world situations.
title: End behavior of algebraic models

description: Given the graph that models a real world context, answer a question about the end behavior of the graph.
title: End behavior of algebraic models

description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their end behavior.
title: Interpreting the end behavior of algebraic models

description: Sal analyzes the periodicity of graphs that model real world situations.
title: Periodicity of algebraic models

description: Given the graph that models a real world context, answer a question about the periodicity of the graph.
title: Periodicity of algebraic models

description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their periodicity.
title: Interpreting the periodicity of algebraic models

description: Given several functions represented in different forms (as a formula, as a graph, and as a table of values), Sal finds the one with that has no x-intercepts.
title: Comparing functions: x-intercepts

description: Sal is given the formula of one function and the graph of the other, and he determines which features are shared by both functions.
title: Comparing functions: shared features

description: Given several quadratic functions represented in different forms, Sal finds the one with the lowest maximum value.
title: Comparing maximum points of quadratic functions

description: Compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.
title: Compare features of functions

description: Learn how to compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.
title: Comparing features of functions

description: Sal solves a few problems where a new operator is defined and Sal evaluates some expression with it.
title: New operator definitions 1

description: Given the definition of a new operator, evaluate an expression that contains that operator.
title: New operator definitions 1

description: Worked examples of working with more newly defined operators.
title: New operator definitions 2

description: Given the definition of two new operators, evaluate an expression that contains that operator.
title: New operator definitions 2

description: Learn about functions that take *two* inputs in order to output a single value.
title: Two-variable functions

description: Learn how to determine the domain, the range, and the graph of relatively advanced functions. Learn how to interpret advanced features of functions (like symmetry, end behavior, and periodicity) in terms of their context, and compare features of various types of functions. Learn about two-variable functions.
title: Advanced functions

description: Sal explains sequences and gives examples of different sequences, defined either explicitly or recursively.
title: Intro to sequences

description: Sal introduces arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. He gives various examples of such sequences, defined explicitly and recursively.
title: Intro to arithmetic sequences

description: Given the first few terms in an arithmetic sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend arithmetic sequences

description: Given the formula of an arithmetic sequence, ether in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use arithmetic sequence formulas

description: Find the recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in an arithmetic sequence are 12, 5, -2, and -9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds the equation that describes a growth pattern of shapes made of squares.
title: Sequences word problem: growth pattern

description: Review arithmetic sequences before you dive into arithmetic series.
title: Arithmetic sequences

description: The standard notation for writing long sums.
title: Sigma notation for sums

description: Evaluate expressions that use sigma notation to make sure you understand what sigma notation means.
title: Sigma notation

description: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!
title: Basic sigma notation

description: Sal explains the formula for the sum of a finite arithmetic series
title: Intro to finite arithmetic series

description: Practice figuring out the sum of finite arithmetic series
title: Finite arithmetic series

description: Watch Sal prove the expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n.
title: Proof of finite arithmetic series formula

description: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.
title: Finite arithmetic series

description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.
title: Intro to geometric sequences

description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and gives a few examples. Notation used in this video is relatively advanced.
title: Intro to geometric sequences (advanced)

description: Given the first few terms in a geometric sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend geometric sequences

description: Given the formula of a geometric sequence, either in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use geometric sequence formulas

description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.
title: Explicit & recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in a geometric sequence are 1/3, 1, 3, and 9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for geometric sequences

description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of geometric sequences

description: Find the recursive formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Given a verbal description of a real-world relationship, determine the sequence that models that relationship.
title: Sequences word problems

description: Review geometric sequences before you dive into geometric series.
title: Geometric sequences

description: Think about a geometric series as the sum of a geometric sequence.
title: Intro to geometric series

description: Sal extends the idea of geometric sequences to geometric series
title: Geometric series with sigma notation

description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series
title: Finite geometric series

description: Evaluate finite geometric series given in sigma notation, recursively, or explicitly.
title: Finite geometric series

description: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!
title: Finite geometric series

description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.
title: Finite geometric series word problem: social media

description: Figuring out the formula for fixed mortgage payments using the sum of a geometric series
title: Finite geometric series word problem: mortgage

description: Understanding and solving problems with the formula for a finite geometric series
title: Finite geometric series word problems

description: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.
title: Finite geometric series applications

description: Review sequences and then dive into arithmetic and geometric series.
title: Sequences and series

description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.
title: Rational equation word problem

description: Sal models a context that concerns a candy vending machine. The model turns out to be a quadratic inequality.
title: Quadratic inequality word problem

description: Sal models a context that concerns a bank savings account. The model turns out to be an exponential equation.
title: Exponential equation word problem

description: Construct an equation or an inequality that model a given context. Modeling expressions can be quadratic, rational, or exponential.
title: Equations & inequalities word problems

description: Learn how to determine the appropriate *type* of modeling equation (or inequality) according to the description of a real-world context.
title: Modeling with one-variable equations and inequalities

description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.
title: Manipulating formulas: perimeter

description: Sal rewrites the formula for the area of a triangle so it is solved for height.
title: Manipulating formulas: area

description: Sal takes the formula for converting from Fahrenheit temperature to Celsius, and solves it for F so it serves to convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit.
title: Manipulating formulas: temperature

description: Solve multi-variable formulas for a specific variable in order to solve some word problems.
title: Manipulate formulas

description: Learn how to solve problems that involve multi-variable formulas.
title: Manipulating formulas

description: Practice modeling problems with a variety of function types.
title: Modeling with algebra

description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.
title: Intro to conic sections

description: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.
title: Introduction to conic sections

description: Sal graphs a circle centered at (3,-2) with a radius of 5 units in our interactive widget.
title: Graphing circles from features

description: Given information about the center and radius of a circle, graph it.
title: Graph a circle from its features

description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its center and its radius.
title: Features of a circle from its graph

description: Given the graph of a circle, find its center and radius.
title: Features of a circle from its graph

description: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.
title: The features of a circle

description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.
title: Features of a circle from its standard equation

description: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in standard form.
title: Features of a circle from its standard equation

description: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.
title: Graphing a circle from its standard equation

description: Given the standard form equation of a circle, graph the circle.
title: Graph a circle from its standard equation

description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².
title: Writing standard equation of a circle

description: Given the graph of a circle or its features, find its standard equation.
title: Write standard equation of a circle

description: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.
title: Standard equation of a circle

description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.
title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

description: Find the center and radius of a circle given the equation in expanded form.
title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation

description: Given an expanded equation of a circle, graph it.
title: Graph a circle from its expanded equation

description: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.
title: Expanded equation of a circle

description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.
title: Intro to focus & directrix

description: Sal derives the equation of a general parabola whose focus is (a,b) and directrix is y=k. He then uses this general formula in order to find the specific formula whose focus is (1,2) and directrix is y=-1.
title: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix

description: Given the focus and the directrix of a parabola, find its equation.
title: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix

description: Given the parabola equation y-23/4=-1/3(x-1)^2, Sal finds the parabola's focus and directrix using the general formula for a parabola whose focus is (a,b) and directrix is y=k.
title: Focus & directrix of a parabola from equation

description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.
title: Focus and directrix of a parabola

description: Learn about two basic conic sections and their equations: Circle and Parabola.
title: Introduction to conic sections

description: Your studies in algebra 1 have built a solid foundation from which you can explore linear equations, inequalities, and functions. In algebra 2 we build upon that foundation and not only extend our knowledge of algebra 1, but slowly become capable of tackling the BIG questions of the universe.  We'll again touch on systems of equations, inequalities, and functions...but we'll also address exponential and logarithmic functions, logarithms, imaginary and complex numbers, conic sections, and matrices. Don't let these big words intimidate you. We're on this journey with you!
title: Algebra II

description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.
title: Intro to the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.
title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles

description: Given the side lengths of a right triangle, find the sine, cosine, or tangent of one of the acute angles.
title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles

description: Meet your new best friends: sine, cosine, and tangent.
title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
title: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry

description: Given one side length and an acute angle in a right triangle, find another side using trigonometry.
title: Solve for a side in right triangles

description: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.
title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

description: Given two sides in a right triangle, find one of the acute angles using trigonometry.
title: Solve for an angle in right triangles

description: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.
title: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.
title: Right triangle word problem

description: Solve word problems by modeling real-world (and not-so-real) situations as right triangles and using trigonometry.
title: Right triangle word problems

description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.
title: Modeling with right triangles

description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.
title: Triangle similarity & the trigonometric ratios

description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to verify identities relating to trig ratios in those triangles.
title: Trig challenge problem: verify identities

description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.
title: Trig challenge problem: trig values & side ratios

description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.
title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity

description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles

description: Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53, find sin(32°).
title: Using complementary angles

description: Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.
title: Trig word problem: complementary angles

description: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90°.
title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles

description: Sal introduces and proves the identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1, which arises from the Pythagorean theorem!
title: Intro to the Pythagorean trig identity

description: Learn about a very special trigonometric identity that follows from the Pythagorean theorem.
title: Introduction to the Pythagorean trigonometric identity

description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.
title: Finding reciprocal trig ratios

description: Sal is given two sides in a right triangle and the cotangent of one of the angles, and he uses this information to find the missing side.
title: Using reciprocal trig ratios

description: Understand the right triangle definition of sec, csc, and cot ratios.
title: Reciprocal trig ratios

description: Learn about the remaining three side ratios in a right triangle: the secant, the cosecant, and the cotangent.
title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios

description: Learn the basics of trigonometry: What are sine, cosine, and tangent? How can we use them to solve for unknown sides and angles in right triangles?
title: Trigonometry with right triangles

description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solving for a side with the law of sines

description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure, and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solving for an angle with the law of sines

description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of sines.
title: Solve triangles using the law of sines

description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.
title: Proof of the law of sines

description: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.
title: The law of sines

description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and the contained angle measure, and he finds the missing side length using the law of cosines.
title: Solving for a side with the law of cosines

description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure, and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.
title: Solving for an angle with the law of cosines

description: Solve missing triangle measures using the law of cosines.
title: Solve triangles using the law of cosines

description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.
title: Proof of the law of cosines

description: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.
title: The law of cosines

description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.
title: Trig word problem: stars

description: Solve word problems that involve general triangles using trigonometry.
title: General triangle word problems

description: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.
title: Solving general triangles

description: Learn how to use trigonometry in order to find missing sides and angles in any triangle.
title: Trigonometry with general triangles

description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.
title: Intro to radians

description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.
title: Degrees to radians

description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.
title: Radians to degrees

description: Convert angle measures given in degrees to radians and vice versa.
title: Radians & degrees

description: Sal determines the quadrant at which a ray falls after a rotation by a certain measure of radians.
title: Radian angles & quadrants

description: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).
title: Introduction to radians

description: Sal shows how we can extend SOH CAH TOA so that we can define trig functions (sine, cosine, & tangent) for all real numbers.
title: Unit circle definition of trig functions

description: Sal shows how, for acute angles, the two different definitions of the trigonometric values (SOH CAH TOA and the unit circle definition) result in the same values.
title: The trig functions & right triangle trig ratios

description: Learn about the ingenious way in which we define the trigonometric functions for any real number.
title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal draws the graph of the sine function to learn about its domain and range.
title: Graph of y=sin(x)

description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.
title: Graph of y=tan(x)

description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.
title: Intersection points of y=sin(x) and y=cos(x)

description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.
title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.
title: Sine & cosine identities: symmetry

description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for tangent by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.
title: Tangent identities: symmetry

description: Sal finds trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering angle rotations on the unit circle.
title: Sine & cosine identities: periodicity

description: Sal solves a problem by considering the periodicity of the tangent function.
title: Tangent identities: periodicity

description: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.
title: Basic trigonometric identities

description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.
title: Trig values of special angles

description: Find the sine and cosine of special angles, which are angles whose trig values we can determine without the use of a calculator.
title: Trig values of special angles

description: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.
title: Trigonometric values of special angles

description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.
title: Proof of the Pythagorean trig identity

description: Given that sin(θ)=1/2 and that θ is in the third quadrant, Sal finds tan(θ) using the Pythagorean identity.
title: Using the Pythagorean trig identity

description: Given the sine (or cosine) of an angle, find its cosine (or sine) using the Pythagorean identity.
title: Use the Pythagorean identity

description: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.
title: The Pythagorean identity

description: Why Tau might be a better number to look at than Pi
title: Tau versus pi

description: Please excuse the simple math and spelling errors. You shouldn't believe anything I say without double-checking even at the best of times. Go here: http://tauday.com/ and here: http://www.math.utah.edu/~palais/pi.html Me: http://vihart.com
title: Pi is (still) wrong

description: Watch videos by Sal and Vi that discuss the ongoing battle between the more popular Pi (π=3.14..) and its more qualified rival Tau (τ=6.28...).
title: Long live Tau

description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.
title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal draws the graph of the sine function to learn about its domain and range.
title: Graph of y=sin(x)

description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.
title: Graph of y=tan(x)

description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.
title: Intersection points of y=sin(x) and y=cos(x)

description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(θ), y=cos(θ), and y=tan(θ) look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.
title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent

description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.
title: Features of sinusoidal functions

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.
title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.
title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.
title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its midline equation.
title: Midline of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its amplitude.
title: Amplitude of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

description: Given the graph of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.
title: Period of sinusoidal functions from graph

description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function, determine its period.
title: Period of sinusoidal functions from equation

description: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
title: Transforming sinusoidal graphs: vertical stretch & horizontal reflection

description: Sal graphs y=-2.5*cos(1/3*x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and reflection, and a horizontal stretch, of y=cos(x).
