description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx)+d, draw its graph.
title: Graph sinusoidal functions

description: Given the formula of a sinusoidal function of the form a*f(bx+c)+d, draw its graph.
title: Graph sinusoidal functions: phase shift

description: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(πx)-7.
title: Graphing sinusoidal functions

description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.
title: Sinusoidal function from graph

description: Given a few features of a sinusoidal function, find its formula.
title: Construct sinusoidal functions

description: Sal solves a word problem about the daily change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.
title: Trig word problem: modeling daily temperature

description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.
title: Trig word problem: modeling annual temperature

description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it.
title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions

description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in the length of day by modeling it with a sinusoidal function that has a phase shift.
title: Trig word problem: length of day (phase shift)

description: Given the description of a real-world relationship, find the sinusoidal function that models it. The functions in this exercise have a phase (horizontal) shift.
title: Modeling with sinusoidal functions: phase shift

description: Learn how to find the formula of a sinusoidal function from its graph or a few selected features. Model real-world situations with sinusoidal functions.
title: Constructing sinusoidal functions

description: Learn how to graph trigonometric functions and how to interpret those graphs. Learn how to construct trigonometric functions from their graphs or other features.
title: Graphs of trigonometric functions

description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.
title: Intro to arcsine

description: Sal introduces arctangent, which is the inverse function of tangent, and discusses its principal range.
title: Intro to arctangent

description: Sal introduces arccosine, which is the inverse function of cosine, and discusses its principal range.
title: Intro to arccosine

description: Given a sine, cosine, or tangent value, find the principle angle who has this value. In other words, find the arcsine, arccosine, or arctangent of that value.
title: Evaluate inverse trig functions

description: Sal is given the graph of a trigonometric function, and he discusses ways in which he can change the function to make it invertible.
title: Restricting domains of functions to make them invertible

description: Sal find the formula for the inverse function of g(x)=tan(x-3π/2)+6, and then determines the domain of that inverse function.
title: Domain & range of inverse tangent function

description: Sal discusses the appropriate way to use the calculator in order to find an angle when its tangent value is given.
title: Using inverse trig functions with a calculator

description: Learn about the inverse functions of sine, cosine, and tangent, and how they are defined even though the functions are not really invertible. These functions will be very helpful when you will solve trigonometric equations.
title: The inverse trigonometric functions

description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.
title: Solving sinusoidal equations of the form sin(x)=d

description: Sal solves the equations cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1 using the graph of y=cos(θ).
title: Solving cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1

description: Solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number.
title: Solve sinusoidal equations (basic)

description: Learn how to solve equations of the form sin(x)=d or cos(x)=d where d is any number. For example, solve sin(x)=0.6.
title: Solving basic sinusoidal equations

description: Solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number.
title: Solve sinusoidal equations

description: Learn how to solve equations of the form a*sin(bx+c)=d or a*cos(bx+c)=d where a, b, c, and d are any number. For example, solve 5*sin(2x-1)=3.
title: Solving advanced sinusoidal equations

description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.
title: Trig word problem: solving for temperature

description: Solve word problems that involve real-world contexts that are modeled by sinusoidal functions.
title: Sinusoidal models word problems

description: Solve word problems that involve sinusoidal modeling functions.
title: Solving sinusoidal models

description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).
title: Review of trig angle addition identities

description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine angle addition formula.
title: Using the cosine angle addition identity

description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine double-angle formula.
title: Using the cosine double-angle identity

description: Find the trig values of sums of angles whose individual trig values are known.
title: Using the trig angle addition identities

description: Sal proves the identity sin(x+y) = sin(x)*cos(y) + cos(x)*sin(y).
title: Proof of the sine angle addition identity

description: Sal proves the identity cos(x+y) = cos(x)*cos(y) - sin(x)*sin(y).
title: Proof of the cosine angle addition identity

description: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).
title: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities

description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.
title: Finding trig values using angle addition identities

description: Find the trigonometric values of various angles that (while they are not special angles) can be expressed as the sum or difference of special angles.
title: Find trig values using angle addition identities

description: Sal is given a drawing with two triangles and some side lengths, and he uses the sine angle addition identity in order to find a missing side length.
title: Using trig angle addition identities: finding side lengths

description: Sal is given that cos(2θ)=C and he uses the cosine double-angle identity in order to find an expression for sin(θ).
title: Using trig angle addition identities: manipulating expressions

description: Sal rewrites various trigonometric expressions using the Pythagorean identity and other trig identities.
title: Using trigonometric identities

description: Learn about different ways in which trigonometric identities, such as the Pythagorean identity and the angle addition identities, can be used to solve problems.
title: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems

description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 11 in the 2003 AIME II exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: area of a triangle

description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 14 in the 2003 AIME II exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: area of a hexagon

description: Sal is given cos(θ) and cos(φ) and he finds cos(θ+φ). To do that, he must first find sin(θ) and sin(φ) using the Pythagorean identity.
title: Trig challenge problem: cosine of angle-sum

description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 29 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: arithmetic progression

description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 48 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: maximum value

description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 47 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: multiple constraints

description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 55 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.
title: Trig challenge problem: system of equations

description: See Sal solve a bunch of very challenging geometry and algebra problems that involve trigonometry.
title: Challenging trigonometry problems

description: Learn how to solve trigonometric equations and how to use trigonometric identities to solve various problems.
title: Trigonometric equations and identities

description: Big, fancy word, right? Don't be fooled. Looking at the prefix, tri-, you could probably assume that trigonometry ("trig" as it's sometimes called) has something to do with triangles. You would be right! Trig is the study of the properties of triangles. Why is it important? It's used in measuring precise distances, particularly in industries like satellite systems and sciences like astronomy. It's not only space, however. Trig is present in architecture and music, too. Now you may wonder...how is knowing the measurement and properties of triangles relevant to music?? THAT is a great question. Maybe you'll learn the answer from us in these tutorials!
title: Trigonometry

description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.
title: Intro to probability

description: Sal solves an example about subsets.
title: Subsets of sample spaces

description: Answer interesting questions about subsets of sample spaces.
title: Subsets of sample spaces

description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag, we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes and how then many of them meet our constraints.
title: Simple probability: yellow marble

description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.
title: Simple probability: non-blue marble

description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.
title: Simple probability

description:
Can I pick a red frog out of a bag that only contains marbles?  Is it smart to buy a lottery ticket?

Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others).  This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events.
title: Basic probability

description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.
title: Probability with venn diagrams

description: Venn diagrams and the addition rule for probability
title: Addition rule for probability

description: Find four probabilities for each problem: P(A), P(B), P(A and B), and P(A or B).
title: Adding probabilities

description: What is the probability of getting a diamond or an ace from a deck of cards?  Well I could get a diamond that is not an ace, an ace that is not a diamond, or the ace of diamonds.  This tutorial helps us think these types of situations through a bit better (especially with the help of our good friend, the Venn diagram).
title: Venn diagrams and adding probabilities

description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.
title: Compound probability of independent events

description: In this video, we 'll explore the probability of getting at least one heads in multiple flips of a fair coin.
title: Coin flipping probability

description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.
title: Die rolling probability

description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal how to determine the probability of making 10 free throws in a row. Hint: the answer is surprising!
title: Free throwing probability

description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal if there's a high probability of making three free throws in a row or one three-pointer. Before solving the problem, jot down what you think the answer will be!
title: Three pointer vs free throwing probability

description: Up until now, we've looked at probabilities surrounding only equally likely events. What about probabilities when we don't have equally likely events? Say, we have unfair coins?
title: Probability without equally likely events

description: Have you ever taken a test and discovered you have no choice but to guess on a couple of problems? In this example problem, we are considering the probability of two independent events occurring.
title: Independent events example: test taking

description: We hope you're not a gambler, but if you had to bet on whether you can roll even numbers three times in a row, you might want to figure this probability first.
title: Die rolling probability with independent events

description: Find probabilities of independent events like flipping a heads and rolling an even number!
title: Independent probability

description: Practice using sample space diagrams to find probabilities.
title: Probabilities of compound events

description:
What is the probability of making three free throws in a row (LeBron literally asks this in this tutorial).

In this tutorial, we'll explore compound events happening where the probability of one event is not dependent on the outcome of another (compound, independent, events).
title: Compound, independent events

description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.
title: Dependent probability introduction

description: We're thinking about how the probability of an event can be dependent on another event occuring in this example problem.
title: Dependent probability: coins

description: It's important to practice these probability problems as they get more complex eventually. Take a stab on this one...with our help, of course.
title: Dependent probability example

description: This time around we're not going to tell you whether we're working on a dependent or independent probability event problem. You tell us!
title: Independent & dependent probability

description: Sal uses an example about shirts, scarves, hats, and pants to explain how to use probabilities to figure out if two events are independent.
title: Analyzing event probability for independence

description: Determine if two events are dependent or independent.
title: Dependent and independent events

description: Find dependent probabilities like P(A | B) or P(B | A) for a variety of contexts.
title: Dependent probability

description: Sal finds dependent probabilities like P(A | B) using an example rolling die.
title: Dependent probability

description: Sal solves a conditional probability example where he thinks about probabilities like P(A | B) where the events are about lunch and breakfast!
title: Calculating conditional probability

description: Use properties of dependent probability like P(A | B) * P(B) = P(A and B) to solve some tricky probability problems!
title: Multiplying dependent probabilities

description: Here we have a presentation and analysis of the famous thought experiment: the "Monty Hall" problem! This is fun.
title: The Monty Hall problem

description: What's the probability of picking two "e" from the bag in scrabble (assuming that I don't replace the tiles).  Well, the probability of picking an 'e' on your second try depends on what happened in the first (if you picked an 'e' the first time around, then there is one less 'e' in the bag).  This is just one of many, many type of scenarios involving dependent probability.
title: Dependent probability

description: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?").  But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in?  What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car?  Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates.  Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7?  Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.

description: Is this some kind of cute cat video? No! Box and whisker plots seek to explain data by showing a spread of all the data points in a sample. The "whiskers" are the two opposite ends of the data. This video is more fun than a handful of catnip.

description:
The normal distribution (often referred to as the "bell curve" is at the core of most of inferential statistics.  By assuming that most complex processes result in a normal distribution (we'll see why this is reasonable), we can gauge the probability of it happening by chance.

To best enjoy this tutorial, it is good to come to it understanding what probability distributions and random variables are.  You should also be very familiar with the notions of population and sample mean and standard deviation.
title: Normal distribution

description:
In this tutorial, we experience one of the most exciting ideas in statistics--the central limit theorem.  Without it, it would be a lot harder to make any inferences about population parameters given sample statistics.  It tells us that, regardless of what the population distribution looks like, the  distribution of the sample means (you'll learn what that is) can be normal.

Good idea to understand a bit about normal distributions before diving into this tutorial.
title: Sampling distribution

description: Estimating the probability that the true population mean lies within a range around a sample mean.
title: Confidence interval 1

description: Sal calculates a 99% confidence interval for the proportion of teachers who felt computers are an essential tool.
title: Confidence interval example

description: Constructing small sample size confidence intervals using t-distributions
title: Small sample size confidence intervals

description:
We all have confidence intervals ("I'm the king of the world!!!!") and non-confidence intervals ("No one loves me").  That is not what this tutorial is about.

This tutorial takes what you already know about the central limit theorem, sampling distributions, and z-scores and uses these tools to dive into the world of inferential statistics.  It may seem magical at first, but from our sample, we can now make inferences about the probability of our population mean actually being in an interval.
title: Confidence intervals

description: Sal calculates the mean and variance of a Bernoulli distribution (in this example the responses are either favorable or unfavorable).
title: Mean and variance of Bernoulli distribution example

description: Sal continues on from the previous video to derive the mean and variance formulas for the Bernoulli distribution.
title: Bernoulli distribution mean and variance formulas

description: Finding the 95% confidence interval for the proportion of a population voting for a candidate.
title: Margin of error 1

description: Finding the 95% confidence interval for the proportion of a population voting for a candidate.
title: Margin of error 2

description: Ever wondered what pollsters are talking about when they said that there is a 3% "margin of error" in their results.  Well, this tutorial will not only explain what it means, but give you the tools and understanding to be a pollster yourself!
title: Bernoulli distributions and margin of error

description: Sal walks through an example about a neurologist testing the effect of a drug to discuss hypothesis testing and p-values.
title: Hypothesis testing and p-values

description: Sal continues his discussion of the effect of a drug to one-tailed and two-tailed hypothesis tests.
title: One-tailed and two-tailed tests

description: Sal gives the definition of type 1 error and builds some intuition behind it.
title: Type 1 errors

description: Sal breaks down the difference between Z-statistics and T-statistics.
title: Z-statistics vs. T-statistics

description: Sal walks through an example of a hypothesis test where he determines if there is sufficient evidence to conclude that a new type of engine meets emission requirements.
title: Small sample hypothesis test

description: Sal computes a confidence interval for the emission from an engine with a new design.
title: T-statistic confidence interval

description: Sal uses a large sample to test if more than 30% of US households have internet access.
title: Large sample proportion hypothesis testing

description:
This tutorial helps us answer one of the most important questions not only in statistics, but all of science:  how confident are we that a result from a new drug or process is not due to random chance but due to an actual impact.

If you are familiar with sampling distributions and confidence intervals, you're ready for this adventure!
title: Hypothesis testing with one sample

description: Sal derives the variance of the difference of random variables
title: Variance of differences of random variables

description: Sal walks through the difference of sample means distribution.
title: Difference of sample means distribution

description: Sal uses a confidence interval to help figure out if a low-fat diet helps obese people lose weight.
title: Confidence interval of difference of means

description: Clarification of Confidence Interval of Difference of Means
title: Clarification of confidence interval of difference of means

description: Hypothesis Test for Difference of Means
title: Hypothesis test for difference of means

description: Sal uses an election example to compare population proportions.
title: Comparing population proportions 1

description: Sal continues the election example for population proportions.
title: Comparing population proportions 2

description: Once again, Sal continues the discussion of election results to run a hypothesis test comparing population proportions.
title: Hypothesis test comparing population proportions

description: You're already familiar with hypothesis testing with one sample.  In this tutorial, we'll go further by testing whether the difference between the means of two samples seems to be unlikely purely due to chance.
title: Hypothesis testing with two samples

description: Chi-Square Distribution Introduction
title: Chi-square distribution introduction

description: Sal uses the chi square test to the hypothesis that the owner's distribution is correct.
title: Pearson's chi square test (goodness of fit)

description: Sal uses the contingency table chi-square test to see if a couple of different herbs prevent people from getting sick.
title: Contingency table chi-square test

description: You've gotten good at hypothesis testing when you can make assumptions about the underlying distributions.  In this tutorial, we'll learn about a new distribution (the chi-square one) and how it can help you (yes, you) infer what an underlying distribution even is!
title: Chi-square probability distribution

description: Analysis of Variance 1 - Calculating SST (Total Sum of Squares)
title: ANOVA 1: Calculating SST (total sum of squares)

description: Analysis of Variance 2 - Calculating SSW and SSB (Total Sum of Squares Within and Between)
title: ANOVA 2: Calculating SSW and SSB (total sum of squares within and between)

description: Analysis of Variance 3 -Hypothesis Test with F-Statistic
title: ANOVA 3: Hypothesis test with F-statistic

description: You already know a good bit about hypothesis testing with one or two samples.  Now we take things further by making inferences based on three or more samples.  We'll use the very special F-distribution to do it (F stands for "fabulous").
title: Analysis of variance

description: Making inferences based on sample data.  Confidence intervals.  Margin of error.  Hypothesis testing.
title: Inferential statistics

description: We dare you to go through a day in which you never consider or use probability. Did you check the weather forecast? Busted! Did you decide to go through the drive through lane vs walk in? Busted again! We are constantly creating hypotheses, making predictions, testing, and analyzing. Our lives are full of probabilities! Statistics is related to probability because much of the data we use when determining probable outcomes comes from our understanding of statistics. In these tutorials, we will cover a range of topics, some which include: independent events, dependent probability, combinatorics, hypothesis testing, descriptive statistics, random variables, probability distributions, regression, and inferential statistics. So buckle up and hop on for a wild ride. We bet you're going to be challenged AND love it!
title: Probability and statistics

description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine angle addition formula.

description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine double-angle formula.
title: Using the cosine double-angle identity

description: Find the trig values of sums of angles whose individual trig values are known.

description: Sal proves the identity sin(x+y) = sin(x)*cos(y) + cos(x)*sin(y).

description: Sal proves the identity cos(x+y) = cos(x)*cos(y) - sin(x)*sin(y).

description: Learn about the trigonometric angle addition identities, which help us discuss the trig values of sums of angles in terms of the trig values of the individual angles. For example, we can express sin(x+y) in terms of sin(x), sin(y), cos(x), and cos(y).

description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

description: Find the trigonometric values of various angles that (while they are not special angles) can be expressed as the sum or difference of special angles.

description: Sal is given a drawing with two triangles and some side lengths, and he uses the sine angle addition identity in order to find a missing side length.

description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

description: Sal solves a problem where he has to determine whether unknown matrices are zero or identity to make an equation true.
title: Using identity & zero matrices

description: Learn about identity matrices and about how matrix multiplication relates to real number multiplication (spoiler: the distributive property applies but the commutative property does not!).
title: Properties of matrix multiplication

description: Sal transforms a 2-dimensional vector using a 2x2 matrix, and draws the original vector and its image on the plane.
title: Transforming vectors using matrices

description: Find the result (both algebraically and graphically) of transforming a vector using a transformation matrix.
title: Transform vectors using matrices

description: Sal transforms a triangle using a 2x2 matrix.
title: Transforming polygons using matrices

description: Find the image of a given polygon under a transformation defined by a given matrix.
title: Transform polygons using matrices

description: Sal finds the drawing that appropriately represents the effect of a given 2x2 transformation matrix on the plane.
title: Visual representation of transformation from matrix

description: Match transformation matrices with a visual representation of their effect on the plane.
title: Matrices as transformations

description: Learn how matrices can be used as transformations of vectors or transformations of the plane.
title: Matrices as transformations

description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.
title: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix

description: Find the determinant of a given 2x2 matrix.
title: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix

description: Learn what the determinant of a matrix is and how to find it for 2x2 matrices.
title: The determinant of a 2x2 matrix

description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.
title: Intro to matrix inverses

description: Given a pair of matrices, determine whether they are inverses of each other.
title: Determine inverse matrices

description: Sal shows why a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is not 0.
title: Determining invertible matrices

description: Given a 2x2 matrix, determine whether it has an inverse.
title: Determine invertibile matrices

description: Learn what the inverse of a matrix is, and how to determine whether two matrices are inverses or whether a matrix is invertible.
title: Introduction to matrix inverses

description: Sal gives an example of how to find the inverse of a given 2x2 matrix.
title: Finding inverse of a 2x2 matrix using determinant & adjugate

description: Learn about a way to find the inverse of a matrix using its determinant and adjuagates.
title: Finding the inverse of a matrix using its determinant

description: Find the inverse matrix of a given 2x2 matrix.
title: Find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix

description: After you've learned how to find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, gain some practice with it.
title: Practice finding the inverses of 2x2 matrices

description: Sal shows the standard method for finding the determinant of a 3x3 matrix.
title: Determinant of a 3x3 matrix: standard method (1 of 2)

description: Sal shows a "shortcut" method for finding the determinant of a 3x3 matrix.
title: Determinant of a 3x3 matrix: shortcut method (2 of 2)

description: Find the determinant of a given 3x3 matrix.
title: Determinant of a 3x3 matrix

description: Sal explains how we can find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix using Gaussian elimination.
title: Inverting a 3x3 matrix using Gaussian elimination

description: Sal shows how to find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix using its determinant. In Part 1 we learn how to find the matrix of minors of a 3x3 matrix and its cofactor matrix.
title: Inverting a 3x3 matrix using determinants Part 1: Matrix of minors and cofactor matrix

description: Sal shows how to find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix using its determinant. In Part 2 we complete the process by finding the determinant of the matrix and its adjugate matrix.
title: Inverting a 3x3 matrix using determinants Part 2: Adjugate matrix

description: Find the inverse of a given 3x3 matrix.
title: Inverse of a 3x3 matrix

description: Learn how to find the determinants and the inverses of matrices with dimensions 3x3 or larger.
title: Determinants and inverses of large matrices

description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.
title: Representing linear systems with matrix equations

description: Represent systems of two linear equations with matrix equations by determining A and b in the matrix equation A*x=b.
title: Represent linear systems with matrix equations

description: After he represented a system of equations with a single matrix equation, Sal solves that matrix equation using the inverse of the coefficient matrix.
title: Solving linear systems with matrix equations

description: Sal finds the appropriate combination of two given vectors in order to obtain a third given vector. This is done by representing the problem with a single matrix equation and solving that equation.
title: Matrix word problem: vector combination

description: Learn how to solve systems of linear equations using inverse matrices, and how to solve matrix equations using inverse matrices.
title: Solving equations with inverse matrices

description: Sal shows how matrices can be used to efficiently represent data about the prices of toilet paper and toothpaste in two different cities.
title: Matrix word problem: prices

description: Learn how matrices can be used to describe real-world situations.
title: Model real-world situations with matrices

description: Learn what matrices are and about their various uses: solving systems of equations, transforming shapes and vectors, and representing real-world situations. Learn how to add, subtract, and multiply matrices, and find the inverses of matrices.
title: Matrices

description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.
title: Intro to the imaginary numbers

description: Sal gives several examples of how we simplify high powers of i. For instance, i^100=1.
title: Powers of the imaginary unit

description: Simplify expressions with base i (the imaginary unit) raised to a positive exponent.
title: Powers of the imaginary unit

description: Sal simplifies √(-52) as 2i√(52).
title: Simplifying roots of negative numbers

description: Rewrite square roots of negative numbers as imaginary numbers.
title: Simplify roots of negative numbers

description: The formal definition of i is i^2=-1 and not √-1=i, and there's a good reason for this (although it's a bit technical). See Sal explain why.
title: i as the principal root of -1

description: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).
title: What are the imaginary numbers?

description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.
title: Intro to complex numbers

description: Determine the real and the imaginary parts of complex numbers
title: Parts of complex numbers

description: Sal first simplifies complex expressions, and then explains how to classify numbers as real, pure imaginary, or complex.
title: How to classify complex numbers (example)

description: Classify numbers as real, pure imaginary, or complex.
title: Classify complex numbers

description: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).
title: What are the complex numbers?

description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.
title: Plotting numbers on the complex plane

description: Given a complex number, plot its corresponding point on the complex plane.
title: Plot numbers on the complex plane

description: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!
title: The complex plane

description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
title: Adding complex numbers

description: Sal subtracts (6-18i) from (2-3i).
title: Subtracting complex numbers

description: Practice addition and subtraction with complex numbers.
title: Add & subtract complex numbers

description: Add or subtract complex numbers, and plot the result in the complex plane.
title: Graphically add & subtract complex numbers

description: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).
title: Adding and subtracting complex numbers

description: Multiply complex numbers by single terms that are either real or pure imaginary.
title: Multiply complex numbers (basic)

description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
title: Multiplying complex numbers

description: Given two complex numbers, find their product.
title: Multiply complex numbers

description: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).
title: Multiplying complex numbers

description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.
title: Intro to complex number conjugates

description: Sal finds the conjugate of (7-5i).
title: Complex number conjugates

description: Given a complex number, find its conjugate or plot it in the complex plane.
title: Complex number conjugates

description: Sal divides (6+3i) by (7-5i).
title: Dividing complex numbers

description: Given a complex number division, express the result as a complex number of the form a+bi.
title: Divide complex numbers

description: Learn how to divide complex numbers using the conjugate of the divisor. For example, divide (2+3i) by (-1+4i) by multiplying both the dividend and the divisor by (-1-4i).
title: Complex conjugates and dividing complex numbers

description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).
title: Absolute value of complex numbers

description: Given a complex number in the form a+bi, find its absolute value.
title: Absolute value of complex numbers

description: Sal finds the modulus (which is the absolute value) and the argument (which is the angle) of √3/2+1/2*i.
title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers

description: Given a complex number of the form a+bi, find its angle.
title: Angle of complex numbers

description: Given the absolute value and the angle of a complex number, express the number in the form a+bi.
title: Complex numbers from absolute value & angle

description: Learn about very important graphical features of complex numbers: their absolute value and their angle.
title: Absolute value and angle of complex numbers

description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.
title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers

description: Given two complex numbers (either algebraically or graphically), find their distance.
title: Distance of complex numbers

description: Given two complex numbers (either algebraically or graphically), find their midpoint.
title: Midpoint of complex numbers

description: Learn how we define the distance of two complex numbers, and how we define their midpoint.
title: Distance and midpoint of complex numbers

description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.
title: Polar & rectangular forms of complex numbers

description: Given a complex number in rectangular form, write it in polar form. Given a complex number in polar form, write it in rectangular form.
title: Polar & rectangular forms of complex numbers

description: Learn how to represent complex numbers in a different way. Unlike rectangular form, which emphasizes the real and imaginary parts, polar form emphasizes the absolute value ("modulus") and the angle ("argument").
title: Polar form of complex numbers

description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.
title: Dividing complex numbers: polar & exponential form

description: Given two complex numbers in polar form, find their product or quotient.
title: Multiply & divide complex numbers in polar form

description: Sal simplifies the 20th power of a complex number given in polar form.
title: Powers of complex numbers

description: Sal finds all complex solutions to the equation x^3=1.
title: Complex number equations: x³=1

description: Simplify a power of a complex number z^n, or solve an equation of the form z^n=k.
title: Powers of complex numbers

description: Learn how complex multiplication and division work when the numbers are given in polar form. Amazingly enough, this is much easier then multiplication and division in rectangular form.
title: Multiplying and dividing complex numbers in polar form

description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about complex numbers.
title: Challenging complex numbers problem (1 of 3)

description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about complex numbers.
title: Challenging complex numbers problem (2 of 3)

description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about complex numbers.
title: Challenging complex numbers problem (3 of 3)

description: Paper 1 Problem 53 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about determinant of a complex numbers matrix.
title: Challenging complex numbers problem: complex determinant

description: This tutorial goes through a fancy problem from the IIT JEE exam in India (competitive exam for getting into their top engineering schools).  Whether or not you live in India, this is a good example to test whether you are a complex number rock star.
title: Challenging complex number problems

description: Understanding i and the complex plane
title: Imaginary and complex numbers

description: Sal gives an example of a situation where parametric equations are very useful: driving off a cliff!
title: Intro to parametric equations

description: Sal starts with parametric equations that give x and y as functions of t, and he manipulates the equations to get y as a function of x.
title: Removing the parameter in parametric equations

description: Sal is given x=3cost and y=2sint and he finds an equation that gives the relationship between x and y (spoiler: it's an ellipse!).
title: Removing the parameter in parametric equations (example 2)

description: Sal shows how different parametric equations can result in the same relationship between x and y (and therefore with the same graph).
title: Parametric equations with the same graph

description: Here we will explore representing our x's and y's in terms of a third variable or parameter (often 't').  Not only can we describe new things, but it can be super useful for describing things like particle motion in physics.
title: Parametric equations

description: Introduction to polar coordinates
title: Polar coordinates 1

description: Conversion from Cartesian to Polar Coordinates
title: Polar coordinates 2

description: Converting between Cartesian and Polar functions
title: Polar coordinates 3

description: Feel that Cartesian coordinates are too "square".  That they bias us towards lines and away from cool spirally things.  Well polar coordinates be just what you need!
title: Polar coordinates

description: An alternative to Cartesian coordinates.
title: Parametric equations and polar coordinates

description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.
title: Intro to probability

description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag, we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes and how then many of them meet our constraints.
title: Simple probability: yellow marble

description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.
title: Simple probability: non-blue marble

description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.
title: Simple probability

description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.
title: Probability with venn diagrams

description: Venn diagrams and the addition rule for probability
title: Addition rule for probability

description: What is the probability of getting a diamond or an ace from a deck of cards?  Well I could get a diamond that is not an ace, an ace that is not a diamond, or the ace of diamonds.  This tutorial helps us think these types of situations through a bit better (especially with the help of our good friend, the Venn diagram).
title: Venn diagrams and the addition rule

description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.
title: Die rolling probability

description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.
title: Probability with counting outcomes

description: Sal figures out the probability of flipping three coins and getting at least two tails.
title: Compound events example with tree diagram

description: Sal uses a diagram to find the probability of rolling a four-sided die and a six-sided die and not getting a 1.
title: Compound events example using diagram

description: Practice using sample space diagrams to find probabilities.
title: Probabilities of compound events

description:
What is the probability of making three free throws in a row (LeBron literally asks this in this tutorial).

In this tutorial, we'll explore compound events happening where the probability of one event is not dependent on the outcome of another (compound, independent, events).
title: Compound probability of independent events using diagrams

description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.
title: Compound probability of independent events

description: Up until now, we've looked at probabilities surrounding only equally likely events. What about probabilities when we don't have equally likely events? Say, we have unfair coins?
title: Probability without equally likely events

description: Have you ever taken a test and discovered you have no choice but to guess on a couple of problems? In this example problem, we are considering the probability of two independent events occurring.
title: Independent events example: test taking

description: We hope you're not a gambler, but if you had to bet on whether you can roll even numbers three times in a row, you might want to figure this probability first.
title: Die rolling probability with independent events

description: In this video, we 'll explore the probability of getting at least one heads in multiple flips of a fair coin.
title: Coin flipping probability

description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal how to determine the probability of making 10 free throws in a row. Hint: the answer is surprising!
title: Free throwing probability

description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal if there's a high probability of making three free throws in a row or one three-pointer. Before solving the problem, jot down what you think the answer will be!
title: Three pointer vs free throwing probability

description: Find probabilities of independent events like flipping a heads and rolling an even number!
title: Independent probability

description: See how we can use the multiplication rule to find the compound probability of independent events.
title: Compound probability of independent events using the multiplication rule

description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.
title: Dependent probability introduction

description: We're thinking about how the probability of an event can be dependent on another event occuring in this example problem.
title: Dependent probability: coins

description: It's important to practice these probability problems as they get more complex eventually. Take a stab on this one...with our help, of course.
title: Dependent probability example

description: This time around we're not going to tell you whether we're working on a dependent or independent probability event problem. You tell us!
title: Independent & dependent probability

description: Find dependent probabilities like P(A | B) or P(B | A) for a variety of contexts.
title: Dependent probability

description: Here we have a presentation and analysis of the famous thought experiment: the "Monty Hall" problem! This is fun.
title: The Monty Hall problem

description: Conditional probability visualized using trees.
title: Conditional probability with Bayes Theorem

description: What's the probability of picking two "e" from the bag in scrabble (assuming that I don't replace the tiles).  Well, the probability of picking an 'e' on your second try depends on what happened in the first (if you picked an 'e' the first time around, then there is one less 'e' in the bag).  This is just one of many, many type of scenarios involving dependent probability.
title: Dependent events

description: Sal explains a tricky factorial problem about counting seat arrangements.
title: Factorial and counting seat arrangements

description: Sal explains the permutation formula and how to use it.
title: Permutation formula

description: Sal explains how to find all of the possible three letter words when we can use each letter as many times as we want, and when each letter can only be used once.
title: Possible three letter words

description: Sal explains the intuition behind zero factorial.
title: Zero factorial or  0!

description: Thinking about how many ways you can pick four colors from a group of 6
title: Ways to arrange colors

description: How many ways can we pick officers for our organization?
title: Ways to pick officers

description: Introductory permutation problems.
title: Permutations

description: You want to display your Chuck Norris dolls on your desk at school and there is only room for five of them.  Unfortunately, you own 50.  How many ways can you pick the dolls and arrange them on your desk?
title: Permutations

description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.
title: Intro to combinations

description: Sal explains the combination formula.
title: Combination formula

description: Sal figures out how different combinations of people can shake hands.
title: Handshaking combinations

description: Thinking about how many ways we can construct a hand of 9 cards
title: Combination example: 9 card hands

description: Introductory combination problems like if you have 5 friends and can pick 2 of them to join you on a boat ride, how many different groups of friends could you take with you?
title: Combinations

description: Permutations and Combinations with overcounting
title: Permutations & combinations

description: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?").  But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in?  What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car?  Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates.  Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7?  Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.
title: Combinations

description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.
title: Probability using combinations

description: Making at least 3 out of 5 free throws.
title: Probability & combinations (2 of 2)

description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.
title: Probability with counting outcomes

description: A different way to think about the probability of getting 2 heads in 4 flips
title: Getting exactly two heads (combinatorics)

description: Probability of exactly 3 heads in 5 flips using combinations
title: Exactly three heads in five flips

description: Conceptual understanding of where the formula for binomial coefficients come from
title: Generalizing with binomial coefficients (bit advanced)

description: Thinking about the different ways we can pick officers in order to find the probability of one situation in particular.
title: Example:  Different ways to pick officers

description: Probability of getting a set of cards
title: Example: Combinatorics and probability

description: What is the probability of winning a 4-number lottery?
title: Example:  Lottery probability

description: Probability questions using permutations and combinations of objects
title: Probability with permutations and combinations

description: Probability of winning the Mega Millions jackpot
title: Mega millions jackpot probability

description: The probability that at least 2 people in a room of 30 share the same birthday.
title: Birthday probability problem

description: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability.  You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than poring all your money into the Powerball Lottery.
title: Probability using combinatorics

description: Basics of probability and combinatorics
title: Probability and combinatorics

description: Sal explains sequences and gives examples of different sequences, defined either explicitly or recursively.
title: Intro to sequences

description: Sal introduces arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. He gives various examples of such sequences, defined explicitly and recursively.
title: Intro to arithmetic sequences

description: Find the recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Given the formula of an arithmetic sequence, ether in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use arithmetic sequence formulas

description: Given the first few terms in an arithmetic sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend arithmetic sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in an arithmetic sequence are 12, 5, -2, and -9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Sal finds the equation that describes a growth pattern of shapes made of squares.
title: Sequences word problem: growth pattern

description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.
title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences

description: Review arithmetic sequences before you dive into arithmetic series.
title: Arithmetic sequences

description: The standard notation for writing long sums.
title: Sigma notation for sums

description: Evaluate expressions that use sigma notation to make sure you understand what sigma notation means.
title: Sigma notation

description: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!
title: Basic sigma notation

description: Sal explains the formula for the sum of a finite arithmetic series
title: Intro to finite arithmetic series

description: Practice figuring out the sum of finite arithmetic series
title: Finite arithmetic series

description: Watch Sal prove the expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n.
title: Proof of finite arithmetic series formula

description: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.
title: Finite arithmetic series

description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.
title: Intro to geometric sequences

description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and gives a few examples. Notation used in this video is relatively advanced.
title: Intro to geometric sequences (advanced)

description: Given the first few terms in a geometric sequence, find the next term in the sequence.
title: Extend geometric sequences

description: Given the formula of a geometric sequence, either in explicit form or in recursive form, find a specific term in the sequence.
title: Use geometric sequence formulas

description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.
title: Explicit & recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Solve problems such as: The first four terms in a geometric sequence are 1/3, 1, 3, and 9. Find an explicit formula for the sequence.
title: Explicit formulas for geometric sequences

description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.
title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of geometric sequences

description: Find the recursive formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms or given an explicit formula.
title: Recursive formulas for geometric sequences

description: Given a verbal description of a real-world relationship, determine the sequence that models that relationship.
title: Sequences word problems

description: Review geometric sequences before you dive into geometric series.
title: Geometric sequences

description: Think about a geometric series as the sum of a geometric sequence.
title: Intro to geometric series

description: Sal extends the idea of geometric sequences to geometric series
title: Geometric series with sigma notation

description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series
title: Finite geometric series

description: Evaluate finite geometric series given in sigma notation, recursively, or explicitly.
title: Finite geometric series

description: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!
title: Finite geometric series

description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.
title: Finite geometric series word problem: social media

description: Figuring out the formula for fixed mortgage payments using the sum of a geometric series
title: Finite geometric series word problem: mortgage

description: Understanding and solving problems with the formula for a finite geometric series
title: Finite geometric series word problems

description: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.
title: Finite geometric series applications

description: Practice writing finite arithmetic series like 6 + 10 + 14 in sigma notation.
title: Finite arithmetic series in sigma notation

description: Practice writing finite geometric series like 3 + 6 + 12 + 24 in sigma notation.
title: Finite geometric series in sigma notation

description: Watch Sal use the properties of sigma notation to make a difficult problem easy!
title: Sigma notation properties

description: Test yourself on some tricky properties of sigma notation.
title: Sigma notation properties (advanced)

description: Now that you know basic sigma notation and series, we can put the two together to write series using sigma notation and evaluate more challenging expressions.
title: Advanced sigma notation

description: Sal uses a clever algebraic manipulation to find an expression for the sum of an infinite geometric series.
title: Infinite geometric series

description: Sal applies limits to the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series to get the sum of an infinite geometric series.
title: Infinite geometric series as a limit

description: Sal looks at examples of three infinite geometric series and determines if each of them converges or diverges
title: Convergent & divergent geometric series

description: Given an infinite geometric series, can you determine if it converges or diverges?
title: Convergent & divergent geometric series

description: Find the sum of an infinite geometric series, but only if it converges!
title: Infinite geometric series

description: You're already familiar with finite geometric series, but you don't want the summation to stop!!  What happens if you keep adding?  The terms are getting small fast!  Can it be that the sum of an infinite number of rapidly shrinking terms can be finite!  Yes, often times it can!  Mind-blowing!  Stupendous!
title: Infinite geometric series

description: Watch Sal determine the total vertical distance a bouncing ball moves using an infinite geometric series.
title: Infinite geometric series word problem: bouncing ball

description: See how we can write a repeating decimal as an infinite geometric series.
title: Infinite geometric series word problem: repeating decimal

description: Apply what you've learned about infinite geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.
title: Infinite geometric series applications

description: Sal discusses the difference between inductive and deductive reasoning by considering a word problem.
title: Inductive & deductive reasoning

description: Sal analyzes a solution of a mathematical problem to determine whether it uses deductive reasoning.
title: Deductive reasoning

description: Sal uses deductive reasoning to prove an algebraic identity.
title: Using deductive reasoning

description: Sal analyzes a solution of a mathematical problem to determine whether it uses inductive reasoning.
title: Inductive reasoning

description: Sal analyzes a solution of a mathematical problem to determine whether it uses inductive reasoning.
title: Inductive reasoning (example 2)

description: Sal uses inductive reasoning to find an expression for the nth number in the sequence 6, 9, 12, 15,....
title: Using inductive reasoning

description: Sal uses inductive reasoning in order to find the 50th element of a pattern toothpick shapes.
title: Using inductive reasoning (example 2)

description: You will hear the words "deductive reasoning" and "inductive reasoning" throughout your life.  This very optional tutorial will give you context for what these mean.
title: Deductive and inductive reasoning

description: Proving an expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n by induction
title: Proof of finite arithmetic series formula by induction

description: Proof by induction is a core tool.  This tutorial walks you through the general idea that if 1) something is true for a base case (say when n=1) and 2) if it is true for n, then it is also true for n+1, then it must be true for all n!  Amazing!
title: Induction

description: An assortment of concepts in math that help us deal with sequences and proofs.
title: Sequences, series and induction

description: Sal explains what partial fraction expansion is by rewriting (x²-2x-37)/(x²-3x-40) as the sum of 1 and two rational expressions with linear denominators.
title: Intro to partial fraction expansion

description: Sal performs partial fraction expansion upon (10x²+12x+20)/(x³-8).
title: Partial fraction expansion

description: Sal performs partial fraction expansion upon (6x²-19x+15)/(x-1)(x-2)².
title: Partial fraction expansion: repeated factors

description: Represent a complicated rational fraction as a sum of simpler fractions using partial fraction expansion.
title: Partial fraction expansion

description: Learn how to rewrite a complex rational expression as the sum of more simple expressions.
title: Partial fraction expansion

description: What are limits?
title: Intro to limits

description: Introduction to the intuition behind limits
title: Limits intuition

description:
Limits are the core tool that we build upon for calculus.  Many times, a function can be undefined at a point, but we can think about what the function "approaches" as it gets closer and closer to that point (this is the "limit").  Other times, the function may be defined at a point, but it may approach a different limit.  There are many, many times where the function value is the same as the limit at a point.  Either way, this is a powerful tool as we start thinking about slope of a tangent line to a curve.

If you have a decent background in algebra (graphing and functions in particular), you'll hopefully enjoy this tutorial!

description: You may think that precalculus is simply the course you take before calculus. You would be right, of course, but that definition doesn't mean anything unless you have some knowledge of what calculus is. Let's keep it simple, shall we? Calculus is a conceptual framework which provides systematic techniques for solving problems. These problems are appropriately applicable to analytic geometry and algebra. Therefore....precalculus gives you the background for the mathematical concepts, problems, issues and techniques that appear in calculus, including trigonometry, functions, complex numbers, vectors, matrices, and others. There you have it ladies and gentlemen....an introduction to precalculus!
title: Precalculus

description: Much of calculus deals with the idea of infinity.  You will commonly hear people speaking about something "infinitely small", for example.  Limits are the tool underlying all calculus which let us talk sensibly about infinity.  In particular, they give us the language to talk about being "infinitely close" to some number by considering what happens as you approach that number.

description:
If a function is always smaller than one function and always greater than another (i.e. it is always between them), then if the upper and lower function converge to a limit at a point, then so does the one in between.  Not only is this useful for proving certain tricky limits (we use it to prove lim (x → 0) of (sin x)/x, but it is a useful metaphor to use in life (seriously). :)

This tutorial is useful but optional.  It is covered in most calculus courses, but it is not necessary to progress on to the "Introduction to derivatives" tutorial.
title: Squeeze theorem

description:
This tutorial introduces a "formal" definition of limits.  So put on your ball gown and/or tuxedo to party with Mr. Epsilon Delta (no, this is not referring to a fraternity).

This tends to be covered early in a traditional calculus class (right after basic limits), but we have mixed feelings about that.  It is cool and rigorous, but also very "mathy" (as most rigorous things are).  Don't fret if you have trouble with it the first time.  If you have a basic conceptual understanding of what limits are (from the "Limits" tutorial), you're ready to start thinking about taking derivatives.
title: Epsilon delta definition of limits

description: Why we study differential calculus.
title: Newton, Leibniz, and Usain Bolt

description: The topic that is now known as "calculus" was really called "the calculus of differentials" when first devised by Newton (and Leibniz) roughly four hundred years ago.  To Newton, differentials were infinitely small "changes" in numbers that previous mathematics didn't know what to do with.  Think this has no relevence to you?  Well how would you figure out how fast something is going *right* at this moment (you'd have to figure out the very, very small change in distance over an infinitely small change in time)?  This tutorial gives a gentle introduction to the world of Newton and Leibniz.
title: Introduction to differential calculus

description:
One of the reasons calculus was invented was to be able to optimize functions.  When you have some function modeling a real world situation, you often want to find its maximum or minimum.

In this tutorial, you will see how information about the derivative of a function can give powerful ways to mathematically describe the "shape" of a function.

description:
When you're looking for the maximum or minimum of a function, a good way to start is by finding points where the derivative equals zero.  However, you won't always get the maximum possible value of the function; you might just end up with a point which is maximum *relative* to those points around it. 

In this tutorial, you will learn about the extreme value theorem, and what it tells us about relative maxima and minima.
title: Absolute and relative maxima and minima

title: Applications of differentiation in biology, economics, physics, etc.

description: So, you've probably been told that calculus is useful, but this fact can be hard to believe and remember when you're deep in the weeds of a particularly nasty derivative.  In this tutorial, we begin to just scratch the surface as we apply derivatives in fields as disperse as biology and economics.
title: Applying differentiation in different fields

description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?
title: Rates of change between radius and area of circle

description: In this example, you are analying the rate of change of a ballon's altitude based on the angle you have to crane your neck to look at it.
title: Related rates: Balloon example

description: As you pour water into a cone, how does the rate of change of the depth of the water relate to the rate of change in volume.
title: Related rates: water pouring into a cone

description: You're on a ladder.  The bottom of the ladder starts slipping away from the wall.  Amidst your fright, you realize this would make a great related rates problem...
title: Related rates: Falling ladder

description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?
title: Related rates: Approaching cars

description: And owl, his shadow, the mouse he's hunting, and more related rates practice.
title: Related rates: Shadow of a bird

description:
Have you ever wondered how fast the area of a ripple of a pond is increasing based on how fast the ripple is?  What about how fast a volcano's volume is increasing?  This tutorial on related rates will satiate your curiosity and then some!


Solving related rates problems using calculus
title: Related rates

description: The mean value theorem tells us when certain values for the derivative must exist.
title: Mean value theorem

description: See what the mean value theorem looks like in practice.
title: Example of the mean value theorem

description: Even if a cop never spots you while you are speeding, he can still infer when you must have been speeding...
title: Getting a ticket because of the mean value theorem

description: In this example, we find the maximum possible value of a function based on a contraint put on its derivative.
title: Maximizing function at value

description: Practice using the mean value theorem.
title: Mean value theorem

description: Intuition behind the Mean Value Theorem
title: Mean value theorem

description: If over the last hour on the highway, you averaged 60 miles per hour, then you must have been going exactly 60 miles per hour at some point.  This is the gist of the mean value theorem (which generalizes the idea for any continuous, differentiable function).
title: Mean value theorem

description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or infinty/infinity, L'Hopistal's rule is the tool you need.
title: Introduction to l'Hôpital's rule

title: L'Hôpital's rule example 1

description: L'Hôpital's Rule Example 2
title: L'Hôpital's rule example 2

description: L'Hôpital's Rule Example 3
title: L'Hôpital's rule example 3

description: Unlike previous example, we now have a variable inside a limit which we can tweak, and we are trying to make the limit equal a specific value.
title: L'Hopital's Rule to solve for variable

description: L'Hopital's rule can apply to situation which don't look like 0/0 or infinity/infinity, if you are clever enough.
title: Tricky L'Hopital's Rule problem

description: Practice using L'Hopital's rule.
title: L'Hôpital's rule

description: This isn't a full proof of L'Hopital's rule, but it should give some intuition for why it works.
title: Proof of special case of l'Hôpital's rule

description: Limits have done their part helping to find derivatives.  Now, under the guidance of l'Hôpital's rule, derivatives are looking to show their gratitude by helping to find limits.  Ever try to evaluate a function at a point and get 0/0 or infinity/infinity?  Well, that's a big clue that l'Hopital's rule can help you find the limit of the function at that point.
title: L'Hôpital's rule

description: Approximating square roots using tangent lines.
title: Local linearization

description: Approximating ln(x^2) using local linearization.
title: Local linearization example

description: Practice approximating functions with local linearizations.

title: Local linearization

description: Practice tangent lines of functions defined with polar coordinates.
title: Tangents to polar curves

description: Here you have the chance to practice thinking about tangent lines when curves are defined in polar coordinates.
title: Tangents to polar curves

description:
The reason we study calculus, and the reason it was invented, is for its many uses in real-world problems.  In particular, derivatives let us optimize functions and study their rates of change.

Here we cover optimization, rates of change, L'Hopital's rule, the mean value theorem, and more!
title: Derivative applications

description: How would you like to follow in the footsteps of Euclid and Archimedes? Would you like to be able to determine precisely how fast Usain Bolt is accelerating exactly two seconds after the starting gun? Differential calculus deals with the study of the rates at which quantities change. It is one of the two principal areas of calculus (integration being the other).
title: Differential calculus

description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".
title: Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals

description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?
title: Indefinite integrals of x raised to a power

description: Can you find a function whose derivative is 1/x?
title: Antiderivative of x^-1

description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x) and e^x?
title: Basic trig and exponential antiderivatives

description: In this example, we find the antiderivative an expression which is not so simple.
title: Antiderivative of hairier expression

description: Identify the graphs of antiderivatives
title: Graphs of antiderivatives

description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration.
title: Velocity and position from acceleration

description: Practice finding what that little "+c" should be when your integral is used for a real problem.
title: Finding the constant of integration

description: You are very familiar with taking the derivative of a function.  Now we are going to go the other way around--if I give you a derivative of a function, can you come up with a possible original function.  The symbol which we'll use to denote the anti-derivative will see strange at first, but it will all come together in a few tutorials when we see the connection between areas under curves, integrals and anti-derivatives.
title: Indefinite integral as anti-derivative

description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

description: Practice associating the area under rate-of-change curves with net change.
title: Area and net change

description: Differential calculus was all about rates. That is, after all, what a derivative is.  As we'll see, integral calculus is all about the idea of summing or "integrating" infinitely many infinitely small things to get a finite value.  This often represents the area under a curve.  This tutorial is a preview of the connection between these two concepts.
title: Area and net change

description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum"
title: Riemann approximation introduction

description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.
title: A more general Riemann sum

description: In this tutorial, we'll think about how we can find the area under a curve.  We'll first approximate this with rectangles (and trapezoids)--generally called Riemann sums.

description: As with any other mathematical operation, studying the properties of definite integrals will be a way of kicking the tires and getting a feel for how they work.  Not only will this sharpen your understanding of integrals, but it will help to make computations easier down the road.
title: Properties of the definite integral
Evaluating a function defined by an integral

description: Let's explore functions defined by definite integrals.  It will hopefully give you a deeper appreciation of what a definite integral represents.

description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.
title: Fundamental theorem of calculus

description: Fundamental theorem of calculus practice problems
title: Fundamental theorem of calculus

description: The very powerful and very surprising fact at the heart of calculus is that integrals and derivatives are, in a sense, opposite to one and other.  At first glance, rates of change and slope might seem completely unrelated to the area under a curve.  In this tutorial, you will learn about the aptly named "Fundamental theorem of calculus".
title: Fundamental theorem of calculus

description: The moment you've been waiting for.  Here we connect the idea of Riemann sums with integrals.
title: Riemann sums and integrals

description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.
title: Connecting the fundamental theorems of calculus

description: Why should taking the integral of an derivative bring you back to the function where you started?
title: Intuition for second fundamental theorem of calculus

description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.
title: Evaluating simple definite integral

description: Area between curve and axis practice problems.
title: Area between a curve and an axis

description: With integrals, it can be helpful to introduce the notion of "negative area".  See why!

description: Evaluating definite integrals using the fundamental theorem of calculus
title: Evaluating definite integrals

description: Here we'll see how the fundamental theorem of calculus lets us compute definite integrals using antiderivatives.  In some sense, this is what we have been building up to for the last few tutorials.
