description: What if you want to compute the area of a curve over an infinite region?  That turns out to be a perfectly fine thing to do.  The bounds of your integral might be infinity (or negative infinity), but with a little help from limits you will be able to handle this situation.  Even though nothing is "improper" about doing this, integrals with infinite bounds have been given the unfortunate name of "improper integrals".
title: Improper integrals

description: In this topic, we are going to connect the two big ideas in Calculus: Instantaneous rate and area under a curve.  We'll see that a definite integral can be thought of as an infinite sum of infinitely small things and how this connects to the derivative of a function.

description: When we wanted to take the derivative of f(x)g(x) in differential calculus, we used the product rule.  In this tutorial, we use the product rule to derive a powerful way to take the anti-derivative of a class of functions--integration by parts.

description:
U-substitution is a must-have tool for any integrating arsenal (tools aren't normally put in arsenals, but that sounds better than toolkit).  It is essentially the reverse chain rule.

Why the letter "u"?  Well, it could have been anything, but this is the convention.  I guess why not the letter "u" :)
title: u-substitution

description: We know that a definite integral can represent area and we've seen how this is connected to the idea of an antiderivative through the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  Unfortunately, integrals aren't always easy to compute.  Now, we'll build out our toolkit for evaluating integrals, both definite and indefinite!
title: Integration techniques

description: We don't need calculus to figure out the average value of a linear function over an interval, but what about non-linear functions?  Luckily, integral calculus comes to the rescue here.  In this tutorial, we'll understand what "average value" of a function over an interval means.  We'll also connect that notion to the Mean Value Theorem we first learned in differential calculus.
title: Average value of a function

title: Limit comparison test

description: Direct and limit comparison tests
title: Direct and limit comparison tests

description: When a series alternates (plus, minus, plus, minus,...), you only need to test if the terms of the series approach 0.
title: Alternating series test

description: "Absolute convergence" means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term.
title: Conditional and absolute convergence

description: Alternating series practice problems
title: Alternating series

description: Sometimes computing an improper integral is easier than computing a series, and we can use it for comparison.
title: Integral test intuition

description: Practice using the integral test.
title: Integral test to show series divergence

description: Here you will learn several "tests" which determine whether certain series converge or diverge.
title: Tests for convergence and divergence

description: When the terms of a series are defined as some function of n, we can place bounds on our sum by integrating that function.
title: Estimating infinite series using integrals, part 1

description: (Continuation of the last video)
title: Estimating infinite series using integrals, part 2

description: By computing only the first few terms of an alternating series, we can get a pretty good estimate for the infinte sum.  See why
title: Alternating series error estimation

description: More practice putting bounds on our estimates for alternating series.
title: Alternating series remainder

description: Apply the alternating series error test
title: Alternating series remainder

description: We've spent a lot of time thinking about whether a series converges or diverges.  But, even if we can determine that a series converges, how can we figure out what it converges to?  This tutorial will show techniques of estimating what a series converges to, and for determining how good our estimates are.  This is super useful because most series can't be precisely evaluated (like we were able to do with infinite geometric series).
title: Estimating infinite series

description: Representing a power series function over an interval of convergence
title: Power series radius and interval of convergence

description: Representing a function over an interval of convergence
title: Function over interval of convergence

description: Function represented as a geometric series
title: Function as a geometric series

description: Creating power series from geometric series using algebra practice problems.
title: Power series from geometric series using algebra

description: Power series representation using integration
title: Power series using integration

description: Creating power series from geometric series using differentiation and integration practice problems.
title: Power series from geometric series

description: Now that we're familiar with the idea of an infinite series, we can now think about functions that are defined using infinite series.  In particular, we'll begin to look at the power series representation of a function, which are kind of like infinite polynomials.  In later tutorials, we'll use calculus to find expressions of several common functions as power series.
title: Power series function representation using algebra

description: Approximating a function at 0 using a polynomial
title: Maclaurin and Taylor series intuition

description: Approximating f(x)=cos x using a Maclaurin Series
title: Cosine Taylor series at 0 (Maclaurin)

title: Taylor series at 0 (Maclaurin) for e to the x

description: This example is the reverse of previous ones.  We start with a power series, and ask which function it represents.
title: Evaluating power series for mystery function

description: Maclaurin series for sin x, cos x, and eˣ practice problems

description:
In this tutorial, we will learn to approximate differentiable functions with polynomials.  Beyond just being super cool, this can be useful for approximating functions so that they are easier to calculate, differentiate or integrate.  So whether you will have to write simulations or become a bond trader (bond traders use polynomial approximation to estimate changes in bond prices given interest rate changes and vice versa), this tutorial could be fun.

If that isn't motivation enough, we also come up with one of the most epic and powerful conclusions in all of mathematics in this tutorial: Euler's identity.
title: Maclaurin series and Euler's identity

description: Using Wolfram Alpha to approximate sin(x)
title: Visualizing Taylor series approximations

description: Approximating a function around a non-zero x value
title: Generalized Taylor series approximation

description: As we've already seen, Maclaurin series are special cases of Taylor series centered at 0.  We'll now focus on more generalized Taylor series.
title: Taylor series approximations

description: Now we switch gears away from integration to talk about sequences and series.  Much of calculus is about dealing with infinity, and this topic has us dancing very closely with infinity itself.  Sequences are infinite lists,  series are infinite sums, and there is no small amount of delicacy involved in managing these two objects.
title: Sequences, series, and function approximation

description: The Calculus BC AP exam is a super set of the AB exam.  It covers everything in AB as well as some of the more advanced topics in integration, sequences and function approximation.  This tutorial is great practice for anyone looking to test their calculus mettle!
title: AP Calculus BC questions

description: Sample questions from the A.P. Calculus AB and BC exams (both multiple choice and free answer).
title: AP Calculus practice questions

description: How do you find the area under a curve?  What about the length of any curve? Is there a way to make sense out of the idea of adding infinitely many infinitely small things?  Integral calculus gives us the tools to answer these questions and many more.  Surprisingly, these questions are related to the derivative, and in some sense, the answer to each one is the opposite of the derivative.
title: Integral calculus

description: An introduction to multivariable functions, and a welcome to the multivariable calculus content as a whole.
title: Multivariable functions

description: Welcome to multivariable calculus!  Soon you will learn how to apply to tools of calculus to multivariable functions, but to start things off let's start getting a feel for what these multivariable functions can actually look like.
title: Introduction to multivariable calculus

description: Test ability to recognize functions based on various different ways to visualize them
title: Skill check: Visualizing multivariable functions

description: Test your knowledge of the different ways to visualize multivariable functions.
title: Skill check

description: Learn how to represent and think about points and vectors in three-dimensional space.
title: Representing points in 3d

description: Three-dimensional graphs are a way to represent functions with a two-dimensional input and a one-dimensional output.
title: Introduction to 3d graphs

description: 3d graphs can be a lot to take in, but it helps to imagine slicing them with planes parallel to the x-axis or y-axis and relate them with two-dimensional graphs.
title: Interpreting graphs with slices

description: An alternative method to representing multivariable functions with a two-dimensional input and a one-dimensional output, contour maps involve drawing purely in the input space.
title: Contour plots

description: The main two tactics for understanding scalar-valued functions are graphs and contour maps.
title: Visualizing scalar-valued functions

description: When a function has a one-dimensional input, but a multidimensional output, you can think of it as drawing a curve in space.
title: Parametric curves

description: Functions that have a two-dimensional input and a three-dimensional output can be thought of as drawing a surface in three-dimensional space. This is actually pretty cool.
title: Parametric surfaces

description: Vector fields let you visualize a function with a two-dimensional input and a two-dimensional output. You end up with, well, a field of vectors sitting at various points in two-dimensional space.
title: Vector fields, introduction

description: A neat way to interpret a vector field is to imagine that it represents some kind of fluid flow.
title: Fluid flow and vector fields

description: Vector fields can also be three-dimensional, though this can be a bit trickier to visualize.
title: 3d vector fields, introduction

description: See an example of how you can start to understand how the formula for a three-dimensional vector field relates to the way it looks.
title: 3d vector field example

description: To understand vector-valued functions, it's common to either think parametrically, in which you think of the function as drawing a curve or surface in the output space, or with a vector field, in which you plop a vector on various points in space.
title: Visualizing vector-valued functions

description: One fun way to think about functions is to imagine that they literally move the points from the input space over to the output space. See what this looks like with some one-dimensional examples.
title: Transformations, part 1

description: More transformations, but this time with a function that maps two dimensions to two dimensions.
title: Transformations, part 2

description: Learn how you can think about a parametric surface as a certain kind of transformation.
title: Transformations, part 3

description: Thinking about a function as a transformation means thinking about how it moves points from the input space to the output space.  A nice way to visualize this is with animations that actually move space.
title: Transformations

description: The only thing separating multivariable calculus from ordinary calculus is this newfangled word "multivariable".  It means we will deal with functions whose inputs or outputs live in two or more dimensions.  Here we lay the foundations for thinking about and visualizing multivariable functions.
title: Thinking about multivariable functions

description: Test your knowledge of partial derivatives
title: Skill check: Partial derivatives and the gradient

description: Test your knowledge of the various ways to extend the idea of a derivative to multivariable function.
title: Skill checks

description: Partial derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you tweak just one of the variables in its input.
title: Partial derivatives, introduction

description: One of the best ways to think about partial derivatives is by slicing the graph of a multivariable function.
title: Graphical understanding of partial derivatives

description: Partial derivatives are formally defined using a limit, much like ordinary derivatives.
title: Formal definition of partial derivatives

description: There are many ways to take a "second partial derivative", but some of them secretly turn out to be the same thing.
title: Symmetry of second partial derivatives

description: The meaning of the derivative is not so straightforward when the input space has multiple dimensions.  Partial derivatives allow us to handle this by restricting movement in the input space.
title: Partial derivatives

description: The gradient captures all the partial derivative information of a scalar-valued multivariable function.
title: Gradient

description: Learn how the gradient can be thought of as pointing in the "direction of steepest ascent". This is a rather important interpretation for the gradient.
title: Gradient and graphs

description: Gradient vectors always point perpendicular to contour lines.
title: Gradient and contour maps

description: Directional derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you move along some vector in its input space.
title: Directional derivative

description: Learn the limit definition of a directional derivative. This helps to clarify what it is really doing.
title: Directional derivative, formal definition

description: The directional derivative can be used to compute the slope of a slice of a graph, but you must be careful to use a unit vector.
title: Directional derivatives and slope

description: The way we compute the gradient seems unrelated to its interpretation as the direction of steepest ascent. Here you can see how the two relate.
title: Why the gradient is the direction of steepest ascent

description: The gradient is like the king of all partial derivatives.  Or perhaps it's more like the country they all live it.  It stores all partial derivative information in a single vector-valued function, and as such it is a central tool for analyzing rates of change in multivariable functions.
title: Gradient and directional derivatives

description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path
title: Position vector valued functions

description: Visualizing the derivative of a position vector valued function
title: Derivative of a position vector valued function

description: Understanding the differential of a vector valued function
title: Differential of a vector valued function

description: Concrete example of the derivative of a vector valued function to better understand what it means
title: Vector valued function derivative example

description: In this tutorial, we will explore position vector functions and think about what it means to take a derivative of one.
title: Differentiating parametric curves

description: This is the simplest case of taking the derivative of a composition involving multivariable functions.
title: Multivariable chain rule

description: Get a feel for what the multivariable is really saying, and how thinking about various "nudges" in space makes it intuitive.
title: Multivariable chain rule intuition

description: The multivariable chain rule is more often expressed in terms of the gradient and a vector-valued derivative. This makes it look very analogous to the single-variable chain rule.
title: Vector form of the multivariable chain rule

description: See how the multivariable chain rule can be expressed in terms of the directional derivative.
title: Multivariable chain rule and directional derivatives

description: For those of you who want to see how the multivariable chain rule looks in the context of the limit definitions of various forms of the derivative.
title: More formal treatment of multivariable chain rule

description: If you have one function that takes a single number to a high dimensional space, and another which maps that high dimensional space back down to the number line, applying one after the other gives a regular old single-variable function.  But how do you find the derivative of this new function?
title: Multivariable chain rule

description: An introduction to curvature, the radius of curvature, and how you can think about each one geometrically.
title: Curvature intuition

description: Curvature is computed by first finding a unit tangent vector function, then finding its derivative with respect to arc length. Here we start thinking about what that means.
title: Curvature formula, part 1

description: A continuation in explaining how curvature is computed, with the formula for a circle as a guiding example.
title: Curvature formula, part 2

description: Here, this concludes the explanation for how curvature is the derivative of a unit tangent vector with respect to length.
title: Curvature formula, part 3

description: After the last video made reference to an explicit curvature formula, here you can start to get an intuition for why that seemingly unrelated formula describes curvature.
title: Curvature formula, part 4

description: Here, we finish the intuition for how the curvature relates to the cross product between the first two derivatives of a parametric function.
title: Curvature formula, part 5

description: An example of computing curvature by finding the unit tangent vector function, then computing its derivative with respect to arc length.
title: Curvature of a helix, part 1

description: This finishes up the helix-curvature example started in the last video.
title: Curvature of a helix, part 2

description: An example of computing curvature with the explicit formula.
title: Curvature of a cycloid

description: How do you measure how much a curve actually curves?  There are many ways to view the answer to this question, but all land you on the same mathematical quantity, known simply as "curvature".
title: Curvature

description: When a function has a multidimensional input, and a multidimensional output, you can take its partial derivative by computing the partial derivative of each component in the output.
title: Computing the partial derivative of a vector-valued function

description: When a vector-valued function represents a parametric surface, how do you interpret its partial derivative?
title: Partial derivative of a parametric surface, part 1

description: Taking the same example surface used in the last example, we now take a look at the partial derivative in the other direction.
title: Partial derivative of a parametric surface, part 2

description: How do you intepret the partial derivatives of the function which defines a vector field?
title: Partial derivatives of vector fields

description: Here we step through each partial derivative of each component in a vector field, and understand what each means geometrically.
title: Partial derivatives of vector fields, component by component

description: Learn how to compute and interpret the partial derivative of a multivariable function with a vector-valued output.
title: Partial derivatives of vector-valued functions

description: Vector fields can be thought of as representing fluid flow, and divergence is all about studying the change in fluid density during that flow.
title: Divergence intuition, part 1

description: In preparation for finding the formula for divergence, we start getting an intuition for what points of positive, negative and zero divergence should look like.
title: Divergence intuition, part 2

description: How does the x-component of a vector field relate to the divergence?
title: Divergence formula, part 1

description: Here we finish the line of reasoning which leads to the formula for divergence in two dimensions.
title: Divergence formula, part 2

description: An example of computing and interpreting the divergence of a two-dimensional vector field.
title: Divergence example

description: Learn how divergence is expressed using the same upsidedown triangle symbols that the gradient uses.
title: Divergence notation

description: In the fluid flow interpretation of vector fields, divergence is a measure of how much fluid tends to flow away from each point.  However, his turns out to have far-reaching consequences beyond the specific case of fluid flow.
title: Divergence

description: A description of how vector fields relate to fluid rotation, laying the intuition for what the operation of curl represents.
title: 2d curl intuition

description: Here we build up to the formula for computing the two-dimensional curl of a vector field, reasoning through what partial derivative information corresponds to fluid rotation.
title: 2d curl formula

description: A worked example of computing and interpreting two-dimensional curl.
title: 2d curl example

description: The meaning of positive curl in a fluid flow can sometimes look a bit different from the clear cut rotation-around-a-point examples discussed in previous videos.
title: 2d curl nuance

description: Learn how a three-dimensional vector can be used to describe three-dimensional rotation. This is important for understanding three-dimensional curl.
title: Describing rotation in 3d with a vector

description: Here we start transitioning from the understanding of two-dimensional curl into an understanding of three-dimensional curl.
title: 3d curl intuition, part 1

description: Continuing the intuition for how three-dimensional curl represents rotation in three-dimensional fluid flow.
title: 3d curl intuition, part 2

description: How to compute a three-dimensional curl, imagined as a cross product of sorts.
title: 3d curl formula, part 1

description: This finishes the demonstration of how to compute three-dimensional curl using a certain determinant.
title: 3d curl formula, part 2

description: A worked example of a three-dimensional curl computation.
title: 3d curl computation example

description: Curl is a special version of the derivative for vector fields.  It can be nicely interpreted in terms of rotation in fluid flow.
title: Curl

description: A visual understanding for how the Laplace operator is an extension of the second derivative to multivariable functions.
title: Laplacian intuition

description: A worked example of computing the laplacian of a two-variable function.
title: Laplacian computation example

description: This is another way you might see the Laplace operator written.
title: Explicit Laplacian formula

description: If the Laplacian of a function is zero everywhere, it is called Harmonic. Harmonic functions arise all the time in physics, capturing a certain notion of "stability", whenever one point in space is influenced by its neighbors.
title: Harmonic Functions

description: The Laplacian, also known as the "Laplace operator", is a way to extend the second derivative to multivariable functions.
title: Laplacian

description: What does it mean to take the derivative of a function whose input lives in multiple dimensions?  What about when its output is a vector?  Here we go over many different ways to  extend the idea of a derivative to higher dimensions, including partial derivatives​, directional derivatives, the gradient, vector derivatives, divergence, curl, etc.
title: Derivatives of multivariable functions

description: The tools of partial derivatives, the gradient, etc. can be used to optimize and approximate multivariable functions.  These are very useful in practice, and to a large extent this is why people study multivariable calculus.
title: Applications of multivariable derivatives

description: Introduction to the Line Integral
title: Introduction to the line integral

description: Concrete example using a line integral
title: Line integral example 1

description: Line integral over a closed path (part 1)
title: Line integral example 2 (part 1)

description: Part 2 of an example of taking a line integral over a closed path
title: Line integral example 2 (part 2)

description: With traditional integrals, our "path" was straight and linear (most of the time, we traversed the x-axis).  Now we can explore taking integrals over any line or curve (called line integrals).
title: Line integrals for scalar functions (videos)

description: Using line integrals to find the work done on a particle moving through a vector field
title: Line integrals and vector fields

description: Using a line integral to find the work done by a vector field example
title: Using a line integral to find work

description: Understanding how to parametrize a reverse path for the same curve.
title: Parametrization of a reverse path

description: Showing that the line integral of a scalar field is independent of path direction
title: Scalar field line integral independent of path direction

description: Showing that, unlike line integrals of scalar fields, line integrals over vector fields are path direction dependent
title: Vector field line integrals dependent on path direction

description: Showing that if a vector field is the gradient of a scalar field, then its line integral is path independent
title: Path independence for line integrals

description: Showing that the line integral along closed curves of conservative vector fields is zero
title: Closed curve line integrals of conservative vector fields

description: Example of taking a closed line integral of a conservative field
title: Example of closed line integral of conservative field

description: Using path independence of a conservative vector field to solve a line integral
title: Second example of line integral of conservative vector field

description: You've done some work with line integral with scalar functions and you know something about parameterizing position-vector valued functions.  In that case, welcome!  You are now ready to explore a core tool math and physics: the line integral for vector fields.  Need to know the work done as a mass is moved through a gravitational field.  No sweat with line integrals.
title: Line integrals in vector fields (videos)

description: Flux can be view as the rate at which "stuff" passes through a surface.  Imagine a net placed in a river and imagine the water that is flowing directly across the net in a unit of time--this is flux (and it would depend on the orientation of the net, the shape of the net, and the speed and direction of the current). It is an important idea throughout physics and is key for understanding Stokes' theorem and the divergence theorem.
title: Flux in 3D (videos)

description:
There are many ways to extend the idea of integration to multiple dimensions: Line integrals, double integrals, triple integrals, surface integrals, etc.  Each one lets you add infinitely many infinitely small values, where those values might come from points on a curve, points in an area, points on a surface, etc.  

These are all very powerful tools, relevant to almost all real-world applications of calculus.  In particular, they are an invaluable tool in physics.
title: Integrating multivariable functions

description: It is sometimes easier to take a double integral (a particular double integral as we'll see) over a region and sometimes easier to take a line integral around the boundary.  Green's theorem draws the connection between the two so we can go back and forth.  This tutorial proves Green's theorem and then gives a few examples of using it.  If you can take line integrals through vector fields, you're ready for Mr. Green.
title: Green's theorem (videos)

description: Stokes' theorem relates the line integral around a surface to the curl on the surface. This tutorial explores the intuition behind Stokes' theorem, how it is an extension of Green's theorem to surfaces (as opposed to just regions) and gives some examples using it.  We prove Stokes' theorem in another tutorial.  Good to come to this tutorial having experienced the tutorial on "flux in 3D".

description: An earlier tutorial used Green's theorem to prove the divergence theorem in 2-D, this tutorial gives us the 3-D version (what most people are talking about when they refer to the "divergence theorem").  We will get an intuition for it (that the flux through a close surface--like a balloon--should be equal to the divergence across it's volume).  We will use it in examples.  We will prove it in another tutorial.

description: In multivariable calculus, we progress from working with numbers on a line to points in space.  It gives us the tools to break free from the constraints of one-dimension, using functions to describe space, and space to describe functions.

description: How is a differential equation different from a regular one?  Well, the solution is a function (or a class of functions), not a number.  How do you like me now (that is what the differential equation would say in response to your shock)!

description: Can population grow exponentially forever?  Malthus would say "no".  Well how do you model that mathematically.  The logistic differential equation and logistic function are there to rescue us!

description: Most differential equations cannot be solved by "hand" (through analytical means).  However, this doesn't mean that we have to give up!  As we'll see in this tutorial, we can use numerical methods to approximate a solution to a differential equation.  In particular, we'll learn about Euler's Method which is a fairly intuitive way to do this!

description:
You can use a transformation/function to map from one set to another, but can you invert it?  In other words, is there a function/transformation that given the output of the original mapping, can output the original input (this is much clearer with diagrams).  

This tutorial addresses this question in a linear algebra context.  Since matrices can represent linear transformations, we're going to spend a lot of time thinking about matrices that represent the inverse transformation.
title: Inverse functions and transformations

After this we define a determinant for 2x2, 3x3 and nxn matrices.

description:
This is one of those tutorials that bring many ideas we've been building together into something applicable.  Orthogonal projections (which can sometimes be conceptualized as a "vector's shadow" on a subspace if the light source is above it) can be used in fields varying from computer graphics and statistics!

If you're familiar with orthogonal complements, then you're ready for this tutorial!
title: Orthogonal projections

description: Finding a coordinate system boring.  Even worse, does it make certain transformations difficult (especially transformations that you have to do over and over and over again)?  Well, we have the tool for you:  change your coordinate system to one that you like more.  Sound strange?  Watch this tutorial and it will be less so.  Have fun!
title: Change of basis

description: As we'll see in this tutorial, it is hard not to love a basis where all the vectors are orthogonal to each other and each have length 1 (hey, this sounds pretty much like some coordinate systems you've known for a long time!).  We explore these orthonormal bases in some depth and also give you a great tool for creating them: the Gram-Schmidt Process (which would also be a great name for a band).
title: Orthonormal bases and the Gram-Schmidt process

description: Have you ever wondered what the difference is between speed and velocity? Ever try to visualize in four dimensions or six or seven? Linear algebra describes things in two dimensions, but many of the concepts can be extended into three, four or more. Linear algebra implies two dimensional reasoning, however, the concepts covered in linear algebra provide the basis for multi-dimensional representations of mathematical reasoning.  Matrices, vectors, vector spaces, transformations, eigenvectors/values all help us to visualize and understand multi dimensional concepts. This is an advanced course normally taken by science or engineering majors after taking at least two semesters of calculus (although calculus really isn't a prereq) so don't confuse this with regular high school algebra.
title: Linear algebra

description:
Correction: when I mark where pi is on the graph, I meant pi/2!
Note: If this video were supposed to be teaching you, I'd probably have to make it boring and say that in one sense of limits, spoiler alert, you actually do approach a circle and a line, solving the apparent paradox by saying that the invariant of length does not hold over infinity. Luckily I am an artist, and this is a Rhapsody, and instead of "learning," you get to actually think, if you like.
title: Rhapsody on the proof of pi = 4

description: Special thanks to Toby (or not Toby) for playing Dog Hamlet. This cool website lets you search the first 200,000,000 digits of Pi. See if your phone number or encoded name is in there! http://www.angio.net/pi/piquery Seven Sonnets: Are Shakespeare's plays encoded within Pi? The truth is: we don't know, but we suspect They're somewhere in those digits.
title: Are Shakespeare's plays encoded within pi?

description:
Accuracy not guaranteed. Get Audacity and play! http://audacity.sourceforge.net/

Correction: it is the "Basilar" membrane, which is what I say, but somehow between recording the script and actually drawing the stuff I got confused and thought I just pronounced my Vs poorly. Always sad to have such a simple and glaring error in something I put hundreds of hours of work into, but a "Vasilar" membrane can be the kind that a Vi draws to explain Viola Vibrations, I guess! Making up new words is just so prolightfully awstastic.

Props to my Bro for excellent and creative swing pushing, and to my Mamma for filming it.

Extra special thanks to my generous donators, without whom I would not have been able to create this video. Because of your support, I have the equipment, time, and take-out Thai food necessary for doing stuff like this.

description:
The AMC 10 is part of the series of contests administered by the MAA American Mathematics Competitions that determines the United States team in the International Math Olympiad. The AMC 10 is a 25 question, 75 minute multiple choice test for students in 10th grade or below. Two versions of the AMC 10 are offered each year.

This content is brought to you by the Art of Problem Solving (www.aops.com)

description: The 'problem of points' is a classic problem Fermat and Pascal famously debated in the 17th century. Their solution to this problem formed the basis of modern day probability theory. Now it's your turn to relive this challenge!
title: Expectation warmup

description: Can Sal predict the ratio of white to black balls without looking at all of them?

description: Test your understanding of random sampling (7.SP.A.2)
title: Random sample warmup

description: Introduction to random sampling (also known as the weak law of large numbers)
title: Random sampling warmup

description: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.
title: Distribution warmup

description: Introduction to probability distributions, center, spread, and overall shape. In this warmup we will discover the binomial distribution!
title: Distribution warmup

description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth
title: Exponentiation warmup

description: Arithmetic warmups
title: Arithmetic warmups

description: Introducing key concepts using physical analogies
title: Math warmups

description: "Math is like ice cream, with more flavors than you can imagine—and if all your children ever do is textbook math, that's like feeding them broccoli-flavored ice cream." —Denise Gaskins
title: Math for fun and glory

description: Use rates to solve word problems. For example, Charlie can type 675 words in 9 minutes. How many words can Charlie type in 13 minutes?
title: Rate problems

description: Practice expressing a decimal like 0.546 as a percent.
title: Converting decimals to percents

description: Practice expressing a percent like 12.3% as a decimal.
title: Converting percents to decimals

description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100; solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
title: Finding percents

description: Practice solving word problems involving percents.
title: Percent word problems

description: Solve word problems that contain multiple quantities that are measured in different units.
title: Multiple units word problems

description: Practice filling out tables of equivalent ratios.
title: Ratio tables

description: A common application of numbers in real life (what is REAL life anyway, huh?) is through ratios, rates, and percentages. Whether following a recipe, changing the oil in a car, or determining the percentage earned on a test...these are skills you will use over and over. Ratios are simply another way to express fractions. Rates combine units of measurements to help us understand their relationship better. Percentages, like ratios, give us another way to express fractions and decimals. We'll explain each to you and then practice until you've mastered each concept.
title: Ratios, rates and percentages

description: Sal uses the Khan Academy number line widget.
title: Fractions on number line widget

description: Plot and spot fractions on the number line.
title: Fractions on the number line

description: Use unit fractions to think about the location of other fractions on the number line.

description: Divide a unit fraction by a whole number.

description: Practice dividing a whole number by a unit fraction.
title: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions 2

description: Solve and interpret division word problems that include whole numbers and fractions.
title: Divide fractions and whole numbers word problems

description: Practice dividing fractions by fractions. No negative numbers are used in this exercise.
title: Dividing fractions

description: Practice solving word problems by dividing fractions by fractions.
title: Dividing fractions word problems

description: Let's help you relate improper fractions to mixed numbers!
title: Fractions

title: Multiplying 4 digits by 1 digit with visual models

title: Multiply 2-digits numbers with area models

title: Compare with multiplication

title: Divide by 1-digit numbers (no remainders)

title: Divide by 1-digit numbers (visual models)

title: Divide with remainders

title: Multi-step word problems with whole numbers

description: Practice solving multiplication and division word problems. Some problems have remainders.

description: Let's handle slightly more complicated multiplications and divisions. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice! After these tutorials, you'll be comfortable dividing two digit whole numbers and decimals, whether they are in the divisor or dividend position. Pretty exciting, huh? Let me a hear a "Yes!"

And why not go into the fun concepts of manipulating decimals through addition, subtraction, multiplication and division! It really is a breeze once you are done with these videos!

description: Identify prime numbers less than 100.
title: Identify prime numbers

description: Identify composite numbers less than 100.

description: After these videos, understanding the concept of prime numbers and the ones for which you can finding factors and multiples, will be no brainers!

title: Commutative law of multiplication

title: Least common multiple

title: Greatest common factor

description: Solve word problems where you either need to find the GCF or LCM.
title: GCF & LCM word problems

description: This group of tutorials will introduce us to some of the common properties of numbers, including the least common multiple (LCM), greatest common factor (GCF), and the distributive property. We'll hear really good explanations and practice rewriting expressions so that we can extend our understanding of the properties of numbers and of PEDMAS! All of these will be extremely useful going forward. Really, it's true!
title: Properties of numbers

description: The most fundamental branch of math is having a clear idea on number sense and numeration. It consists of understanding place values, adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing numbers. We're willing to bet that doing these operations on whole numbers is a piece of cake, but now we'll mix those numbers up with decimals and fraction and exciting concepts like ratios and percentages. So sharpen that pencil and relax in your chair, we're going for a ride!
title: Number Sense and Numeration

description: Convert between metric measures of distance, volume, and mass.
title: Convert units (metrics)

description: Sal converts 37 centimeters to meters.
title: Converting units: centimeters to meters

description: Sal converts 3 1/2 gallons to cups.
title: Converting units: US volume

description: Solve word problems that involve converting between metric measures of distance, volume, and mass, as well as measures of time.
title: Convert units word problems (metric)

description: Wait, I'm in Europe and my car only tells my distance traveled in kilometers! But I'm used to a units of distance devised by the Romans to measure the average length of 1000 paces of a soldier (the "mile")! How do I operate? These tutorials are about the fundamental skill of unit conversion. Sal's cousin Nadia being a bit confused with this was actually the reason why he started tutoring her (which led to the creation of the Khan Academy).
title: Unit conversion

description: Sal uses an area model to multiply 78x65.
title: Multiplying with area model: 78 x 65

description: Practice finding the area of right, acute, and obtuse triangles from a diagram.
title: Area of triangles

description: Practice finding the areas of triangles and quadrilaterals on grids.
title: Areas of shapes on grids

description: Practice finding the area of parallelograms given base and height.
title: Area of parallelograms

description: Don't be intimidated by odd looking geometric figures and being asked to find its area. In this example you'll understand that breaking up the figure into smaller geometric shapes that are regular make the task a lot easier.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: Practice solving problems involving triangles, parallelograms, and composite figures. Exercises include decimals, fractions, and word problems. Area of circles is not included.
title: Area challenge

description: Practice finding the areas of trapezoids.
title: Area of trapezoids

description: Practice finding the areas of complex shapes that are composed of smaller shapes.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: Practice matching 2D nets to the 3D shapes the fold up into.
title: Nets of polyhedra

description: Practice finding the surface area of 3D objects.
title: Surface area

description: Area is how we thinking about how much space something takes in two dimensions such as comparing how much land one property takes up versus another. We'll take a conceptual look at how area is actually measured.
title: Area

description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area time length.
title: Measuring volume as area times length

description: Find volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.  Find a missing side length on a rectangular prism when given the volume.
title: Volume 1

description: Find volume of rectangular prisms to solve word problems.
title: Volume word problems

description: Practice finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths.
title: Volume with fractions

description: Practice solving volume word problems involving objects like fish tanks, truck beds, and refrigerators.
title: Volume word problems: fractions & decimals

description: In this tutorial we'll practice finding solid geometry volume. Keep paper and pencil nearby in case you want to remember the formulas.
title: Volume of triangular prism & cube

description: Volume measures how much 3-dimensional "space" an object takes up. We'll see in this tutorial that it is an extension of length (1-D) or area (2-D) to three dimensions!
title: Volume

description: If you think about it, we measure almost everything: time, distance, size, weight, volume, etc. Every THING can be measured. The question is, what unit of measurement is used and how is that unit constructed, compared, and converted? This last part is what we explore in these tutorials.
title: Measurement

description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.
title: Intro to the coordinate plane

description: Let's get familiar with the x/y coordinate plane, both from the perspective of plotting points and interpreting the placement of points on a plane.
title: Points on the coordinate plane examples

description: We're plotting an ordered pair on the x (horizontal) axis and y (vertical) axis of the coordinate plane.
title: Plotting a point (ordered pair)

description: Plot a given point on the coordinate plane.
title: Graph points

description: Practice graphing points and identifying which quadrants they're in.
title: Graphing points & naming quadrants

description: Practice plotting points like (-2, 4).
title: Points on the coordinate plane

description: Find the distance between points, graph points, and interpret data on coordinate planes to solve word problems.
title: Coordinate plane word problems (quadrant 1)

description: Practice solving word problems by interpreting the meaning of points plotted on an xy coordinate system.
title: Coordinate plane problems in all four quadrants

description: Practice reflecting points across axes on the xy coordinate plane.
title: Reflecting points in the coordinate plane

description: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions? Here, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane. We now delve into the world of Euclid. This will be a great tutorial experience if you are just starting to ramp up your understanding of graphing or need some fundamental review.
title: Coordinate plane

description: Measure angles using a protractor.
title: Measure angles

description: Use a protractor to construct angles.
title: Draw angles

description: Determine if an angle is acute, right, or obtuse.  A protractor is provided.
title: Angle types

description: Determine if angles in shapes and pictures are acute, right, or obtuse.
title: Recognize angles

description: Create an acute, right, or obtuse angle using a given vertex.
title: Draw right, acute, and obtuse angles

description: Estimate the size of angles when given a picture or a situation.
title: Benchmark angles

description: Challenge problems involving the coordinates of the vertices of the quadrilaterals
title: Quadrilateral problems on the coordinate plane

description: Practice drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.
title: Drawing polygons with coordinates

description: More challenging problems involving drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.
title: Drawing polygons with coordinates challenge

description: Draw and identify lines of symmetry.  Create and identify symmetrical shapes.
title: Identify lines of symmetry and symmetrical figures

description: Analyze various shapes according to their reflective and rotational symmetries.
title: Symmetry of 2D shapes

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform translations.
title: Perform translations

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform rotations.
title: Perform rotations

description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform reflections.
title: Perform reflections

description: It's time to learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations. We will start with lines of symmetry and the order of rotational symmetry and then move on to reflecting, translating, and/or rotating a shape
title: Transformations

description: We are surrounded by space. And that space contains lots of things. And these things have shapes. In geometry we are concerned with the nature of these shapes, how we define them, and what they teach us about the world at large. Geometry is at the core of everything that exists--including you. Some of the interesting topics we cover in measurements section: triangles, prisms, quadrilaterals etc. are all actually part of geometry too! Having said all that,  here we'll delve into angles and coordinate planes and more!
title: Geometry and Spatial Sense

description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.
title: Graphing patterns on coordinate plane

description: One of the fundamentals of algebra is learning to recognize patterns among numbers and being able to visualize those patterns and relationships. So...let's use some mathematical tools to visualize, interpret, and graph patterns involving the coordinate plane.
title: Number patterns

description: Basics of expression with two variables
title: Expressions with two variables

description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.
title: Writing basic expressions word problems

description: Practice plugging in a value for the variable in an equation. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.
title: Evaluating expressions with one variable

description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables.
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables

description: Practice plugging in values to evaluate real-world algebraic expressions. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.
title: Evaluating expressions with variables word problems

description: Another good explanation (minus Chuck Norris) on the how we combine like terms in algebra. This will totally make sense.
title: Combining like terms

description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.
title: Combining like terms challenge problem

description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. Coefficients on some terms are negative.
title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients

description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.
title: Equivalent expressions

description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations.
title: Modeling with one-step equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? I must figure this out!!! Yes, you must. This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of algebraic variables and expressions.
title: Variables and expressions

description: Arithmetic is fun, but algebra is a blast!  These tutorials will give you some straightforward explanations and examples to get you started down the road of algebraic thinking. We'll practice writing and evaluating numerical expressions, as well as seeing, interpreting, and graphing patterns and relationships between numbers. We're laying the foundation for lots of good learning ahead!
title: Patterning and Algebra

description: Practice reading information presented in box plots.
title: Reading box plots

description: Create a bar graph with the data given.
title: Create bar graphs 2

description: Read and interpret a double bar graphs.
title: Read bar graphs 2

description: Interpret picture graphs to answer questions about a context.
title: Read picture graphs 2

description: Practice reading basic dot plots and frequency tables.
title: Reading dot plots & frequency tables

description: Practice creating dot plots. Dot plots are very similar to frequency tables, but they make it easier to see the data.
title: Creating dot plots

description: Interpret fraction data on dot plots to solve word problems.
title: Interpret dot plots with fraction operations

description: This tutorial is less about statistics and more about interpreting data.  Whether you're looking at scientific data or stock price: a table, pictograph, bar graph or line graph, box-and-whisker plots can show up in your life. This tutorial covers what they are, how to read them and how to construct them.
title: Data management

description: Practice spotting the difference between statistical and non-statistical questions.
title: Statistical questions

description: Calculate the mean, median, or mode of a data set!
title: Mean, median, and mode

description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!
title: Mean, median, & mode example

description: Learn how to find the value of a missing piece of data if you know the mean of the data set.
title: Missing value given the mean

description: This is the foundational tutorial for the rest of statistics. Mean, median and mode are measures of "central tendency." That is, they help us find the center (or middle) of the data.
title: Statistics

description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.
title: Intro to probability

description: Practice expressing probabilities in different forms (fractions, decimals, and percents).
title: Comparing probabilities

description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.
title: Simple probability

description: Practice making reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events based on past experience.
title: Experimental probability

description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.
title: Probability models

description: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Explores probability models, sample spaces, predict the frequency of an outcome of a simple probability experiment or game and a whole lot more.
title: Probability

description: We dare you to go through a day in which you never consider or use probability or statistics. Did you check the weather forecast? Busted! Did you decide to go through the drive through lane vs walk in? Busted again! We are constantly creating hypotheses, making predictions, testing, and analyzing. We are constantly looking at data and charts to understand a multitude of information out there....so here you go! All made simple for you!
title: Data Management and Probability

description:
By the 6th grade, you're becoming a sophisticated mathemagician. 
You'll be able to add, subtract, multiply, and divide any non-negative numbers (including decimals and fractions) that any grumpy ogre throws at you. Mind-blowing ideas like ratios, percents, negative numbers, and variable expressions will start being in your comfort zone.  Most importantly, the algebraic side of mathematics is a whole new kind of fun!  

And if that is not enough, we are going to continue with our understanding of ideas like the coordinate plane and area while beginning to derive meaning from data!
title: 6th grade (Ontario)

description: What is "preservation of equality"?  Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? I must figure this out!!! Yes, you must. This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of algebraic variables and expressions.
title: Variables and equations

description: One of the fundamentals of algebra is learning to recognize patterns among numbers and being able to visualize those patterns and relationships. So...let's use some mathematical tools to visualize, interpret, and graph patterns involving the coordinate plane. Trust us, this sounds a lot more complicated than it really is. Just follow along and pause the videos as necessary.
title: Patterns and Relations

title: Misleading line graphs

description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.
title: Intro to probability

description: In this video, we 'll explore the probability of getting at least one heads in multiple flips of a fair coin.
title: Coin flipping probability

description: Manually going through the combinatorics to determine the probability of an event occuring
title: Example: All the ways you can flip a coin

description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.

description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.
title: Simple probability

description: Practice making reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events based on past experience.
title: Experimental probability

description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.
title: Probability models

description: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Explores probability models, sample spaces, predict the frequency of an outcome of a simple probability experiment or game and a whole lot more.
title: Probability

description: We dare you to go through a day in which you never consider or use probability or statistics. Did you check the weather forecast? Busted! Did you decide to go through the drive through lane vs walk in? Busted again! We constantly making predictions and looking at data around us: here's a bit on line graphs and probabilities!
title: Statistics and Probability

description: By the 6th grade, you're starting to become a sophisticated mathemagician. You'll be able to add, subtract, multiply, and divide any non-negative numbers (including decimals and fractions) that any grumpy ogre throws at you. Ratios, percents, and variable expressions will start being in your comfort zone. Most importantly, the algebraic side of mathematics is a whole new kind of fun! And if that is not enough, we are going to continue with our understanding of ideas like the coordinate plane  and area and much more!
title: 6th grade (WNCP)

description: We will understand what the we mean by the term "Greatest common divisor" or "Highest common factor", and cover some basic exercises. Let's begin!
title: Highest common factor

description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 12 and 36, and of 12 and 18. He shows how to do that using the prime factorization method, which is a just great!
title: Least common multiple

description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 25 and 30.
title: Least common multiple: repeating factors

description: This least common multiple example gives us 3 numbers from which to find the lcm. This is a challenge, but fun. Do it with us!
title: Least common multiple of three numbers

description: Find the lcm (least common multiple) of pairs of integers.
title: Least common multiple

description: Here, we will look into what we mean when we use the term "Lowest common multiple" and how we can calculate it.
title: Lowest common multiple

description: Here we have a couple of word problems--one searching for the least common multiple and the other for the greatest common factor. Just read them with us slowly and follow along. You'll get it.
title: GCF & LCM word problems

description: Solve word problems where you either need to find the GCF or LCM.
title: GCF & LCM word problems

description: Let's look into some applications of Highest common factor (HCF) and Lowest common multiple (LCM), and try to build a better understanding of these topics through some exercises.
title: Some problems on HCF and LCM

description: In this chapter we will learn about factors and multiples and about the divisibility rules for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9 and 10
title: Chapter 3: Playing with numbers

description: We don't normally delve too far into history when talking about math, but sometimes it's important to have perspective about how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.
title: Euclid as the father of geometry

description: Here we will discuss the meaning of geometry and the history related to it. We will also look into the life of Euclid, who is known as the father of Geometry.
title: Introduction

description: Sal discusses geometry terms like point, line, and ray.  He also shows to label them.
title: Terms & labels in geometry

description: We will understand the definition of a point and look into how we can make it.
title: Points

description: Sal discusses the difference between lines, line segments, and rays.
title: Lines, line segments, & rays

description: Recognize rays, lines, and line segments in geometric figures.
title: Identify rays, lines, & line segments

description: In this topic we will see that a line segment is a part of a line that is bounded by two end points. A line segment that goes off on both directions indefinitely is called a line, whereas a line segment that only extends in one direction is called a ray. In this topic we will learn to draw, recognize and differentiate between line segments, lines, and rays.
title: Line segments, lines and rays

description: Sal discusses how to tell if lines are parallel or perpendicular.
title: Intro to parallel & perpendicular lines

description: Sal identifies parallel and perpendicular lines in geometric figures.
title: Parallel & perpendicular lines

description: Two lines that cannot have a common point are called parallel lines. When two intersecting lines make an angle of 90 degrees, they are called perpendicular lines. When two lines intersect and the angle between them is a right angle, then the lines are said to be perpendicular. In this topic we will learn to clearly differentiate between parallel and perpendicular lines and to draw them.
title: Parallel lines

description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs
title: Circles glossary

description: A circle is a simple closed curve that is not a polygon. It is the locus of all points that are equidistant from it's centre. In this topic we will look into the language and notations that we use while dealing with circles.
title: Circles

description: Geometry comes from the greek words for "earth" and "measurement." It is the study of shapes and sizes. In this chapter, we will develop a strong foundation for geometry.
title: Chapter 4: Basic geometrical ideas

description: Sal discusses acute, obtuse, and right angles and shows examples of each.
title: Acute, right, & obtuse angles

description: An angle smaller than a right angle is called an acute angle, an angle greater than right angle but less then straight angle is obtuse angle while a reflex angle is larger then a straight angle. I this chapter we will also learn how to categorize triangles based on the angles that it has.
title: Angles: acute, obtuse, and reflex

description: Sal measures an angle with a protractor.
title: Measuring angles in degrees

description: Sal uses a virtual protractor to measure some angles.
title: Measuring angles using a protractor

description: Sal measures several angles with a protractor.
title: Measuring angles using a protractor 2

description: Sal finds the measure of angles by adding or subtracting.
title: Decomposing an angle

description: Sal draws acute, right, and obtuse angles with given points.
title: Drawing acute, right and obtuse angles

description: Create an acute, right, or obtuse angle using a given vertex.
title: Draw right, acute, and obtuse angles

description: One complete revolution is divided into 360 equal parts. Each part is a degree, and angles are measured in degrees. A right angle is 90 degrees and a straight angle is 180 degrees. In this topic we will learn how to measure angles in degrees. We will also learn how to use a protractor and to solve for unknown angles.
title: Measuring angles

description: Sal categorizes triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.
title: Classifying triangles 1

description: You say you can't categorize a triangle because you don't know the length of the sides. Guess what? If you know the size of the angles you can!
title: Classifying triangles by angles

description: Sal categorizes triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.
title: Classifying triangles 2

description: Practice identifying triangles by their side-lengths as equilateral, isosceles, or scalene.
title: Identify triangles by side lengths

description: Triangles are of various types, they can be scalene/isosceles/equilateral or acute angled/obtuse angled/right angled triangle in nature. In this topic we will learnt how to categorize and recognize these different types of triangles.
title: Classification of triangles

description: Sal introduces the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.
title: Intro to quadrilateral

description: Sal identifies quadrilaterals as kites, trapezoids, parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.
title: Quadrilateral types

description: Identify quadrilaterals based on pictures or attributes.  Quadrilaterals included are parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.
title: Quadrilateral types

description: Rectangle, parallelogram, square, rhombus, trapezium all are different types of Quadrilaterals. In this topic we will look more closely at quadrilaterals and will understand how to differentiate between it's various forms.
title: Quadrilaterals

description: Corners, edges, planes, open curves and closed curves are different shapes that we see around us. Understanding these shapes can help us solve a wise variety of real world problems.
title: Chapter 5: Understanding elementary shapes

description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.
title: Intro to negative numbers

description: Practice explaining the meaning of negative numbers in different scenarios.
title: Interpreting negative numbers

description: Given a few negative numbers on a number line, let's see if we can determine what negative numbers are elsewhere on the number line.

description: Identify positive and negative integers on the number line.

description: Practice more challenging problems where you identify positive and negative integers on a number line that doesn't have zero labeled.
title: Missing numbers on the number line

description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.
title: Ordering negative numbers

description: Practice putting positive and negative numbers in order. For example, -28, 12, -51, and 43.
title: Ordering negative numbers

description: If we put the whole numbers and the negative numbers together, the new collection of numbers are called integers. In this topic we will learn how to depict negative numbers on a number line, ordering of negative numbers, and will introduce the concept of fractions on a number line.
title: Integers

description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)
title: Adding negative numbers example

description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29
title: Adding numbers with different signs

description: Practice adding positive and negative single-digit numbers.
title: Adding negative numbers

description: When we add a negative integer to a positive integer, we move to the left on the number line. Similarly, when we add a positive number to a negative number, we move to the right on the number line. In this topic we will learn how to add/subtract negative numbers, integers with different signs, and will practice this concept on the number line.
title: Addition of integers

description: Find out why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding the absolute value of that number.
title: Subtracting a negative = adding a positive

description: Adding and subtracting negative numbers
title: Adding/subtracting negative numbers

description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).
title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers

description: Practice subtracting positive and negative single-digit numbers.
title: Subtracting negative numbers

title: Negative number word problem: temperatures

description: To subtract an integer from another integer, it is enough to add the additive inverse of the integer that is being subtracted, to the other integer. We will also see that subtracting a negative equals adding a positive, and we will practice this concept on several basic problems.
title: Subtraction of integers with the help of the number line

description: The set of numbers from 1 to infinity is called Natural numbers. When we add 0 to this, we get whole numbers. A set of 0, natural numbers and their opposites, make up 'integers'.
title: Chapter 6: Integers

description: A fraction is a number representing part of a whole. We use fractions in everyday life, from dividing a to even checking the time. In this chapter we will learn about the basics of fractions, what proper, improper, equivalent, and mixed fractions are. We will also learn how to write fractions in their simplest forms, to compare fractions, and to add or subtract two fractions.
title: Introduction

In this topic we will learn ow to recognize a fraction, we will introduce the concept of numerators and denominators and we will learn how to compare fractions visually and using the number line.

description: Fractions less than 1 are called proper fractions. In a proper fraction, the numerator is always less than the denominator. A mixed fraction is a combination of a whole and a part, while fractions greater than 1 are called improper fractions. In this topic we will learn about changing/converting mixed numbers into improper fractions and vice versa. We will also do exercises to convert decimals into fractions.

description: A fraction is a number representing part of a whole. We use fractions in everyday life, from dividing a pie to even checking the time. 3/4, 56/3, 25/4 etc. are all fractions.

description: A dot represents a decimal point. In real life problems like measuring of length, weight, or time, the values are not exact whole numbers, but rather portions of whole numbers. In situations where we need to be exact, we use decimal numbers. In this chapter we will learn how to reduce number to 10ths, 100ths of a decimal place, to compare decimal numbers. We will also learn how to add and subtract decimal numbers, and understand how to use them in real life situations.
