description: Where did the word "Algebra" and its underlying ideas come from?
title: Origins of algebra

description: Algebra is the language through which we describe patterns in mathematics. It involves usage of letters with numbers to depict problems. In this topic chapter we will learn about Matchstick patters, we will introduce the idea of variables, and we will understand where these variables can be used. A variable is depicted as a letter which can take any value. We will also learn to write linear expressions and ways to solve them.
title: Introduction

description: Why the abstraction of mathematics is so fundamental.
title: The beauty of algebra

description: Understand how variables can be used to denote patterns and equations, thus making our lives simpler in complex scenarios.
title: Matchstick patterns

description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.
title: What is a variable?

description: Jesse Roe and Sal Khan talk about why we use letters in algebra.
title: Why all the letters in algebra?

description: Great question. In algebra, we do indeed avoid using the multiplication sign. We'll explain it for you here.
title: Why aren't we using the multiplication sign?

description: A variable is a number whose value is not fixed; e.g. n is a variable and it can take any value 1, 2, 3, 4, …
title: The idea of a variable

description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions that involve grouping quantities in parentheses.
title: Writing expressions with variables & parentheses

description: Like other exercises in this tutorial, we're rewriting statements into algebraic expression. This time we have to choose which is the correct one among those given.
title: Writing algebraic expressions example 2

description: The more you practice, the better you get at writing algebraic expressions. So don't hesitate. Let's go!
title: Writing algebraic expressions example 3

description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").
title: Evaluating an expression with one variable

description: Basics of expression with two variables
title: Expressions with two variables

description: Expression like (4x + 5), which contains the variable x, cannot be evaluated. Only if x is given some value, an expression like (4x + 5) can be evaluated. In this topic we will learn how to evaluate exponential equations, we will write expressions variables and learn how to solve them when the value of the variable is specified.
title: Expressions with variables

description: Learn how to write basic expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.
title: Writing basic expressions word problems

description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.
title: Interpreting linear expressions: diamonds

description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.
title: Writing basic expressions word problems

description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.
title: Interpreting linear expressions: flowers

description: Practice interpreting linear expressions
title: Interpreting linear expressions

description: In this topic we will learn to evaluate and interpret linear expression using examples from real world problems.
title: Using expressions practically

description: This basic equation asks us to substitute for a variable with given values in order to find correct one.
title: Substituting variables and simple equation

description: The great thing about understanding expressions and equalities is that they can be used to solve real life problems, like how many dogs you can eat in a minute!
title: Substituting variables and solving for an equality

description: The value of the variable in an equation which satisfies the equation is called a solution to the equation. Here we will learn to solve an equation using substitution.
title: Solution of an equation

description: Algebra is the language through which we describe patterns in mathematics. It involves usage of letters with numbers to depict problems.
title: Chapter 11: Algebra

description: What a ratio is.  Simple ratio problems.
title: Introduction to ratios

description: In certain situations, comparison by division makes better sense than comparison by taking the difference. The comparison by division is called the ratio of the two numbers. In this chapter we will introduce the concept of ratios and proportions.
title: Introduction

description: Learn how to find the ratio between two things. In this video, we find the ratio of apples to oranges.
title: Intro to ratios

description: How are fractions and ratios the same? How are they different? Is 2:5 the same as 2/5?
title: Ratios as fractions

description: Choose the ratio that goes with a picture of two quantities like apples and bananas.
title: Basic ratios

description: Ratios as Fractions in Simplest Form
title: Ratios as fractions in simplest form

description: Simplifying Rates and Ratios
title: Simplifying rates and ratios

description: In this word problem, we'll compare the weight of two objects using a ratio of integers. We'll practice simplifying a fraction, too.
title: Rational number word problem: computers

description: Use your knowledge of proportions and fractions to determine shareholders profit in this word problem.
title: Rational number word problem: stock

description: Sal solves a tricky ratio word problem.
title: Ratio word problem: boys to girls

description: Sal uses ratios to figure out how far apart two cities should be on a map.
title: Ratio word problem: centimeters to kilometers

description: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If Ben reads 10 pages in 15 minutes, how long does it take him to read 40 pages?"
title: Ratio word problems

description: We're displaying ratios in a table format here, and then asking: given a ratio, solve for equivalent ratios. Here are a few examples to practice on.
title: Solving ratio problems with tables example 1

description: Let's compare 2 tables of ratios and interpret them to solve the word problem. This is a fun!
title: Solving ratio problems with tables example 2

description: Practice filling out tables of equivalent ratios.
title: Ratio tables

description: Comparing any two quantities in terms of ‘how many times’ is known as ratio, and it is denoted by a ':' sign.Two quantities can be compared only if they are in the same unit. In this topic we will learn to simplify rations, and see how they are used through several basic examples.
title: Ratio

description: Understanding Proportions
title: Proportion validity example

description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.
title: Intro to proportional relationships

description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and perimeter.
title: Is side length & perimeter proportional?

description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and area.
title: Is side length & area proportional?

description: Given a table of ratios, watch as we test them for equivalence and determine whether the relationship is proportional.
title: Proportional relationships: spaghetti

description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by reasoning about equivalent ratios.
title: Proportional relationships

description: If two ratios are equal, we say that they are in proportion and use the symbol ‘::’ or ‘=’ to equate the two ratios. Here we will look into an example that should help us gain a better understanding of this topic.
title: Proportion

description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.
title: Intro to rates

description: Jayda takes 3 hours to deliver newspapers on her route. What is the rate per hour at which she delivers the newspapers?
title: Solving unit rate problem

description: Miranda's Maid Service charges $280 to clean 8 offices. What is the company's price for cleaning a single office?
title: Solving unit price problem

description: Use rates to solve word problems. For example, Charlie can type 675 words in 9 minutes. How many words can Charlie type in 13 minutes?
title: Rate problems

description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.
title: Rational number word problem: cosmetics

description: The method in which first we find the value of one unit and then the value of required number of units is known as Unitary Method. In this topic we will learn to use the unitary method to solve problems involving ratios.
title: Unitary method

description: In certain situations, comparison by division makes better sense than comparison by taking the difference. The comparison by division is called the ratio of the two numbers.
title: Chapter 12: Ratio and proportion

description: Sal introduces the concept of an "axis of symmetry."
title: Intro to reflective symmetry

description: Draw and identify lines of symmetry.  Create and identify symmetrical shapes.
title: Identify lines of symmetry and symmetrical figures

description: Symmetry is when one shape becomes exactly like another if you flip, slide or turn it. In this chapter we will introduce the concept of axis of symmetry. The axis of symmetry is an imaginary line on a given shape around which if the shape is folded, both sides resemble each other.
title: Introduction

description: Symmetry is when one shape becomes exactly like another if you flip, slide or turn it.
title: Chapter 13: Symmetry

description: Geometry is to draw various shapes with tools like rulers, compasses, dividers, set squares and protractors. It is the study of shapes.

title: Associative law of addition

title: Identity property of 0

description: In this topic we will understand the properties of addition and subtraction of integers, like Commutative Law of Addition, which says that the two numbers can be added in any order--but this does not hold true for subtraction. Apart from this, we will study various other properties like Commutative Property, Associative Law, and that subtracting a negative is equivalent to adding a positive.
title: Properties of addition and subtraction of integers

description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Why a negative times a negative is a positive

description: Use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an understanding of multiplying negative numbers.

description: In this section we will see what happens when we multiply two integers, and how their signs affect the result. For example, a negative times a negative is a positive but positive times a negative is a negative.

description: Commutative Law of Multiplication
title: Commutative law of multiplication

title: Associative law of multiplication

description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.

description: Learn how to apply the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive property or distributive law.

description: Identity property of 1
title: Identity property of 1 (second example)

description: In this section, we will understand the fundamental laws of Multiplication like Commutative Law which says that integers can be multiplied in any order; Identity property of 1 which says that an integer multiplied with 1 gives the same integer. Apart from this we will study various other laws like Associative Law, Combining like terms, and the Distributive Property

You just need to multiply whole number by reciprocal of that fraction. Apart from this, there are videos for Dividing fractions, Dividing mixed numbers, Dividing mixed numbers and Fractions, Reciprocal of a Mixed Number

description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.
title: Intro to multiplying decimals

description: We're multiplying decimals again, but this time answering a common question: what's the cost of filling up the car tank?
title: Multiplying decimals word problem

description: Multiply a whole number times a decimal written to the tenths or hundredths place.
title: Multiplying decimals 1

description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.
title: Multiplying decimals: place value

description: Multiplying decimals? Try multiplying without the decimals first, them add them back in. We'll show you.
title: Multiplying decimals example

description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.
title: Multiplying challenging decimals

description: Multiply two numbers.  Factors are written to the ones, tenths, or hundredths place.
title: Multiplying decimals 2

description: Sal multiplies 0.44 times 1000 using powers of 10.

description: In this topic we will understand multiplication of decimal numbers like how to multiply a whole number with a decimal number, how to multiply a decimal number with a decimal number. Apart from this, we will also figure out an interesting pattern when a decimal number is multiplied by powers of 10.

description: Sal divides 63÷35.
title: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal

description: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is larger than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.
title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2

description: You're doing great. Now we want to mix it up a little: divide a decimal by a whole number. Follow along.
title: Dividing a decimal by a whole number

description: Divide a whole number by a number written to the tenths or hundredths place.  Quotients are whole numbers.
title: Dividing decimals 1

description: When dividing a whole number by a decimal, you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.
title: Dividing a whole number by a decimal

description: Divide a whole number by a number written to the tenths or hundredths place.  Quotients may include decimals.
title: Dividing decimals 2

description: Let's do one more decimal division problem together but change it up. This is one with a decimal divisor and will require you to shift the decimal first.
title: Dividing by a multi-digit decimal

description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

description: The old saying is "practice makes perfect." Let's keep practicing dividing decimals and making our divisor a whole number.
title: Dividing decimals with hundredths example 3

description: Divide two numbers.  Divisors, dividends, and quotients can include decimals written to the tenths or hundredths place.

description: Practice dividing decimal numbers using "long division".
title: Dividing decimals: ten thousandths

description: Sal divides 99.061 by 100 using powers of 10.

description: Practice multiplying and dividing by powers of 10.

description: Give the number of tens a number is being multiplied or divided by when the decimal is moved to the left or right.

description: Sal converts 549 minutes to hours.

description: Convert between metric measures of distance, volume, and mass.

description: In this topic we will learn division of a decimal number by a whole number, or another decimal number. Apart from this, we will also figure out an interesting pattern when a decimal number is divided by powers of 10.
