description: Fractions tell us how many parts of the whole we have. Decimals on the other hand help us with accurate measurement of length, weight etc., because in the real world, these quantities aren't exact whole numbers but in fact parts of a large number.
title: Chapter 2: Fractions and decimals

description: Here's the thing to ask when determining if you have a statistical and non-statistical question on your hand: Is there variability involved? Watch and we'll explain.
title: Statistical and non statistical questions

description: Practice spotting the difference between statistical and non-statistical questions.
title: Statistical questions

description: Data collection is the process of gathering information. There are various methods of data collection, such as personal interviewing, telephone, mail and the internet. But before collecting data, we need to know what would we use it for.
title: Collecting data

description: Sal introduces statistics and explains the three different ways to describe the center of a data set.
title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode

description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!
title: Mean, median, & mode example

description: Practice calculating the mean (average) of a data set. The mean gives us a sense of the middle, or center, of the data.
title: Calculating the mean

description: Practice finding the median of a data set. Like the mean, the median gives us a sense of the middle, or center, of the data.
title: Calculating the median

description: Practice computing the mean of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.
title: Calculating the mean: data displays

description: Practice computing the median of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.
title: Calculating the median: data displays

description: Calculate the mean, median, or mode of a data set!
title: Mean, median, and mode

description: Watch as we use a nifty interactive module to demonstrate how moving points along a number line can help us find the mean and median.
title: Exploring the mean and median

description: Mean, Mode and Median are basic statistical terminologies which you should be aware of. Arithmetic Mean is measure of the central tendency of the group of data. Mode of a set of observations is the observation in the data that occurs most often. Median refers to the value which lie in the middle of data, when arranged in increasing or decreasing order. Let's learn about them in detail.
title: Arithmetic mean, mode, and median

description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.
title: Intro to probability

description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.
title: Simple probability: non-blue marble

description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.
title: Simple probability

description: Probability of an event helps us quantify and understand the likeliness of that event to occur.
title: Chance and probability

description: Data handling helps us in collection, recording and presentation of data -- organizing data makes it easy to understand and interpret.
title: Chapter 3: Data handling

description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.
title: Same thing to both sides of equations

description: Equations are about relationships (no, not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.
title: Representing a relationship with an equation

description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?
title: One-step equations intuition

description: To find the value of a variable, you sometimes have to get it on one side of the equation alone. To do that, you'll need to do something to BOTH sides of the equation. Watch. We'll explain why we do this.
title: One-step equations intuition example

description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.
title: Dividing both sides of an equation

description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.
title: Intro to two-step equations

description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!
title: One-step division equations

description: Remember that what you do to one side, you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction, x/a? Let's do it together.
title: One-step multiplication equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations

description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54
title: One-step subtraction equations

description: Some quick examples to practice solving a variety of one step equations. All 4 operations (add, subtract, multiple, divide) are paired with variables.
title: Simple equations: examples solving a variety of forms

description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples, but you can do it!
title: Two-step equations intuition

description: Let's practice some two step equations, some of which require merging terms and using the distributive property.
title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions 2

description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2.
title: Two-step equations example

description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve.
title: Two-step equations

description: The word 'equation' is derived from the word 'equal'. An Equation is a statement which defines the equality between variables and constants. The addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of a number on both sides does not disturb this equality. Here we will learn various forms of equation like ax=b, a/x=b. We also learn methods to solve an equation.
title: What an equation is

description: An equation is a statement that helps us understand the equality between two or more variables, and constants. A variable can take various values. Its value is not fixed. We use letters x, y, l, m, ... etc. to denote variables. On the other hand, a constant has a fixed value. x+3=7 is an equation where x is a variable and 3 and 7 are constants.
title: Chapter 4: Simple equations

description: Let's add some tools to our geometry tool belt. Here's a thorough explanation of complementary and supplementary angles, as well as definitions of adjacent and straight angles.
title: Complementary & supplementary angles

description: Use your knowledge about complementary and supplementary angles to find missing angles.
title: Complementary & supplementary angles

description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.
title: Equation practice with complementary angles

description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.
title: Equation practice with supplementary angles

description: Given the sum of a pair of angles and the algebraic expressions that represent them, form and solve an equation.
title: Equation practice with angle addition

description: By using our knowledge of supplementary, adjacent, and vertical angles, we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!
title: Intro to vertical angles

description: Use your knowledge about vertical angles to find missing angle measures.
title: Vertical angles

description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles, watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.
title: Find measure of vertical angles

description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.
title: Equation practice with vertical angles

description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles, form and solve an equation.
title: Equation practice with vertical angles

description: Solve this word problem to find the measure of angles. In this example you'll split up a pie (don't forget to share!)
title: Find measure of angles word problem

description: Practice setting up algebraic equations to solve unknown angle problems.
title: Unknown angle problems (with algebra)

description: Here we will understand the meaning of various types of related angles like complementary, supplementary and vertical angles. We will use these concepts to find values of unknown angles.
title: Related angles

description: Sal draws two parallel lines and a transversal, then introduces some new vocabulary.
title: Angles, parallel lines, & transversals

description: Sal draws two parallel lines and a transversal, then finds some missing angle measurements.
title: Missing angles with a transversal

description: Find missing angles given two parallel lines and a transversal.
title: Parallel lines

description: Here we will understand the various relationships that a pair of lines can have with each other. We will understand the meaning of parallel lines, transversals, congruent angles, and how to figure out angles between transversal and parallel lines.
title: Pairs of lines

description: Proof by contradiction that corresponding angle equivalence implies parallel lines
title: Parallel lines & corresponding angles proof

description: There is a simple way to prove that two lines are parallel. If we have a transversal which cuts two lines such that the interior angles are equal to each other, then the two lines are parallel to each other. Let's see how this works!
title: Checking for parallel lines

description: A 'line' has no end points, a 'line segment' has two end points, and an 'angle' is formed when lines or line segments meet. This is where we dive into the world of geometry!
title: Chapter 5: Lines and angles

description: Sal gives a formal proof that the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.
title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof

description: Figuring out angles in a triangle. A little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles
title: Triangle angle example

description: Another example finding angles in triangles
title: Triangle angle example 2

description: Multiple ways to solve for the angles of multiple triangles
title: Triangle angle example 3

description: Example of angle hunting!
title: Triangle angle challenge problem 2

description: Use your knowledge about angles to find missing angle measures in various situations.
title: Finding angle measures 1

description: Use your knowledge about angles to find missing angle measures in various complex situations.
title: Finding angle measures 2

description: The sum of the three interior angles of a triangle is always 180 degree. This property helps us solve a wide variety of problems based on Triangles.
title: Angle sum property of a triangle

description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving, by Richard Rusczyk).
title: Isosceles & equilateral triangles problems

description: The measures of two angles of an isosceles triangle are 3x+5 and x+16. Find all possible values of x.
title: Finding angles in isosceles triangles

description: Here we will learn two special types of triangles: Equilateral and Isosceles. A triangle in which all the three sides are of equal lengths and the measure of each angle is 60 degree is called an 'equilateral' triangle , whereas a triangle with two sides equal is called 'Isosceles'. Also, the angles opposite to equal sides of an isosceles triangle are equal and on the basis of this property, we are going to find missing angles of triangles.
title: Two special triangles: equilateral and isosceles

description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem
title: Triangle inequality theorem

description: Given the lengths of two sides of a triangle, what can we say about the third side?
title: Triangle inequality theorem

description: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third side. This is called Triangle Inequality Theorem.
title: Sum of lengths of two sides of a triangle

description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!
title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2

description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!
title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 1

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.
title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: fishing boat

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.
title: Pythagorean theorem example

description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.
title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet

description: Find the leg or hypotenuse of a right triangle using the Pythagorean theorem.
title: Pythagorean theorem

description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using the Pythagorean Theorem!
title: Pythagorean theorem word problems

description: A right-angled triangle is the one in which the measure of one of the angles is 90 degrees. In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides. This is called Pythagorean Theorem. If the Pythagoras property holds, the triangle must be right-angled.
title: Right angled triangles and Pythagoras property

description: A triangle is a simple closed curve made of three line segments. It has three vertices, three sides and three angles.
title: Chapter 6: The triangle and its properties

description: Let's take line segments a little further. How do we know if line segments are congruent? Let's watch this example of counting points to see if they have the exact same length.
title: Congruent line segments

description: If two line segments have the same length, they are congruent and vice versa.
title: Congruence among line segments

description: In this chapter, we will learn what congruence is and learn different criteria for proving the congruence of two triangles
title: Chapter 7: Congruence of triangles

description: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If Ben reads 10 pages in 15 minutes, how long does it take him to read 40 pages?"
title: Ratio word problems

description: Use rates to solve word problems. For example, Charlie can type 675 words in 9 minutes. How many words can Charlie type in 13 minutes?
title: Rate problems

description: Ratios are a comparison between two quantities. If two ratios are equivalent, they are said to be in proportion. You have already studied about ratios and unitary method in rade 6th, let's see how much you remember!
title: Equivalent ratios

description: Let's think about what percent really means by looking at a 10 by 10 grid.
title: The meaning of percent

description: Percents are parts per hundred. So, how does this work for percents greater than 100% like 109%?
title: Meaning of 109%

description: Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2
title: Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2

description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!
title: Percent word problem: recycling cans

description: Sal converts 0.601 to a percent.
title: Converting decimals to percents: 0.601

description: Sal converts 1.501 to a percent.
title: Converting decimals to percents: 1.501

description: Practice expressing a decimal like 0.546 as a percent.
title: Converting decimals to percents

description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.
title: Converting percents to decimals & fractions example

description: Sal converts 59.2% to a decimal.
title: Converting percents to decimals: 59.2%

description: Sal converts 113.9% to a decimal.
title: Converting percents to decimals: 113.9%

description: Practice expressing a percent like 12.3% as a decimal.
title: Converting percents to decimals

description: 'Percent' comes from the latin 'Per Centum'. The latin word Centum means 100. So a percentage is a measure of the quantity we have of a specific part in relation to 100 portions of the whole! Here we will understand how to convert decimals to percents, percents to decimals, and discuss some percent word problems as well!
title: Percentage: another way of comparing quantities

description: There are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages, decimals, and fractions. Watch as Sal finds the percentage of a whole number.
title: Percent of a whole number

description: Fractions are our friends as we use them to find a percentage. You'll also see a couple of different ways to arrive at the answer.
title: Finding a percent

description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.
title: Percent word problem: 100 is what percent of 80?

description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.
title: Growing by a percentage

description: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!
title: Percent word problem: 78 is 15% of what number?

description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.
title: Percent word problem: guavas

description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.
title: Percent word problem: penguins

description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100; solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
title: Finding percents

description: Practice solving word problems involving percents.
title: Percent word problems

description: Percentages are used in every day life to state progress, ratio of quantities, probability etc. When we say we have done 50% of the work we mean that 1/2 of the work has been completed. Let's do a couple of examples to understand this better!
title: Use of percentages

description: We compare quantities to arrive at conclusions and take decisions all the time. In such situations, to have any meaningful result, the units of the quantities being compared must be equal!
title: Chapter 8: Comparing quantities

description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.
title: Decimals & fractions on the number line

description: Practice placing positive and negative fractions and decimals on the number line.
title: Rational numbers on the number line

description: Here we will learn how to represent decimals, fractions, rational numbers on number line. Representation of rational numbers on number line makes their comparison easier!
title: Rational numbers on a number line

description: U09_L1_T3_we4 Comparing Rational Numbers
title: Comparing rational numbers

description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.
title: Ordering negative numbers

description: Practice putting positive and negative numbers in order. For example, -28, 12, -51, and 43.
title: Ordering negative numbers

description: Sal puts 7/3, -5/2, 0, -2, -12/4, -3.25 in order from least to greatest.
title: Ordering rational numbers

description: Practice putting positive and negative fractions and decimals in order. For example, -12/4, -2.5, and 3.25.
title: Ordering rational numbers

description: Given a, b, and c shown on the number line, Sal determines if statements like -b < c are true.
title: Negative numbers, variables, number line

description: Practice comparing positive and negative numbers by thinking about their positions on the number line. Numbers to the right are greater than numbers to the left.
title: Negative numbers, variables, number line

description: We know how to compare two integers or two fractions and tell which is smaller or which is greater among them. Let us now see how we can compare two rational numbers
title: Comparison of rational numbers

description: Sal proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.
title: Proof: sum & product of two rationals is rational

description: We know how to add, subtract, multiply and divide integers as well as fractions. Let us now study these basic operations on rational numbers
title: Operations on rational numbers

description: A number which can be expressed in the form p/q where p and q are integers and q is not equal to zero is called a Rational Number.
title: Chapter 9: Rational numbers

description: Find the missing side length of a rectangle when given its perimeter or area.  Compare perimeters and areas of rectangles.
title: Area & perimeter of rectangles word problems

description: The perimeter of a square of side A is equal to four times one of its side (4XA), whereas, the perimeter of a rectangle with length L and breadth B is two times the sum of two adjacent sides(2 X [L+B] ). Area of a rectangle is the product of its length and breadth (LXB), whereas, Area of a square is the square of its side (A X A). All this you have already studied in previous classes, let's see how much you remember!
title: Squares and rectangles

description: Guess what's interesting about the opposite sides of a parallelogram? That's right....they are parallel! Let's find the area--base times height
title: Area of parallelogram proof

description: Practice finding the area of parallelograms given base and height.
title: Area of parallelograms

description: A parallelogram is a four-sided figure whose opposite sides are parallel. Here we will learn how to calculate area of parallelogram. The area of parallelogram is the product of its base and height (b * h).
title: Area of a parallelogram

description: Proving that the area of any triangle is 1/2 b x h
title: Area of triangle proof

description: Practice finding the area of right, acute, and obtuse triangles from a diagram.
title: Area of triangles

description: The area of triangle is 1/2 * base * height. Here we will learn how to derive this formula and solve an exercise based on finding area of trianges.
title: Area of triangles

description: The Perimeter of a shape is the distance around a closed figure while its area is the part of plane or region occupied by the closed figure.
title: Chapter 11: Perimeter and area

description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.
title: Writing expressions with variables

description: A variable is denoted by 'x,y,z…' and it can hold many values whereas a constant has a fixed value. The combination of variables and constants makes up an algebraic expression. You have already lean how to form algebraic expressions in class 6th, let's check how much you remember.
title: How are expressions formed?

description: This video explains what the words term, factor, and coefficient mean. Think of an expression as a sentence. A sentence has parts, and so does an algebraic expression.
title: Terms, factors, & coefficients

description: Practice picking out the terms, factors, and coefficients in algebraic expressions.
title: Terms, factors, & coefficients

description: In this topic, we will learn what is meant by terms, factors and coefficients.
title: Terms of an expression

description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.
title: Intro to combining like terms

description: So what if we add not just numbers or variables..but expressions? Here's a simple example to get you thinking about this.
title: Adding expressions

description: Another good explanation (minus Chuck Norris) on the how we combine like terms in algebra. This will totally make sense.
title: Combining like terms

description: We're going to simplify this expression together putting to use our new knowledge of how to combine like terms. Ok? Let's do it!
title: Combining like terms example

description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.
title: Combining like terms challenge problem

description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. Coefficients on some terms are negative.
title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients

description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.
title: Simplifying expressions

description: Practice combining like terms using the distributive property. These problems involve adding and subtracting negative numbers.
title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients & distribution

description: Learn how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.
title: Simplifying expressions with rational numbers

description: We're looking to find the expressions that are equivalent to a given expression that can be simplified. Give it a try with us.
title: Equivalent forms of expressions

description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.
title: Equivalent expressions

description: Sal simplifies (16x+14) - (3x² + x - 9).
title: Subtracting polynomials

description: Example: Subtract (x²+2xy-y) and (3x+5xy+2y²).
title: Add & subtract polynomials: two variables

description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).
title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials

description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3xy + 25) - (9y²x + 7xy - 20).
title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables (example 2)

description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).
title: Adding polynomials: two variables

description: When terms have the same algebraic factors, they are like terms. When terms have different algebraic factors, they are unlike terms. Here we will learn how to write expressions and how to add expressions. While adding and subtracting expressions, first look for like terms and add them; then handle unlike terms. Let's understand this better!
title: Like and unlike terms: adding and subtracting

description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents, specifically, are our focus here.
title: Evaluating expressions with variables: exponents

description: Evaluating exponential expressions 2
title: Evaluating exponential expressions 2

description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!
title: Evaluating expressions with variables: temperature

description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables

description: Evaluating Expressions with Two Variables
title: Example: Evaluating expressions with 2 variables

description: Practice plugging in a value for the variable in an equation. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.
title: Evaluating expressions with one variable

description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables.
title: Evaluating expressions with two variables

description: The value of an algebraic expression depends on the values of the variables forming the expression. There are a number of situations in which we need to find the value of an expression, such as when we wish to check whether a particular value of a variable satisfies a given equation or not. Let's understand in detail what we mean by this!
title: Finding the value of an expression

description: An algebraic expression is an expression built up from constants, variables, and the arithmetic operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
title: Chapter 12: Algebraic expressions

description: Taking an exponent is basically the act of repeated multiplication. You know how to multiply, right? If so, understanding exponents is completely within your grasp!
title: Intro to exponents

description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth
title: Exponentiation warmup

description: Practice taking exponents of whole numbers. All exponents in these problems are either positive or zero.
title: Exponents

description: Sal examines patterns in powers of 10.  He also introduces the terms exponent and base.
title: Patterns in powers of 10

description: Practice evaluating powers of ten.
title: Powers of ten

description: Now that we understand how to interpret an exponent and how the patterns in zeros are related to the exponent, we can solve more complicated problems!
title: Exponents and powers of 10 patterns

description: Here we will get to know what exponents are through various examples.
title: Exponents

description: Gain a deep intuition for these exponent properties: (x^a)( x^b)=x^(a+b) and (xy)^a=(x^a)(y^a) and (x^a)^b=x^(a*b)
title: Exponent properties with products

description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c and (a^b)^c. See WHY they work and HOW to use them.
title: Exponent properties with parantheses

description: When multiplying numbers with common base, add exponents
title: Exponent properties 1

description: Exponent Properties 2
title: Exponent properties 2

description: Exponent Properties 3
title: Exponent properties 3

description: Discover a pattern that explains why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.
title: The 0 & 1st power

description: Apply what we know about negative numbers to determine how negative bases with exponents are affected and what patterns develop. Also learn how order of operations affect the pattern.
title: Exponents with negative bases

description: Practice raising positive and negative numbers (integers only) to whole number powers. Watch out for mischievous negative signs that aren't really part of the base!
title: Exponents with integer bases

description: In this topic we will understand the laws which govern the way in which exponents behave under different combinations of multiplication and division of powers and bases and simplify problems.
title: Laws of exponents with examples

description: Very large numbers, for example 1685742300000 are difficult to read, understand and compare. To make these numbers easier to read, understand and compare, we use exponents.
title: Chapter 13: Exponents and powers

description: Sal introduces the concept of an "axis of symmetry."
title: Intro to reflective symmetry

description: Draw and identify lines of symmetry.  Create and identify symmetrical shapes.
title: Identify lines of symmetry and symmetrical figures

description: The concept of line symmetry is closely related to mirror reflection. A shape has line symmetry when one half of it is the mirror image of the other half. A mirror line, thus, helps to visualise a line of symmetry.
title: Lines of symmetry for regular polygons

description: Symmetry is an important geometrical concept, commonly exhibited in nature and is used almost in every field of activity. Artists, professionals, designers of clothing or jewelry, car manufacturers, architects and many others make use of the idea of symmetry. The beehives, the flowers, the tree-leaves, religious symbols, rugs, and handkerchiefs — everywhere you find symmetrical designs.
title: Chapter 14: Symmetry

description: Practice matching 2D nets to the 3D shapes the fold up into.
title: Nets of polyhedra

description: Sal solves a problem about whether or not a certain net could be folded up into a certain rectangular prism.
title: Nets of polyhedra

description: Practice using the net of a 3D figure to find surface area.
title: Surface area using nets

description: Practice finding the surface area of 3D objects.
title: Surface area

description: A net is a sort of skeleton-outline in 2-D, which, when folded, results in a 3-D shape.
title: Nets for building 3D shapes

description: Can you see that, the two dimensional figures can be identified as the faces of the three dimensional shapes? For example a cylinder has two faces which are circles, and a pyramid, shaped like this has triangles as its faces.We will now try to see how some of these 3-D shapes can be visualised on a 2D- surface, that is, on paper.
title: Chapter 15: Visualizing solid shapes

description: Number Sets
title: Number sets

description: Number Sets 1
title: Number sets 1

description: Number Sets 3
title: Number sets 3

description: We have already seen basic operations on rational numbers. We now try to explore some properties of operations on the different types of numbers seen so far.
title: Introduction

description: Simple idea that multiplying by a numbers multiplicative inverse gets you back to one
title: Inverse property of multiplication

description: Commutative Property for Addition
title: Commutative property for addition

description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.
title: Distributive property over addition

description: Here we have some algebraic expressions to which we need to apply the distributive property. Now we're beginning to see how useful this property can be!
title: Distributive property algebraic expressions

description: You'll be a pro applying the distributive property once you've solved these exercise examples with us.
title: Distributive property exercise examples

description: Practice applying the distributive property to factor numerical expressions (no variables).
title: Factor with the distributive property

description: We're looking to find the expressions that are equivalent to a given expression that can be simplified. Give it a try with us.
title: Equivalent forms of expressions

description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.
title: Equivalent expressions

description: In this topic we will look at the inverse property of multiplication, distributive property of algebraic expressions, equivalent forms of expressions, etc.
title: Properties of a rational number

description: Rational numbers can be expressed in the form p/q where p and q are integers and q is not equal to zero. In this chapter we will look at some properties of rational numbers.
title: Chapter 1: Rational numbers

description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.
title: One-step multiplication & division equations

description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.
title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

description: We have already studied how to solve equations with variable on one side in class 7th, let's see how much you remember!
title: Solving equations with linear expressions on one side and numbers on the other

description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations.
title: Modeling with one-step equations

description: Practice finding the nth number in a sequence of consecutive numbers based on the sum.
title: Sums of consecutive integers

description: We have already studied how to frame and solve equations with variable on one side in class 7th, let's see how much you remember!
title: Some applications

description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.
title: Why we do the same thing to both sides: Variable on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.
title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7y = 6y - 6.
title: How to solve an equation with variables on both sides (20 - 7y = 6y - 6)

description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.
title: Equations with variables on both sides: 20-7x=6x-6

description: Practice solving one-variable equations like 20 - 7x = 6x - 6, where the variable appears on both sides of the equals sign.
title: Equations with variables on both sides

description: In the above cases, we had one variable on only one side, but this might not always be the case. Both LHS and RHS can have variables. Note: Just like numbers, variables can, also, be transposed from one side of the equation to the other.
title: Solving equations with the variable on both sides

description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
title: Equations with parentheses

description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.
title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions

description: Fine tuning our skills as we tackle more equations in which we utilize the distributive property.
title: Ex 2: Distributive property to simplify

description: Let's do a few examples (including a word problem) in which we put the distributive property to work solving multi-step equations.
title: Ex 1: Distributive property to simplify

description: The power of the distributive property allows us to solve these examples equations (and a word problem).
title: Ex 3: Distributive property to simplify

description: Practice solving equations with parentheses using the distributive property.
title: Equations with parentheses

description: Here we will study how to reduce complex linear equations to simpler form.
title: Reducing equations to simpler form

description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.
title: Equation with the variable in the denominator

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?
title: Age word problem: Arman & Diya

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?
title: Age word problem: Imran

description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago, William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?
title: Age word problem: Ben & William

description: Solve age word problems with a system of equations.
title: Age word problems

description: Here we are going to deal with the framing of equations that variables on both sides of the equality.
title: Some more applications

description: Equations having variables with the highest power as '1' are called linear equations, for example 2x+7=3. Here the power of x is 1. In this chapter we will introduce the concept of equations with variables on both sides, and we will look into some applications for linear equations.
title: Chapter 2: Linear equations in one variable

description: Showing a generalized way to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon
title: Sum of interior angles of a polygon

description: Find the sum of interior angles of different polygons.
title: Angles of a polygon

description: Polygons are many-sided figures, with sides that are line segments. Polygons are named according to the number of sides and angles they have. The most familiar polygons are the triangle, the rectangle, and the square. In this topic we will learn about the exterior angle property, interior angle property, and we will also practice with some exercises related to polygons.
title: Polygons

description: More elegant way to find the sum of the exterior angles of a convex polygon
title: Sum of the exterior angles of a polygon

description: In this section we will learn about how to calculate the sum of the measure of the exterior angles of a polygon.
title: Sum of the measures of the exterior angles of a polygon

description: Sal discusses a special type of quadrilateral, the kite.
title: Kites as a geometric shape

description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.
title: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram

description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.
title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram

description: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.
title: Proof: Diagonals of a parallelogram

description: A quadrilateral is a four sides polygon with 4 angles. In this topic we will learn about the different kinds of quadrilaterals that can exist!
title: Kinds of quadrilaterals

description: Sal discusses the properties of quadrilaterals, parallelograms, trapezoids, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.
title: Quadrilateral properties

description: Sal classifies quadrilaterals by their properties (such as parallel sides).
title: Classifying quadrilaterals

description: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with two pairs of parallel sides. The opposite or facing sides of a parallelogram are of equal length and the opposite angles of a parallelogram are of equal measure. In this chapter we will learn about two different kinds of parallelograms, the rhombus and the rectangle.
title: Some special parallelograms

description: A quadrilateral is a four-sided polygon with four angles. There are many kinds of quadrilaterals. The five most common types are the parallelogram, the rectangle, the square, the trapezoid, and the rhombus. In this chapter we will learn about polygons, different types of quadrilaterals, and the special case of parallelograms!
title: Chapter 3: Understanding quadrilaterals

description: Begin your journey into the world of statistics with some warm-up questions about data sets.
title: Data set warm-up

description: In this video, we organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).
title: Frequency tables & dot plots

description: Practice creating frequency tables from small data sets.
title: Creating frequency tables

description: Practice creating dot plots. Dot plots are very similar to frequency tables, but they make it easier to see the data.
title: Creating dot plots

description: Practice reading basic dot plots and frequency tables.
title: Reading dot plots & frequency tables

description: Usually, data available to us is in an unorganised form called raw data. To draw meaningful inferences, we need to organise the data systematically. We will learn about a couple of ways to do so.
title: Organizing data

description: Histograms
title: Histograms

description: Learn how to create histograms, which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.
title: Creating a histogram

description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms, which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.
title: Interpreting a histogram

description: Practice creating histograms.
title: Creating histograms

description: Practice reading histograms.
title: Reading histograms

description: Read and interpret a double bar graphs.
title: Read bar graphs 2

description: In this topic we will learn about depicting and interpreting data on bar graphs, and pictographs.
title: Grouping Data

description: In this chapter we will learn about interpreting data in interesting ways. We will learn how to read and depict data on bars, graphs and charts, and we will also introduce the topic of probability. Probability is used in our daily life, so we will look into it in detail by practicing with many questions.
title: Chapter 5: Data handling

description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.
title: Intro to square roots

description: Understanding Square Roots
title: Understanding square roots

description: Practice finding the square root of a perfect square positive integer.
title: Square roots of perfect squares

description: Sal rewrites 5√117 as 15√13, and finds that 3√26 cannot be simplified further.
title: Simplifying square roots

description: Using exponent rules to simplify radicals or square roots
title: Simplifying radicals

description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.
title: Square root of decimal

description: Sal simplifies 3√(500x³) as 30x√(5x).
title: Simplifying radical terms

description: For example, simplify √18 as 3√2.
title: Simplify square roots

description: The square root of a given number is an integer which yields the given number when multiplied by itself.
title: Square roots

description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.
title: Approximating square roots to hundredths

description: Practice finding the approximate value of square roots by thinking about perfect squares.
title: Approximating square roots

description: In this topic we will learn how to estimate square roots when we cannot find the exact result, using a simple method.
title: Estimating square roots

description: A square of an integer is the product of some integer with itself. Similarly, the square root of a number is an integer which when multiplied with itself give this number. In this topic we will increase our understanding of squares, square roots, and will will learn about ways of finding them.
title: Chapter 6: Squares and square roots

description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.
title: Intro to cube roots

description: Learn how to find the cube root of -512.
title: Cube root of a negative number
Cube root of a non-perfect cube

description: Simplifying Radical Expressions1
title: Simplifying a cube root

description: Practice finding the cube root of a perfect cube positive integer.
title: Cube roots

description: In this topic we will learn about ways to find the cube root of a number and we will solve some exercises to practice this technique.
title: Cube roots

description: We get the cube of a number by finding the result of its multiplication with itself three times. Similarly, we can find the original number from this result by finding the cube root. In this topic we will learn more about cubes and cube roots.
title: Chapter 7: Cubes and cubes roots

description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations really are.
title: Variables, expressions, & equations

description: An algebraic expression is a statement built up from integer constants, variables, and the algebraic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
title: What are expressions?

description: Example: Add (2x²-3) and (7x³-4x+1).
title: Add polynomials

description: Example: Subtract (x²+2xy-y) and (3x+5xy+2y²).
title: Add & subtract polynomials: two variables

description: You have already studied how to add and subtract algebraic expressions in grade 7, let's see how much you remember!
title: Addition and subtraction of algebraic expressions

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4y and width 2y as a monomial.
title: Multiplying monomials to find area

description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4xy and width 2y as a monomial.
title: Multiplying monomials to find area: two variables

description: Express the product of two monomial expressions as a single monomial
title: Multiply monomials

description: Here we will learn multiplication of monomials by finding area of rectangle.
title: Multiplying a monomial by a monomial

description: Sal multiplies -4x² by (3x² + 25x - 7).
title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a monomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply monomials by polynomials

description: Here we will learn how to multiply a monomial with a polynomial.
title: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial

description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.
title: Multiplying binomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of two binomials as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply binomials intro

description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials

description: Use the distributive property to express the product of a binomial and a polynomial as a single polynomial.
title: Multiply binomials by polynomials

description: Here we will learn how to multiply a polynomial with a polynomial, a binomial with a binomial, and a binomial with a trinomial.
title: Multiplying a polynomial by a polynomial

description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.
title: More examples of special products

description: Sal expand the difference of squares (2x+8)(2x-8) as 4x²-64.
title: Special products of the form (ax+b)(ax-b)

description: Sal expands the perfect square (7x+10)² as 49x^2+140x+100.
title: Squaring binomials of the form (ax+b)²

description: Find perfect squares of the forms (x+a)² and (x-a)², and differences of squares of the form (x+a)(x-a).
title: Special products of binomials

description: Sal finds the area of a square with side (6x-5y).
title: Special products of binomials: two variables

description: Find special products (perfect squares and difference of squares) of "advanced" binomials: binomials with leading coefficients other than 1; binomials with higher degrees; and binomials with two variables.
title: Special products of binomials (advanced)

description: An identity is an equality, which is true for all values of the variables in the equality. Here we will learn three standard identities- (a+b)^2=a^2+b^2+2ab, (a-b)^2=a^2+b^2-2ab, (a+b)(a-b)=a^2-b^2.
title: Standard identities

description: An algebraic expression is an expression built up from integer constants, variables, and the algebraic operations. In this chapter we will learn about expressions, factors, coefficients, monomials, binomials, and polynomials.
title: Chapter 9: Algebraic expressions and identities

description: Practice interesting area and circumference problems.
title: Area and circumference of circles challenge

description: Practice finding the area of parallelograms given base and height.
title: Area of parallelograms

description: We have studied about area of squares, rectangles, triangles, circles in previous classes; let's check how much you remember!
title: Let us recall

description: A trapezoid is a cousin of the parallelogram. However, in trapezoid only two of the opposing sides are parallel to each other. Here's we explain how to find its area.
title: Area of trapezoids

description: Practice finding the areas of trapezoids.
title: Area of trapezoids

description: A quadrilateral which has one pair of opposite sides parallel is called trapezium. Here we will learn how to calculate area of trapezium
title: Area of a trapezium

description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.
title: Proof: Rhombus area

description: Here we will learn how to calculate area of rhombus.
title: Area of general quadrilaterals

description: Don't be intimidated by odd looking geometric figures and being asked to find its area. In this example you'll understand that breaking up the figure into smaller geometric shapes that are regular make the task a lot easier.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: Practice solving problems involving triangles, parallelograms, and composite figures. Exercises include decimals, fractions, and word problems. Area of circles is not included.
title: Area challenge

description: Practice finding the areas of complex shapes that are composed of smaller shapes.
title: Area of composite shapes

description: A polygon can be decomposed into different parts and the area of individual parts can be added to find the area of polygon.
title: Area of polygons

description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.
title: Intro to volume

description: Sal measures rectangular prisms with cube units.
title: Measuring volume with unit cubes

description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area time length.
title: Measuring volume as area times length

description: Learn how to find the volume of a rectangular prism that has fractional side lengths. The prism in this video has dimensions 3/5 by 1 1/6 by 3/7.
title: Volume of a rectangular prism: fractional dimensions

description: Sal finds the area of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.
title: Volume of a rectangular prism

description: Find volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.  Find a missing side length on a rectangular prism when given the volume.
title: Volume 1

description: Practice finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths.
title: Volume with fractions

description: Sal using volume of a rectangular prism to solve a word problem.
title: Volume word problem: water tank

description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.
title: Volume of a ring

description: In this tutorial we'll practice finding solid geometry volume. Keep paper and pencil nearby in case you want to remember the formulas.
title: Volume of triangular prism & cube

description: How many crates can we fit into a boxcar? We'll explain that there's more than one way to solve for the volume in this problem.
title: Volume of rectangles inside rectangles

description: Sal explains how to find the value of a rectangular prism fish tank that fractional side lengths.
title: Volume of a rectangular prism: word problem

description: Find volume of rectangular prisms to solve word problems.
title: Volume word problems

description: Practice solving volume word problems involving objects like fish tanks, truck beds, and refrigerators.
title: Volume word problems: fractions & decimals

description: Finding the volume and surface area of a cylinder
title: Cylinder volume & surface area

description: In this topic we will learn about three dimensional shapes like Cubes, Cuboids, and Cylinders and we will learn about to calculate their volumes.
title: Volume of cube, cuboid, and cylinder

description: The part of geometry concerned with ascertaining lengths, areas, and volumes, is called Mensuration. In this chapter we will add to what we have already studied in previous classes by learning about new shapes like Cube, Cuboid, Cylinder and their volumes.
title: Chapter 11: Mensuration

description: How does a negative exponent affect our answer? Before you assume that the answer must be negative, think again!
title: Negative exponents

description: Intuition on why a^-b = 1/(a^b) (and why a^0 =1)
title: Negative exponent intuition

description: Practice computing numbers raised to positive and negative exponents. Bases may be fractions.
title: Negative exponents

description: In this topic we will learn about negative exponents, exponent properties involving quotients, zero, non-negative, and fractional exponents. We will also solve some exercises to have a better understanding of this topic.
title: Powers with negative exponents

description: Introduction to exponent rules
title: Exponent rules part 1

description: 2 more exponent rules with an introduction to composite problems
title: Exponent rules part 2

description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).
title: Exponent properties with quotients

description: Exponent Properties 4
title: Exponent properties 4

description: Practice applying properties of exponents.
title: Properties of exponents

description: Practice evaluating expressions by adding, subtracting, or multiplying exponents.
title: Using exponent rules to evaluate expressions

description: We have already studied laws of exponents in grade 7 but there powers of exponents used to be positive. Here we will study about the laws of exponents with negative powers. The laws which are applicable to positive powers of exponents shall be applicable on negative powers of  exponents as well.
title: Laws of exponents

description: Introduction to scientific notation. An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.
title: Introduction to scientific notation

description: Learn how to solve a variety of scientific notation problems.
title: Scientific notation examples

description: More scientific notation examples
title: Scientific notation examples

description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!
title: Scientific notation example: 0.0000000003457

description: Learn how to solve a multiplication problem using scientific notation: (9.1 * 10^6)(3.2 * 10^-5)
title: Multiplying in scientific notation example

description: Practice expressing numbers in scientific notation.
title: Scientific notation

description: Multiplying really big or really small numbers is much easier when using scientific notation. This video gives an example of multiplying three numbers that are written in scientific notation.
title: Multiplying three numbers in scientific notation

description: Amazingly, we can figure out how far the sun is from the earth if we know how to multiply numbers in scientific notation.
title: Scientific notation word problem: speed of light

description: Ever wonder what your part of the national debt is? It might surprise you. What isn't surprising is that you can use scientific notation and division to figure out the answer.
title: Scientific notation word problem: U.S. national debt

description: Learn how to simplify a multiplication and division expression using scientific notation. The expression in this problem is (7 * 10^5) / ((2 * 10^-2)(2.5 * 10^9)).
title: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation

description: Practice expressing products and quotients in scientific notation.
title: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation

description: Sal simplifies a very hairy expression that involves quantities in scientific notation.
title: Simplifying in scientific notation challenge

description: Vampires and math students want to know: How many red blood cells are in the a human body? We can find the answer using scientific notation.
title: Scientific notation word problem: red blood cells

description: Practice solving more challenging problems involving scientific notation.
title: Scientific notation challenge

description: Here we will learn how large and small numbrs can be expressed in standard form/scientfic notation and solve various word problems with that.
title: Use of Exponents to Express Small Numbers in Standard Form

description: Exponents are shorthand for repeated multiplication of the same thing by itself, and it's power refers to the number of times it is multiplied. In this chapter we will learn about the basics of exponents and introduce the concept of powers with negative exponents.
title: Chapter 12: Exponents and powers

description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.
title: Intro to direct & inverse variation

description: Sal gives many examples of two-variable equations where the variables vary directly, inversely, or neither.
title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation

description: Proportionality Constant for Direct Variation
title: Proportionality constant for direct variation

description: Direct Variation 1
title: Direct variation 1

description: Direct Variation Application
title: Direct variation application

description: Given a few two-variable equations, find those that show direct or inverse variation.
title: Recognize direct & inverse variation

description: Some examples of writing two ratios and setting them equal to each other to solve proportion word problems
title: Writing proportions example

description: Practice writing proportions to describe real-world situations.
title: Writing proportions

description: Here's a great video where we explain the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers, too.
title: Solving proportions example

description: Practice solving basic proportions.
title: Solving proportions

description: We're putting some nifty thinking to work as we use proportions to create equations which then tell us how much tip to leave for dinner.
title: Constructing equations from proportions to solve problems

description: A slightly more involved ratio problem with algebra
title: Ratio problem with basic algebra

description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. Mow much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?
title: Proportion word problem: cookies

description: Mika can eat 21 hot dogs in 66 minutes. She wants to know how many minutes it would take her to eat 35 hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.
title: Proportion word problem: hot dogs

description: Practice setting up and solving proportions to solve word problems.
title: Proportion word problems

description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.
title: Rates with fractions

description: One common application of rate is determining speed. Watch as we solve a rate problem finding speed in meters per second using distance (in meters) and time (in seconds).
title: Rate problem using fractions

description: Two values are said to be in direct proportion when increase in one results in an increase in the other. Similarly, they are said to be in indirect proportion when the increase in one results in a decrease in the other.
title: Direct and inverse proportions

description: Two values are said to be in direct proportion when increase in one results in an increase in the other. Similarly, they are said to be in indirect proportion when the increase in one results in a decrease in the other. I this chapter we will learn more about these properties.
title: Chapter 13: Direct and inverse proportions

description: Learn how to expand the following expression that has rational coefficients: 6(-4w + 1/2)
title: How to expand an expressions using the distributive property

description: In this topic we will see how to expand an expression using the distributive property.
title: What Is factorization?

description: Sal explains what polynomial long division is, and gives various examples of polynomial long divisions.
title: Intro to long division of polynomials

description:
We have learnt how to add and subtract algebraic expressions. We also know how to
multiply two expressions. We have not however, looked at division of one algebraic
expression by another. In this section we will learn about that.
title: Division of algebraic expressions

description: Factorization is the decomposition of an object (for example, a number, a polynomial) into a product of other objects, or factors, which when multiplied together give the original. In this chapter we will learn about methods of factorization.
title: Chapter 14: Factorization

description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)
title: Reading pie graphs (circle graphs)

description: Histograms
title: Histograms

description: Have you seen graphs in the newspapers, television, magazines, books etc.? The purpose of the graph is to show numerical facts in visual form so that they can be understood quickly, easily and clearly. Thus graphs are visual representations of data collected. Let's recall some of the graphs about which we have studied earlier.
title: Introduction

description: A line graph is another way to visually represent data, especially data that changes over time. They are extremely useful Let's take a look at this example.
title: Reading line graphs

description: A series of points, discrete or continuous, forming a curve or surface, each of which represents a value of a variable make up a linear graph. It can also be called a network of lines connecting points. In this topic we will learn how to read a line graph.
title: Linear graphs

description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.
title: Linear graphs word problems

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear graphs word problem: cats

description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.
title: Linear equations word problems: volcano

description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.
title: Linear equations word problems: earnings

description: Sal uses a linear equation to model the amount of snow on the ground.
title: Modeling with linear equations: snow

description: Solve word problems about real world relationships that are given in graphs.
title: Linear equations word problems: graphs

description: In this topic we will learn about visualization of sequence relationships, interpreting & graphing relationships, interpreting relationships betweens patterns on a graph, and we will do some exercises which will help us understand the use of graphs a little better!
title: Some applications

description: Graphs are a graphical depiction of data, or relation between two or more variables. In this chapter we will learn about linear graphs, coordinates, and some applications. We will see that data becomes very easy to understand and interpret when depicted through graphs!
title: Chapter 15: Introduction to graphs

description: Sal writes 14,897 in expanded form.
title: Writing a number in expanded form

description: Practice reading and writing numbers written in expanded form. Example: The expanded form of 376 is 300 + 70 + 6.
title: Write whole numbers in expanded form

description: Sal writes six hundred forty-five million, five hundred eighty-four thousand, four hundred sixty-two with numbers.
title: Writing a number in standard form

description: Practice working with whole numbers in written form. For example, "one thousand four hundred three" is the written form of 1403.
title: Write numbers in written form

description: Sal regroups 4500 different ways.
title: Regrouping numbers into various place values

description: Practice problems to challenge your understanding of whole number place value
title: Whole number place value challenge

description: Writing numbers in the expanded form, as '10a + b' or '100a + 10b + c'.
title: Numbers in general form

description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests
title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10

description: Recognizing Divisibility
title: Recognizing divisibility

description: Why you can add the digits to see if something is divisible by 3
title: The why of the 3 divisibility rule

description: Why you can test divisibility by 9 by just adding the digits
title: The why of the 9 divisibility rule

description: Common Divisibility Examples
title: Common divisibility examples

description: In grade 6, you learnt how to check divisibility by the following divisors: 10, 5, 2, 3, 6, 4, 8, 9, 11. You would have found the tests easy to do, but you may have wondered at the same time why they work. Now, in this chapter, we shall go into the “why” aspect of the above.
title: Tests of divisibility

description: You have studied various types of numbers such as natural numbers, whole numbers, integers and rational numbers.You have also studied a number of interesting properties about them. In grade 6, we explored finding factors and multiples and the relationships among them. In this chapter, we will explore numbers in more detail. These ideas help in justifying tests of divisibility.
title: Chapter 16: Playing with numbers

description: Watch videos and practice your skills for almost any math subject.
title: Math
